fields.text:
* Software Engineering *                                       -*-muse-*-


Technology + Process + Management = Innovation

**Better Technology**

    Selecting the right tools and technology is an important part of every software
    development project. Use the best available technologies that are well suited for
    your specific business problems.

    Use tools that are readily available to solve common problems. Build new tools only
    when required to solve your unique problem.  A standard tool can often solve a problem
    with a small fraction of the investment required by custom software.

    Pick tools that are proven to produce better results. We have over 50 years of
    combined engineering experience that makes us experts at tool selection. 

    Key Technologies Used:
    * Linux
    * Python
    * Django
    * Node JS
    * Angular JS
    * Git
    

**Better Process**

    How you build software dictates the results that you will get.  The software process
    dictates how you plan, design, implement, test, deploy, and maintain your software.

    Design patterns increase leverage. Use standard solutions to common problem.  Figure
    out the changing elements and develop standard solutions that can be applied to future
    problems. 

    Create common coding patterns to leverage code resue.  Software can be reused in many
    ways and all levels.  Define your product development strategy to maximize leverage of
    the definition, design, libraries, and functions that you develop.

    We use the following processes because they have proven to produce better results.
    Best practices result in higher quality and lower cost.

    * Frameworks increase leverage
    * Common problems are already solved
    * Extensive use of code generation
    * Completely automatic testing
    * Flexibility of custom code at the cost of off-the-shelf code


**Better Project Management**

    We deliver results weekly! This lets you see the resulting product long before it is
    done. You define the project scope and priorities.

    Redirect the engineering to match growing understanding of need.  We believe that it
    is impossible to understand the full product at the beginning of the project.  By
    building the product you can se and respond to the design throughout the development.

    Traditional software planning defines the product details at the beginning of the
    project.  Then the development proceeds until the most of the budget is consumed.
    This is far too late to make meaningful changes.  We beleive that this is a serious
    mistake that leads to failed projects.

    We will send results to you so that you can see the product as it emerges. This gives
    you the opportunity to redirect the work to match your priorities.  Do as much (or as
    little) as you want. This flexible work engagement helps you get exactly what you want.


**Full range of services**

We manage, create, test, and support software development.  Use us as you would your own
engineering teams.

Manage

    understand top business needs
    prioritize work
    communicate progress
    coordinate

Create

    deliver solutions to top problems
    develop new tools for future problems
    leverage systems for efficiency
    rapid development and incremental deployment

Test

    find defects immediately
    build automatic tests
    leverage tools across projects
    focus coverage on top priorities

Support

    refactoring of legacy code
    keep the system running
    address new bix needs quickly
    understand operations
    embrace biz needs
    training in best practices
 

**Simple Pricing**

Choosing the correct pricing model for your project. How you want to pay for your project
depends on a number of different factors.


Effort-based pricing

 * Pay for each hour of engineering services delivered.
 * Works best if many details of the project are unknown.
 * Good fit for exploratory work.
 * Project can be guided throughout the development.
 * Maximizes flexibility.

Value-based price model:

 * Pay for the value delivered.
 * Works best if the project is well understood.
 * Good for routine work like replacing existing functionality.
 * Requires clear understanding of project scope.
 * More expensive for exploratory projects.
 * Requires concrete and robust project specifications.

[[Pricing]]

fields.text:
* My Book *                 -*-muse-*-

MyBook is an electronic publishing format that allows you to author
and publish your content on the internet. Readers can either browse
the content interactively on the web or download the entire book for
off-line reading, when you don't have an active internet connection.

Authors can create the material online and download a copy of the data
file to their local computer for safe keeping. You own the content
file that is displayed on your My Book site.  You can move from
creating content to instant publishing.

As a publisher you can
create your own site which is hosted at My Book Online.org. You can
also download the software and use it to set up your own host
environment.
fields.title: My Book

fields.text:
* Reader User Stories *                 -*-muse-*-

The reader can download an HTML or PDF file that contains the entire
content of the book. This is very convenient for offline reading.

Each topic contains references to other web sites. This is a powerful
way to provide links to additional information that is not contained
directly within the book.

An index of all the topics can be seen through the Table of
Contents. This lets the reader jump very quickly to any topic from a
single page. It also helps the reader to understand the overall
content of the book.
fields.title: Reader User Stories

fields.text:
* Modify an Existing Topic *                 -*-muse-*-


To modify an existing topic just select "Edit topic" from the bottom
menu. Change the content and hit "Save Topic". This will save the
changes back in the database on the web site. Now everyone will see
the changed topic.
fields.title: Modify an Existing Topic

fields.text:
* My Book for the Developer *                 -*-muse-*-

MyBook is an open source project that is dedicated to making it easy
for everyone to publish books online. We believe that many people have
something meaningful to say and that tools should be readily available
without requiring advanced technical training.
fields.title: My Book for the Developer

fields.text:
* Writer User Stories *                 -*-muse-*-

The writing features are protected by a password. The author must be
logged in to edit any of the online content.

There is a view that allows the order of all the topics to be
modified. It is a customized version of the table of contents. The
current topic can be moved up and down in the reading order. The
effect of this operation is to change the which topic is considered
the parent of the topic in question.
fields.title: Writer User Stories

fields.text:
* Get Involved *                 -*-muse-*-

MyBook is an open-source project that gives you the ability to read,
write, and publish. We believe that everyone should be able to do this
free of charge. We also believe that the software that allows this
should be given away for other people to build on.

If you believe in this goal then work with us to build something of
value to help everyone. We have immediate needs for three main types
of contributors. First, we need programmers to help build the wish
list. Second, we need marketing people to help build and promote the
brand "MyBook". Third, we need people that can write to help add
instructions and supply feedback while they use the software.

If you want to help us build MyBookOnline.org then contact Mark Seaman
at http://MarkSeaman.org. Mark is the founder of this project and is
currently coordinating the efforts of others.
fields.title: Get Involved

fields.text:
* My Book for the Publisher *                 -*-muse-*-

Publishing involves the administration of the site, authors, and
content. As a publisher you can create a new site to be used to
display your online book. Creating a new book means that you create a
place for the book on the server and create a database that holds all
of your content. It also displays the content of your book using a web
address (know as a URL) that is unique to your book.

Sometimes
you will want to delete topic completely from the database. Note that
this is different than deleting the text within a topic. MyBook
provides tools for deleting the records that hold topics that you no
longer want. Go to the "Change topics" link in the authoring tools to
remove unwanted topics.

As a publisher you can grant permission
to other authors. This allows them to collaborate with you on a MyBook
project. It is a great way to jointly develop an online book
together.

As a publisher you can download a copy of the entire
web site as a data file. This gives you an electronic form of the book
in a single file. You can backup your copy of the book and restore it
later if you wish. This gives you full control over your MyBook
content. The web site is then nothing more than a display vehicle for
your content.
fields.title: My Book for the Publisher

fields.text:
* Searching MyBook *                 -*-muse-*-

Each MyBook can be searched to find keywords. This makes it a perfect
format for reference materials. You can quickly jump to the topics
that you need and bypass the labor of thumbing through many pages of
material looking for the needle in your haystack.

Currently the browsers search capability is used to find the content
that you are interested in. The best way to search is to go to the
"Entire book" page. This creates an HTML page that shows all of the
content for the book.

Next you use the "Ctrl-F" key to let you set the phrase to search
for. You can use the "Next" button to select other matches. Once you
find the topic in the "Entire book" page you can use the links of the
topic titles to go the topic display for that page. This lets you find
other topics that are connected to this one.
fields.title: Searching MyBook

fields.text:
* Online reading *                 -*-muse-*-

To read MyBook all you need is an internet connection and a web
browser. A perfect device for reading is a low cost netbook or a
iPad.

The content of the book is organized as a series of topics. Each topic
is nested under related topics to provide more details. When
displaying a page of topics the text from the topics one level down is
also displayed. This allows you to read while getting a slightly more
complete context without clicking to go deeper. This sneak-peek
feature is one of the innovations in usability unique to MyBook.

An index will get you to each of the topics in the book quickly. The
index page shows you all of the topics of the first three levels of
the book. This lets you scan the entire book looking for interesting
topics. It encourages you to skim rather than read the whole
book. People are busy and they are looking for value quickly. In this
internet age we are all looking for instant gratification.

Each page of the site has links to help you get back to where you came
from. Click on any of these link to go up in the topic list. This
gives you an extremely fast way to jump through the topics of
interests. It lets your readers catch the ideas that they are
interested in without having to wade through the rest.
fields.title: Online reading

fields.text:
* Write a new article *                 -*-muse-*-

To create a new topic select "Write" in the top menu. Enter the
information that you wish to add.

Use the "Parent" selector to establish the reading order for this
topic. Select the parent topic that this one is a subtopic for.

That's it. Now you've added your first article.
fields.title: Write a new article

fields.text:
* My Book for the Author *                 -*-muse-*-

My Book contains all the tools that you need for creating the content
for your book online. This chapter will step you through how to write
articles and modify them later.

Also in this chapter you will learn how to connect the individual
topic together so that the reader will have an easy time navigating
through them.
fields.title: My Book for the Author

fields.text:
* Feature wish list *                 -*-muse-*-

This project is directed by a wish list of things we want to see
implemented. These user stories not yet implemented, but we intend to
implement them as quickly as possible.

If you have interest in working on one of these features then read the
Get involved section to see how.
fields.title: Feature wish list

fields.text:
* My Slides Online *      -*-muse-*-
Making a slide show just became a "no-brainer"!
 
 By Mark Seaman
 http://myslidesonline.org
fields.title: My Slides Online

fields.text:
* Delete a topic *                 -*-muse-*-

Occasionally you will need to delete a topic that has been
created. When a topic is deleted all of the references to that topic
are automatically removed for you.

There are two ways to delete a topic. You can select "Change Topics"
from the bottom menu and then select the topic that you wish to
delete. In the edit view you will see a delete option at the bottom of
the screen.

In order to delete multiple topics at once you can go
to the "Change Topics" screen and click on the check boxes for the
topics you want to delete. Then select the "Delete items" from the
Action list.
fields.title: Delete a topic

fields.text:
* Project Goals *                 -*-muse-*-

There are several distinct goals for this project. Each of these goals is important for the success of the project.

  * deliver a great online reading experience.

  * download an eBook for offline reading.

  * allow anyone to use the software any way they choose.

  * provide convenient way for authors to create published material online.

  * protect the content with secure access and backup of data..

  * invites collaboration from other programmers.
fields.title: Project Goals

fields.text:
* Technology *                 -*-muse-*-

There are several key technologies that are used to build MyBook. Each
of the unique technologies work together to bring a stable foundation
for the MyBook platform. Any of these technologies may be replaced by
another that provides improved characteristics. This chapter outline
the current technology stack that is used today.

**Technologies**
 * Linux
 * Apache/MySQL
 * Python/Django
 * CSS/HTML

**Django** 
The most important technology decision for MyBook is the
selection of the Django web application framework. Django is perfect
for these types of applications. It is easy to write shell scripts
that write the custom code for the application.

Django is very flexible in allowing custom code where it is needed
while eliminating any repeated code structures that are common within
web applications. In other words it is easy to write a simple program
that does nothing and then grow it into a powerful application by
incrementally adding features.

**Python**
The Django application framework is written mostly in the
Python programming language. Python is a very concise and powerful
language. Programmers familiar with Python are much more productive
than programmers using other languages. There is excellent support for
both high and low-level language features.

Python also enjoys some of the fastest execution times for scripting
languages. It is extremely portable and can run across many computer
architectures and operating systems.

**MySQL**
The MyBook application saves its data in a MySQL
database. MySQL is an open-sourced implementation of the Structured
Query Language (SQL) that drives most databases in use today. It is
available free of charge. It is free to use in any way that you see
fit.

Overall it is the leading choice of developers looking for an
alternative to the proprietary solutions provided by large
vendors. This issue of vendor lock-in can be a significant millstone
around the neck of any project.
fields.title: Technology

fields.text:
* Developer notes *                 -*-muse-*-

This chapter covers the MyBook functionality from the software
developer's perspective. MyBookOnline.org is a web site that hosts an
open source project. The MyBook server is available to anyone that
needs it under the Gnu Software License.
fields.title: Developer notes

fields.text:
* My Book for the Reader *                 -*-muse-*-


The readers of "MyBook" can read the content online from the web
site. They can also download the book in HTML or PDF format for
offline reading. Both of these capabilities are part of the reader
experience.
fields.title: My Book for the Reader

fields.text:
* Change the Reading Order *                 -*-muse-*-


The order that the topics are presented to the user is determined by
the nesting of the topics. All topics are arranged in a
hierarchy. Each topic has a single parent. You can select this parent
anytime you are editing a topic.
fields.title: Change the Reading Order

fields.text:
* Self hosting *                 -*-muse-*-

MyBook is set up to let you host your own web site.  You need to find
an internet service provider (or ISP) to setup an account that allows
you shell access.  Then download the software for MyBook onto your
computer.  Once the software is working properly on your local
computer you will transfer it to your ISP account.

In order to get this working properly you should be familiar with the
following technologies:

  * Linux command line
  * Python
  * MySQL
  * Django
  * Apache 

This is a good project for a computer hobbyist that enjoys a
challenging computer project and views the experience as a learning
opportunity.  This is definitely not the best hosting alternative to
use if you are not familiar with each of the prerequisite
technologies.
fields.title: Self hosting

fields.text:
* My Book Hosting *                 -*-muse-*-

MyBook is a tool that can be used to publish any online content. There
are MyBook Hosting Services available that will provide a complete
host environment for the MyBook content.

Another option is for you to set up your own MyBook Hosting. MyBook is
available in source code for so that you can install all of the
software that you need to run your MyBook application.

MyBookOnline.org is a web site that hosts the open source project. The
MyBook server is available to anyone that needs it under the Gnu
Software License.
fields.title: My Book Hosting

fields.text:
* Building user stories *                 -*-muse-*-

An application is a collection of features that are interconnected to
support the desired user experience. Each group of related features
provides certain capabilities for the user. The scenarios that are
implemented are called "user stories". These stories describe the task
that can be performed by the application.

This project is intended to be immediately useful in its most
embryonic form. Many projects are only useful when they have been
fully completed. MyBook is organized and driven by having an initial
core functionality that is improved over time.

Each step of the evolution will only make it better. This also means
that the application itself is constantly under construction. New
features are not added to the application until they work correctly.

This gives you a stable and reliable platform that you can use that
will continue to get better over time.
fields.title: Building user stories

fields.text:
* Download My Book *                 -*-muse-*-

The content of MyBook can be downloaded in HTML format. This single
file can be used on any computer. It is very portable to any web
browser and compatible with any operating system.

You can easily import HTML into a word processor (such as Microsoft
Word). This can be useful for working with the content in a way other
than how it was originally published.
fields.title: Download My Book

fields.text:
* Fix Watermill Cron *                 -*-muse-*-
How to fix the support issues in 6.0.

Issues with 6.0
---------------
1. Mills are not setup to automatically load the software in the field.
2. Easy to lose the accounting data by resetting the mill.
3. No script is run before the load operation.


Fixes 
----- 

1. Capture current state of ethan (crontab, /etc/rc.local). Update server script with changes
from ethan. Make sure that diagnostics and engineer tools are deployed.  Sync files with contents of
server.

2. Build new code and deploy on ethan.  Use 'set-power-on' script to configure the autoload. 

3. Setup cron to 'save-data' every five minutes. Confirm that cron starts up automatically.  Confirm
that file updates are saved.

4. Use python script to configure a known accounting file.

5. Confirm automatic save.

6. Setup reload to 'recall-data'. Confirm that accounting is saved.

7. Add 'on-shutdown' hook to run a script before the 'load' replaces the software.

8. Fold all changes into initial flash card image.

9. Create official build for 6.0 RC3.


Files
------
startup/load
diagnostics/load
startup/version-banner
startup/startAllProcs.sh

cron/mill-frequently
cron/mill-hourly
cron/mill-daily
cron/mill-hourly-cron
cron/mill-daily-cron

data/save-data
data/recall-data

cron/setup-crontab.sh

build/packcode

----------------------

diagnostics/*
diagnostics/on-reload
diagnostics/on-shutdown
diagnostics/tank-level
diagnostics/set-tank
diagnostics/wm_daily_accounting
diagnostics/wm_collection

engineer/*
engineer/reboot-watermill
engineer/set-power-on


See also [[Watermill]]
fields.title: Fix Watermill Cron

fields.text:
* Business Partners *                 -*-muse-*-

BusinessPolicies to build a business on

    1. **Agile** - we only do what must be done
    2. **Trust** - we aim for life-long partnerships
    3. **Value** - we look for 10 times ROI
    4. **Solutions** - we solve pressing problems quickly and elegantly
    5. **Best Practices** - we do what works
    6. **Open** - we freely share everything we can

BusinessOpportunities to work over the next year

    **Fifty Tricks**            - Writer        - Develop training materials for the intenet 
    **Corporate trainer**       - Trainer       - Contract with training company 
    **Contract engineering**    - Engineer      - Work primarily for a single client
    **Business growth**         - Entrepreneur  - Build a leading software engineering company

TacticalPartnerships

    Business collaborator   - Coordinates the business side of client interactions
    Technical collaborator  - Delivers value by creating services and products
    Client                  - Pays for solutions to business problems
    Owner                   - Invests money for future profits

CompanyGrowth 

    1.  solo software consultant
    2.  two senior developers
    3.  marketing, junior and senior developer
    5.  business, marketing, small development team (3)

**Agile Business**

    Every action should put us in a better position for future benefits

    1. Reflect and review to build list of possible opportunities
    2. Pick next problem to solve
    3. Act quickly with available resources and acceptable risk
    4. Learn from action and continue with step 1

**Identify Potential Opportunities**

    What would success look like for you?   Risk/reward
    What opportunities do you see for collaborating? Project ideas - business ideas
    How would you like to structure the arrangement? 
    Would you be willing to meet regularly?
 

See also [[Business]], BusinessPractices
fields.title: Business Partners

fields.text:

* Bit Rot Economics *                 -*-muse-*-

**Development Cost**
    Typical project: 5 engineers * 2 years * 200-300K lines
    Project cost: 10 ey * $200K = $2M
    Project size: 1-2 lines/hr * 200K hr = 200-400K lines
    Maintenance: expected cost is 20% of dev cost

**Context Change**
    Input:    10%/y
    Output:   10%/y
    Platform: 10%/y
    Behavior: 10%/y

**Cause for Decay**
    Structure reflects the system needs
    Needs change --> Structure changes
    Desire for short-term fixes
    Not allowed to do it right

**Decay Rate**
     0% bit rot - At intro      (10 eng-years)
    20% bit rot - One year out  (40% decay, 20% repair)
    40% bit rot - Two years out (80% decay, 40% repair)  
    It will take two more years to replace this system

See also WorldClassSoftware

* Spiritual Issues *                 -*-muse-*-

There are some issues that need attention over a long period of time.  Most of these are at there
core issues of the spirit that involve embracing God's truth about our lives.

**1. Disappointment and fear for Christine**

I have felt like I have done everything that I know how to do and nothing seems to help her. She
seems so struct that I fear for her life.  She has really unhealthy eating habbits and has gain a
lot of weight.  

She is not motivated to get paying work and I believe that she would not be able to hold a job for
more than a short while.  I think that she will live with us for the rest of her life.  That creates
a great deal of resentment with me.

My relationship with Christine creates tension between Stacie and I.  She believes that Christine
needs encouragement and support, rather than confrontation.

Her relationships are all very shallow.  I have spent about 500 hours with her over the past year
and have

The viewpoint of what is good for Christine is deeply colored by my resentments toward her. If I am
to play any constructive role in her life I must be tranformed by your power and love, Lord.  Give
me your eyes and heart.

________________________________________________________________________________________

**Other issues**
Lack of affirmation from Stacie about writing
Pressure at work
Identity found in work
Create a career as a writer

Greed over time

Recognition for ministry

fields.text:
* Security *                 -*-muse-*-

I want to be healthy and financially secure.  I fear that some tragedy will destroy everything and
that I will lose it all suddenly.

At the core, this is a deep desire to be in control of everything. I need to invite God into my life
and present him with the keys.

I know that his plan for me is better than anything that I can come up with myself.  But I still
attempt to orchestrate things to be in control.

I acknowledge that this is a sickness and sin.  It blocks God's presence in my life.  It lets fear
rule over me.

The overwhelming desire to control is felt in several areas:

 * People       - Meeting new people  
 * Job          - Job search
 * Knowledge    - What I know
 * Goals        - Life goals
 * Performance  - Evaluation of my performance

I must regularly yeild to God in each of these areas.

See also [[PrayerPractices]], DreamsAndFears
fields.title: Security

fields.text:
* Pragmatic Spirituality *                 -*-muse-*-

**Peace with God**

 * A power beyond ourselves
 * Embracing truth
 * Gaining acceptance
 * Stop trying so hard

**Learning to love**

 * Receiving love
 * Loving the lovely
 * Loving the unlovely
 * Protecting the helpless  

**Making a difference**

 * Everybody has a super-power
 * Finding your purpose
 * Buy friends
 * Gather partners

**Accepting reality**

 * Courage and peace
 * Before all else fails
 * Learn God's strategy
 * Surrender everything

**Finishing well**

 * Marathon vs. sprint
 * Build the life you want
 * Happiness is tied to how you treat others
 * Never neglect your inner life

________________________________________________________________________________________

* Introduction

Many of us want to follow God but are afraid of the strange behaviors we see in others.  What if we
could have a authentic experience with God that would last the rest of our lives?  What if by
knowing God we could become more loving and at peace with ourselves and others?  This is the journey
of seeking out pragmatic spirituality.

________________________________________________________________________________________

* 1. Peace with God

Life is really pretty pointless until we can find a power beyond ourselves.  We can pursue many
things to try to fulfill our deepest desires.  But apart from having a relationship with God,
nothing will ever satisfy us. Yielding control of our lives to God is an essential aspect of a rich
life. 

We humans have an amazing capacity for self-deception.  We see things through a very distorted
lens.  We believe things because we want to, not because they are true.  At some point in our lives
we must embrace absolute truth.  This is a simple acknowledgment of reality, rather than bending
the truth to match how we think it should be.

One of the most fascinating things about the good news of reconciliation, is that when we admit the
truth about ourselves we gain God's acceptance. When we acknowledge how hopeless life without God
is, we receive his hope. With the understanding of our weakness we begin to rely on his
strength. This begins a phenomenal process of transformation.

We receive the provisions of the Lord as a gift.  As we understand this we can stop trying so hard
to earn God's love. Nothing that we can do or be, is that great anyway.  We gain his favor by seeking
relationship with him, not by trying to do favors for him.  This changes the nature of every facet
of our lives.

When we spend time alone with God we find true peace.  Opening ourselves to his presence is the
only way to truly be at peace.  This does not occur automatically.  It happens when we consciously
lay down our own plans and demands, and simply receive his love.  This can be a hard thing for us
since we live such busy lives.  But is is well worth the effort.

________________________________________________________________________________________

* 2. Learning to love

It is impossible to be happy and content unless we are able to receive love.  We learn from the Lord
how to receive love.  He desires to demonstrate his love for us in so many varied ways.  He can be
incredibly extravagant with his love.

This experience of taking in God's love changes us.  We are then able to receive love from others.
We understand that the Lord has put others in our life to be a blessing.  We experience
companionship, comfort, and Ecstasy in our relationships with others.

As God changes our hearts we are able to begin to love those around us. We discover that we can
extend more mercy to family members, friends, and coworkers.  People don't seem quite as irritating
as they once did.  This is a supernatural work.  Receiving love and mercy allows us to be more
merciful with other.

Cutting off that flow of love has the opposite effect.  We all know plenty of religious people who
are harsh and critical.  It is possible to not know God's love and be very religious.  In fact,
people who know God well are not at all religious.  Religion is about keeping rules.  It has nothing
to do with a real experience of God's love.

This process of learning to love can become so out of control that we begin to love people we don't
even know.  We hear about people that are suffering and want to figure out a way to do something to
help. Being motivated by love is completely different that feeling guilt.

We can have such a relationship with the Lord that we look for opportunities to serve others.  The
desire to protect the helpless is a direct result of knowing the God helped us when we were
helpless. The willingness to lay down our arms comes from knowing how God brought peace into our
lives when we were his enemies.

________________________________________________________________________________________

* 3. Making a difference

Everybody has a set of special abilities, personality, and life experiences.  These are not simply
an accident of chance.  Your special blend was built by God for a purpose. Think of it as a
super-power.  God has given you gifts and talents that he intends to use in some unique way.

Unfortunately, many people go through their entire life within discovering God's unique plans.
Finding your purpose in life is one of the greatest thrills there is.  Don't let the constant
demands of survival prevent you from knowing what special things that God has in store for you.

At the end of your life, the most important things you have done will be about relationships.
Invest in the lives of others.  Start with your spouse, kids, parents, and friends.  But let is go
beyond that.  Live in such a way that you are a better friend to everyone that you meet than they
are to you.

Learn to forgive.  Let go of the disappointment of life.  You are guaranteed that others will let you
down. Don't collect those hurts as if they are some kind of treasure. They are more like frozen
rattlers.  Leave them alone or you will feel the bite.  

Be intentional about working with others.  Find as much common ground as you can. Gather partners
wherever you go.  These come in many forms: coworkers, business partners, comrades, spouses,
companions, and confidants.  Seek ways to minimize disagreement and maximize the amount of
cooperation. 

________________________________________________________________________________________

* 4. Accepting reality

Courage and peace are two keep ingredients in a successful life.  You need boldness to make the
changes that must be made.  But you also need the grace to accept reality for what it is.  If you
lack courage you will live the life of a victim; but lacking peace will lead you to be a victimizer.

Before all else fails pray.  The quality of our prayer life is one of the truest measures of
spiritual maturity.  We can fake a lot of actions for others.  How we respond to the presence of God
in our lives is an indicator of our true mental and spiritual health.  This includes times when he
points out things that we would rather not see.

Learn God's strategy for you.  Because he has created each person to be completely unique, he has a
very special plan for you.  It is not the same as what he has for anyone else.  Finding the specific
opportunities that are right for you is one of the great mysteries of live.  It will bring you great
joy and tremendous satisfaction.  When you are doing what you are made for you will be the most
successful and happiest person that you could possibly be.

Give it all to the Lord. He provide you with everything that you need.  Surrendering everything will
bring you a tremendous amount of peace.  You will not feel the constant desire to control, protect,
and hoard.  Be generous with all that you have.   And not just your possessions.  Be generous with
your praise, your time, and mercy for others.  Live with an open hand.

Be open to new opportunities.  The greatest things in your life you will not see coming.  Receive
them as the gifts that they are.  Live a life of constant thankfulness and gratitude.

________________________________________________________________________________________

* 5. Finishing well

Marathon vs. sprint

Build the life you want

Happiness is tied to how you treat others

Never neglect your inner life
fields.title: Pragmatic Spirituality

fields.text:
* Hatred *                 -*-muse-*-

Taken from Psalm 103:3-7

Whenever I see destructive behavior, I will leave that scene.

I will not trust people who are betrayers, so that I won't be hurt by their actions.

I will avoid those who exploit good things like love and sex to inflict injury.

I don't want to be around those who slander or belittle others.

I avoid arrogant or superior people who try to put me down.

I want to spend my time with good-hearted and loving people who build others up.

I want to be open receive good things from others.

I desire long-term trusting relationships.

I avoid liars and people without regard for the truth.


**Things I hate**
wasted time
wasted money
injustice
manipulation
dishonesty
looking foolish
helplessness
distrust
irresponsibility
hopelessness
exploitation

 See also PrayerPractices

* Biz Portal *                 -*-muse-*-

Project Plan for Simple Apps Biz Portal

**Product definitions phases**

Simple Apps will be built in a series of phases.  Each phase will add a new value proposition to the
previous one.  This approach will allow us to have usable product quickly without having to solve
all engineering problems at once.

**Phase 1: Business Portal**
simple wiki for team collaboration
single user space
required log in to use product
every doc has 6 operations (list, show, edit, new, delete, execute)
create content for documenting business and product decisions

**Phase 2: User Applications**
separate user spaces for every registered user
user registration system
managed permissions on all documents
2 unique applications (notes, slides)
user can setup each application

**Phase 3: Public Areas**
user can share docs with others
basic social networking and user interaction
copy content from others

**Phase 4: Analytics**
tools and process for analyzing user behavior
designed customer experiments (A/B testing)
feedback system for interacting with users
programmatic tools for collaboration


See also SimpleApps

fields.text:
* Fight Bit Rot *                 -*-muse-*-
Project to help companies protect their software investment
BitRotStrategy
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Bit Rot in 1 Minute**

As a software consultant, I help companies fight bit rot.

Over time **software degrades** until it is **no longer useful**.

I have developed **techniques to fix flaws** that grow in systems resulting from **changes** over time.

The natural **decay** can be **reversed** but it takes **effort**. 

I **teach** development teams how to fight bit rot by adopting **proven practices**.

About 80% of the software systems are seriously compromised and 90% of those companies will replace
their systems with new ones.

Replacement is not cost effective.

I show companies how to extend the lifetime of their existing software.

Learn more at http://FightBitRot.com
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Bit Rot in 10 Minutes**

**Four Stroke Engine of Software Development**
Test        Automate the testing effort (measured in percent of test code)
Fix         Solve all known problems    (measured in outstanding defects)
Improve     Refactor system structure   (measured in complexity)
Extend      Create features             (measured in velocity of features)

**Software quality conundrum**
Only paid for functionality
Constant pressure for short-term results
Taking short-cuts results in technical debt

**Tech Debt** -- Measure and track
Function        Velocity
Structure       Complexity
Test            Percent of tests
Deployment      Cycle time
Merge           Time to merge
Communication   Trust level

**Software Economics**
Lessons learned from the last 50 product releases.  Major software project is expected to take
around one year and last for three years. The actual investment made is almost twice this level.
Once the software is release it has already begun aging badly.  Within a few maintenance releases it
can no longer be maintained at a reasonable cost.

Eventually the entire system is replaced at cost similar to the original development cost.  This is
very wasteful and could be prevented.

**Quality Spiral**
Poor development practices -> low quality  -> long cycles  -> high cost
Best development practices -> high quality -> short cycles -> low cost

**Best Practices**

**Agile techniques** are proven to reduce cost and improve quality
 * Short cycles
    - Measure time to business value
    - Driven by deployment cost
    - Forces best practices
    - Make it half of the current cycle time
    - Scope creep
 * Prioritized backlog
    - Stakeholder demos weekly
    - Most important things get done first
    - Stop at any time
    - Do not build until you need it
 * High-performance teams - remove 3 to destroy the team
    - Clear goals
    - Autonomy
    - Productivity mindset
    - Accountability

**Development Practices**
 * Four-stroke development engine
 * Automated testing
 * Strategic version control
 * Rapid development loop
 * Continuous integration
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Bit Rot in 1 Hour**


**Four Stroke Engine of Software Development**
Test        Automate the testing effort (measured in percent of test code)
Fix         Solve all known problems    (measured in outstanding defects)
Improve     Refactor system structure   (measured in complexity)
Extend      Create features             (measured in velocity of features)

**Software quality conundrum**
Only paid for functionality
Constant pressure for short-term results
Taking short-cuts results in technical debt

**Tech Debt** -- Measure and track
Function        Velocity
Structure       Complexity
Test            Percent of tests
Deployment      Cycle time
Merge           Time to merge
Communication   Trust level

**Software Economics**
Learned from the last 50 product releases

i - investigation
d - design
c - coding
t - testing
d - deployment
m - maintenance

           |   1   |   2   |   3   |   4   |    5
Expected    i c t d m m m          
Actual      i i c c t t d d m m m m
                                   ^
                                   system is obsolete

Expect 18 months of investment for a 3 year life
Actual investment is double 
At end-of-life new system is two year away from release
Double the development team

**Quality Spiral**
Poor development practices -> low quality  -> long cycles  -> high cost
Best development practices -> high quality -> short cycles -> low cost

**Best Practices**

Agile techniques are proven to reduce cost and improve quality
 * Short cycles
    - Measure time to business value
    - Driven by deployment cost
    - Forces best practices
    - Make it half of the current cycle time
    - Scope creep
 * Prioritized backlog
    - Stakeholder demos weekly
    - Most important things get done first
    - Stop at any time
    - Do not build until you need it
 * High-performance teams - remove 3 to destroy the team
    - Clear goals
    - Autonomy
    - Productivity mindset
    - Accountability

Development Practices

fields.text:
* Command Clusters *                 -*-muse-*-
*Groups of related commands that provide a block of functionality*

The concept of command clusters allows for an easy implementation of a group of related functions.
Each command cluster embodies operations to be done on a specific object type (represented as a
nouns, eg. command, brain, prayer, mybook, writing).


**Canonical Operations** - 12 operations for any object type

 * clone   - Create a new one by copying an existing one
 * new     - Create a new object from scratch
 * delete  - Delete an object
 * rename  - Rename an object

 * help    - List possible operations
 * list    - List all of the objects
 * show    - Display the contents of one object
 * edit    - Modify an existing object

 * search  - Search all the contents of all objects
 * find    - Search for file name pattern
 * recent  - List objects recently modified
 * old     - List the oldest objects in the system


**Command Groups**

 * ClusterCmd
 * ClusterPray
 * ClusterBrain
 * ClusterMyBook
 * ClusterBlog

See also [[Brain]], BrainLobes,  AutomateYourWorld
fields.title: Command Clusters

fields.text:
* Comcast *                 -*-muse-*-

CHAT ID: 3F892366-F39C-4C12-BC5F-31335BBFE4C2
Problem: Our DVR is malfunctioning. We have had the same unit for many years. It just recently started activing up.
Regene > Hello Mark, Thank you for contacting Comcast Live Chat Support. My name is Regene. Please give me one moment to review your information.
Regene > I hope your day is fine. I will be glad to assist you from here on.
Regene > How can I help you today?
Mark > Our DVR is malfunctioning
Regene > That seems odd that you are having this issue, I do apologize for any inconvenience this might have caused you. Rest assured I will be able to address your concern today one way or the other.
Mark > The remote does not get a response from the base unit.
Mark > I replaced batteries and nothing changed.
Mark > When FF, large amounts of the stream are skipped.
Regene > Oh, so your DVR is not responding to your remote, correct?
Mark > I think the issue is with the unit rather than the remote.
Mark > But I'm not totally sure of this
Regene > When you press any button of the remote, does the light blink?
Mark > yes
Mark > It responds eventually, in most cases
Regene > That is good. Can I ask what is the problem with your DVR? Is there any error showing up?
Mark > Does not respond to remote
Regene > Oh, can you please describe to me the color of your remote and its OK button?
Mark > sliver on top, dark gray on bottom. ok button is small red (with ok/select text)
Regene > Thank you.
Regene > Is it the platinum silver or just the light silver one?
Mark > we have two remotes
Mark > the one having problems is the lighter of the two
Regene > All right. Thank you.
Mark > can we use the other remote to operate our dvr? we have just been using in to run a remote tv without a dvr.
Regene > We actually need to program the remote to the box for it to respond Mark.
Mark > i see
Regene > Let us try to program your remote.
Regene > Yes.
Mark > our remote was working fine for years
Regene > How old is this remote?
Mark > so the issue we are having is not related to the programming
Mark > I think between 3-5 years
Regene > Oh, I see. So basically this remote was already programmed.
Mark > yes
Regene > In this case, you can actually have the remote replaced for free at the office Mark. You can get a new remote.
Regene > Let me get the address for you.
Mark > recently the system has gotten very sluggish
Mark > 404 Crystal Beach Dr. Windsor, CO 80550
Regene > Thank you.
Regene > It is here, Greeley Address: Hours: 3737 W 10th St Greeley, CO 80634 888-824-4010 Monday-Saturday: 9:00am-6:00pm. Sunday: Closed.
Mark > I think a technician visit would be great
Regene > Oh, that will be fine too Mark.
Mark > thanks
Regene > You are very much welcome!
Mark > Can you schedule a visit for me?
Regene > Yes Mark! I am on the process to set an appointment for you.
Regene > For verification and security purposes, may I ask for the last four digits of your SSN or your full account number please?
Mark > 9936
Regene > Thank you.
Regene > Oh, I am sorry, the SSN is not recorded in the account. Can I ask for the account number instead?
Mark > I have no idea where to find that
Regene > You can actually get it in your billing statement.
Regene > I hope you have it.
Mark > 8497700750493448
Regene > Thank you.
Regene > May I ask for the most reliable phone number to reach you?
Mark > 9704816240
Regene > Thank you.
Regene > Please give me a moment to work on this for you.
Regene > The earliest available schedule is 02/02/13 at 8:00-10:00 am.
Regene > Would that work for you?
Mark > yes
Regene > Great! I will finish it now for you.
Mark > Can we move that to 12:00?
Regene > Oh yes let me change it.How about 10:00-12:00 noon?
Mark > 12-2 would work better for me
Regene > Other than 10:00-12:00 noon, we have 1:00-3:00pm. Which one seems better?
Mark > 1-3
Regene > No problem!
Mark > are we all done?
Regene > I am sorry, I am seeing an error in my system which I am currently working on. We are almost done.
Regene > Oh, Mark I am sorry, we cannot go through the later schedule that 8:00-10:00 am on 02/02/13, otherwise we have to move it to another day.
Mark > ok I'll do 8:00-10:00
Regene > Thank you so much for understanding.
Regene > I already have set this schedule for you. To recap, your DVR is not responding to your remote and we addressed it by opening a ticket for an appointment as you requested. It is CR310730580. You can take note of this. You will be called prior to the visit for your notice.
Regene > Is there anything else that I can help you further for today?
Mark > thanks, bye

fields.text:
* Watermill Rules *                                                                        -*-muse-*-

The new Support Center makes it easy to check that certain business rules.  In the past we had an
open-loop system.  Watermills report data daily and this information is automatically passed on with
only rudimentary checking performed.  This required that people be watching the system to catch
errors.

The new system has a general-purpose rule checker built in.  This makes it very easy to setup rules
that must always be true.  Nightly and hourly there are test scripts that run to ensure that all of
the data in the system is valid.  The import filters for each type of data also run many of these
rules before the data is added to the tables.

If any rule is violated then the exception is sent to the engineering staff at Watermill (currently
Mark Seaman). This email will result in an investigation.  

Certain violations will be "normal" operation of the system.  These will be turned into alerts and
sent to the Watermill Operations Staff for normal handling.

There will be a transition period as we turn on detectors for all of these business rules.
Initially I expect the system to flag many issues.  Some will be false alarms, and some will point
up real flaws in the system that have caused us much heartache.

The new tools will allow us to trace problems to their root cause very quickly.  As the we track
down issues and resolve them we will enter a phase where the system will be very quiet and stable.
All of the rules are fully automatic and don't require any person to watch the system.

Here are the current set business rules:

 * Every mill must send accounting data nightly
 * Receipts must equal the value of the vends done
 * There must be a small gain in cumulative receipts each day
 * There must be a small gain in cumulative vends each day
 * Daily vends must reconcile with the cumulative values
 * Daily receipts must reconcile with the cumulative values
 * No prices are changed (without an exception generated)

 * Accounting data is exported for every mill
 * Exported data is limited to three days worth of records
 * The daily number of records in each table is not allowed to grow by more than 1%

 * No software version is changed (without an exception generated)
 * Every watermill is running the correct software version
 * New watermills are upgraded automatically
 * The correct diagnostics are distributed to every mill

 * The watermill checkup is performed nightly on every mill
 * All watermills have enough disk space
 * All watermills have a transfer process that is working
 * Every mill sends hourly logs for pressures, vends, tank level
 * Watermill logs are gathered from each mill
 * There are a small number of alerts active
 * There is at most 2 mills with a current outage

 * The inbox process is running and the inbox is empty
 * All types of data can be imported and manipulated for Unit 3999
 * No imported files are larger than expected
 * Executor is capable of executing commands and gathering results
 * The SQL data is exported from the database into the version control system
 * Database size grows by reasonable amount
 * Hourly data values are archived monthly
 * No unexpected file changes are on the server

 * Every subsystem within Support Center is working properly (eg. vends, receipts, collections, pressure, alerts, notifications, notes, dashboard, mills, contacts...)
 * Support Server is not running low on disk space.

Many of these rules are already in place the remaining ones will be added over the next few weeks.
As additional issues are spotted by people, these will be added to the system so that they can be
detected automatically in the future.
fields.title: Watermill Rules

fields.text:
* Setup Your Profile *                 -*-muse-*-

Your profile controls everything about your shell evironment.  This is the first step in configuring
Linux to your needs. Generic Linux will not give you any better productivity than generic DOS.  You
get the benefit from taking ownership of your complete environment and shaping it into exactly what
you need.

Start by creating a bin directory in your home. This will eventually house all of the commands for
your custom enviroment.

    $ mkdir bin                 # Make a place to put your commands

Edit your profile to add the path to your commands.

    $ ls -al                    # View the files in your home directory.
    $ cp .bashrc .bashrc.old    # Save your profile
    $ vi .bashrc                # Edit your profile

Find "PATH=/usr/bin:/bin...blah...blah" and add you "bin" directory.

    $ . .bashrc                 # Read the new profile into the current shell
    $ echo $PATH                # Test your path

Test what you just did.

    $ echo "echo Dude, Where's my bin" > bin/dude
    $ chmod +x bin/dude
    $ dude

Congratulations.  You just created your first custom command.  Don't worry.  We will build more
useful commands in the future.
    

See also DaysOfLinux
fields.title: Setup Your Profile

fields.text:
* User Story Process *                 -*-muse-*-

Creating a new feature in software is organized around a building a user story.  Each
story is a scenario for solving a specific user problem.

The overall process will follow a familiar pattern.

**Learn**
    understand the user problem
    describe the end goal
    identify the key elements that the solution must have
    make connections to other stories

**Plan**
    propose a solution
    detail the solution by creating a series of next steps
    reduce the solution to its core
    define how to measure success

**Test**
    figure out a test strategy
    create a testing context
    incrementally test to drive development
    build automatic monitoring for the future

**Fix**
    solve problems that emerge during the testing
    keep a list of all unsolved issues
    review progress on all defects
    work off the defect backlog

**Extend**
    add new product features
    strive to deploy the same day
    test every five minutes
    maintain a prioritized feature backlog

**Improve**
    refactor constantly
    eliminate all duplication
    identify common patterns
    create list of possible design improvements


See also SimpleAppsUserStories
fields.title: User Story Process

fields.text:
* Prayer Pals *                 -*-muse-*-

Recently the Lord has started doing a lot of work within me.  I feel like I am entering a new season
in my relationship with him. 

As I have been growing in understanding, there are things that I believe could benefit others as
well.  Some of these things are based on life stage and time spent with God, so not everyone will be
able to relate to them.

Other aspects are of a personal nature and I only feel comfortable sharing them with others that I
trust.  Fortunately, the Lord has put some wonderful people in my life, and surrounded me with
people of great depth.

You are one of the people in my cirlce that I would like to share this journey with.  One of the
ways that I process spiritual things is to write about what the Lord is doing.  If you would be
open, I can share these things with you.  Let me know if you would like to receive occasional email
about the journey of spiritual formation.

fields.text:
*  Levels of Expertise *                 -*-muse-*-

There are many levels of expertise for any skill.  It takes experience to acquire the next level.

**Novice**
Experience: First time working with this. 
Expectations: Don't know the fundamentals. Need specific steps and
guidance.

**Beginner**
Experience: Have seldom done this.
Expecations: Can follow a recipe, but don't know why or what to do
with variations.

**Competent**
Experience: Have done this several times.
Expectations: Can create recipes, and deal with variations.

**Proficient**
Experience: Done this many times.
Expectations: Understands the nuances of the different contexts.

**Expert**
Experience: Cannot count how many times
Expectations: Functions intuitively

See also [[Brain]]
fields.title: Levels of Expertise

**Return**
Expected return to build tool or knowledge.

 * High   - Greater than 100 hours
 * Medium - 10 -- 100 hours
 * Low    - Less than 10 hours

**Investment**
Expected time to build tool or knowledge.

 * High   - Greater than 40 hours
 * Medium - 4 -- 40 hours
 * Low    - Less than 4 hours

**Types of ROI**
 1. High/Low     - Major winner; do immediately
 1. High/Medium  - Great gain with at least a 4x payout; plan top three
 2. Medium/Low   - Great gain; low hangin fruit; do these as time allows
 2. High/High    - Big risk and reward; limit to one
 3. Medium/Medium- Find a simpler solution

fields.text:
* Wm After Action Report *                 -*-muse-*-

On Sunday, evening we had a failure of the Watermill server.  This is a description of what happened
and actions we are taking to repair the situation and prevent future disruptions.


What happened?

The old mill server ran out of disk space on its main volume.  This caused the system to
malfunction.   It stopped working completely at 9:30 PM on Sunday, 3-10.   It may have had problems
prior to that.

Running out of space creates a variety of mystery problems, since some operations will succeed and
others will fail.

All data traffic from the watermills goes through the old mill server.  All traffic was blocked
started and 9:30 PM, Sunday.

All data from the watermills was deposited into the local storages in the home directory for the
Watermill user.  This is not on the same volume that ran out of space.

The command that sends data to the production server was blocked causing the data traffic to be
blocked.


How we found the issue

The automatic tests reported massive failures from the blocked traffic.  Testing on the production
server confirmed that everything there was functioning properly.

The inbox on the old mill server contained several hundred files that were blocked.

The inbox script was running, but the files were not being processed.  The forwarding command was
running properly but the import command would hang when executed manually.

Restarting the process did not fix the issue.  Showing the available disk space on all volumes
revealed that the root volume was completely out of space.

Investigation reveals that a large amount of space was used by the Git repos.  The largest repo is
tied to the old mill server.  This repo grows nightly and was responsible for the problem.


What repair actions were taken?

To fix the immedate problem, I removed some old repos that are no longer needed.  This freed up 12
GB immediately.

Then with the system running properly.  I pushed all alert files through the system.  There were 84
files to be processed.  I confirmed that these went all the way through the system.

The accounting files were also processed by reimporting them into the inbox.  This resulted in all
of the accounting being brought up to date.  There were 124 files for accounting.  Mannually trigger
the export of the accounting data to Wex Net.

Next, all of the log files were imported.  We had 363 files for tank, vends, and pressure.

Testing of the system will continue throughout the day on Monday.


How can we prevent this in the future?

The root cause of the problem is the growth rate of the server git repo.  This has already been
addressed for the new server repo.  This was fixed for the new repo in January.  There is also a
test in place for disk usage on the new server.

A new test will be added for the disk space on the old server.  We will also make some changes for
the growth rate of the repo itself.


Summary

The loss of disk space resulted in a temporary outage of the watermill server.  The problem has now
been resolved with no data loss.  Additional testing and fixes will be setup to defend against this
type of problem and minimize the impact in the future.

Please report any additional problems you may see.
fields.title: Wm After Action Report

* Pray For Work *                 -*-muse-*-

Lord, the ability to work comes from you.  All provision comes at your call.  I desire to serve
others in your name.

Show me your destiny for my life.  Give me direction for the next stage of my career. Connect me
with the opportunity that is the best fit for me.

Help me understand what I value most.  Of all tradeoffs, which ones really matter?  How can my
career be used to build your kingdom.

Lord, I choose what you have for me.  I know your best plan will be better than my best.  Show me
how to search in the right places and ask the right questions.  Lead me and guide me.


See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Pray For Work

fields.text:
* Act To Learn *                 -*-muse-*-


** Act To Learn **

Most planning tools assume that we can project fom the past to the future.

Often we are faced with a future that is unpredictable.

A plan is a map to a goal.

When we get offtrack we can create a new plan to the same goal.

Along the way we may change the goal we are pursuing.

A blockage is a opportunity to reassess both the plan and the goal.

Action is far more important than thinking alone.

If you cannot predict the future you can build it.

Discover opportunities and act on them.

Define an opportunity map.

Every action should have an ROI analysis

Connecting with others leads to commitments that leads to new means and new goals


**Action model**
 1. Identify something you really want.
 2. Look at available resources.
 3. Take one smart step.
 4. Pause to reflect and learn.
 5. Repeat until done.

**Resource questions**
Who am I?
What do I know?
What resources of available to me?
Who do I know?

**One smart step**
act quickly with available resources
what can you afford to lose?
what do you want to pay?
bring in others
build off the unexpected

**Repeat until**
You don't want to continue
You exceed your loss limit
You prove it cannot be done

**Principles**
minimize risk
small steps
review and learn
replan
connect with others
follow your passion
act immediately

**Affordable loss**
money
time
reputation
missed opportunities
relationships

**Self-selected stakeholders**
 1. Enroll yourself by creating a vision
 2. Be authentic and transparent
 3. Offer a plan to accomplish their goals


 See also ActionModel, [[Understanding]]
fields.title: Act To Learn

fields.text:
* Prayer Is Encounter *                 -*-muse-*-

Prayer is vital to every aspect of life.  And yet I frequently neglect
it.  Lord show me how to pray in good times.  It is easy to pray when
things are bad.

If we pray and don't encounter God then we have missed the point.

It is a two-way conversation not a recitation. Jesus said, "Don't recite".

Prayer requires honesty and is key to personal transformation.

Prayer cannot be automated.

We rarely inform God, although we can become profoundly enlightened.

**Prayer is where I ...**
    understand and accept my brokenness
    surrender my will
    get healing
    experience the kingdom of God

See also [[Prayer]]
fields.title: Prayer Is Encounter

* System Repair 4-5-13 *                 -*-muse-*-

**Overview**
While working on the pipescan code the system triggered some operation that caused the disk to start
seeking.  Then the views started disapearing from the desktop and apps started closing.

After that the system would repeat the behavior when trying to initialize the shell environment.
Moving .bashrc let me get a window.

I belive that the disk in failing.

fields.text:
* Seasons With God *                 -*-muse-*-

**Fresh experience**
My relationship with God goes through seasons, times when the nature of our relationship changes
significantly. The Lord has recently been working in me to deepen my relationship with him. He has
been revealing both himself and my true nature.

**Transformation**
I have found a new longing to be with him, and simply enjoy his company.  The Lord has started a new
work deep within my inner-most being.  He is transforming me in surprising ways.  I welcome this work
of renewal and realize that it is something that he is doing.

**Embrace truth**
He is forcing me to look at the truth of who I actually am, rather than the illusion of how I
wish that I was.  This takes courage and honesty to admit.

**Source of what I need**
I am drawn to spend more time with Jesus. This lets me draw strength and wisdom from his presence.
In a place of solitude I am learning to lay down my burdens, confess my failures, receive healing
from hurts, expose my grief, and acknowledge foolishness and idolatry.

**Fully equipped**
In his presence I am accepted, forgiven, empowered, and equipped for the journey.  Finally I believe
that this season of life will culminate with a new energy and ability to do God's work wherever I
am.  Instead of trying harder, I will be more yielded to the purpose of God.  As I lose control,
Jesus will control me more.  I long for this new balance of power.

**Aspects of renewal:**
 1. Honesty & openness
 2. Solitude
 3. Empowerment

See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Seasons With God

fields.text:
* Memories Of Mom *                 -*-muse-*-

I have wonderful memories of my mother.  She was such a blessing in my life. She provided me with an
emotional safe haven from which I could grow.  In her presence I felt security, comfort, and hope.
She taught me that You work all things out in our lives according to Your purpose.  She saw You as
the Protector and Provider.

I miss her presence now.  But I thank You for her life and how she changed my life.  I would not
have been nearly as healthy as I am now without her being there for me.

I feel a deep sense of grief over her passing away from my life.  For the most part, I push it down
and suppress it, for fear that I will be overwhelmed with emotion.  Lord, help me to be honest with
my feelings before You.  I acknowledge that grief is an important part of life.  Help me experience
that in Your presence.

 See also
fields.title: Memories Of Mom

fields.text:
* Brightness Setting *                 -*-muse-*-

To configure the display brightness from the command line...

    sudo su -c 'echo 5 > /sys/class/backlight/acpi_video0/brightness'

Now edit /etc/rc.local file to execute this command at boot up.

    gksu gedit /etc/rc.local

Just before exit in the file, add the following line,

    echo 5 > /sys/class/backlight/acpi_video0/brightness

fields.text:
* Sabbath Rest *                 -*-muse-*-

A day without work is hard for someone with AchieverTalent. I have an internal drive to always be
proving my worth by doing.  I need to practice the Sabbath.  During this time I cease from trying to
control and win.

You are the source of every perfect gift and untainted blessing.  You supply all that I need.  You
guide the details of my life in a way that will bring You glory, and me to maturity.  For all this I
don't need to strive.  Help me rest in Your care and acknowledge You for all that You do on my
behalf.

A day of rest is also important because it causes us to pull back from the things that consume our
attention.  It is easy to believe that work is all there is to life.  But the ''To Do'' list never
relents.  The Sabbath forces a break to this thinking.  It lets us recreate to re-create our souls.
Thank You for this gift.

I want to just "be" in Your presence.  I want to live InThePresent and the Sabbath is a good way to
start.  You are God, I am not.

To have a meaningful Sabbath Rest it is important to do activities that are fundamentally different
than the regular work activities. I work on computers for a living, so working on computers as a
break is insane. I need activities that involve working with my hands, riding bikes, hiking, or
playing guitar. These are legitimate activities that would feed my soul by giving me a break in my
routine.

See also SpiritualLog
fields.title: Sabbath Rest

If you need wisdom, ask our generous God, and he will give it to you. He will not rebuke you for
asking. But when you ask him, be sure that your faith is in God alone. Do not waver, for a person
with divided loyalty is as unsettled as a wave of the sea that is blown and tossed by the wind. Such
people should not expect to receive anything from the Lord. Their loyalty is divided between God and
the world, and they are unstable in everything they do.
fields.title: Ask For Wisdom

fields.text:
* Why Bother  with Emacs? *                 -*-muse-*-

There are plenty of ways to edit text.  What makes Emacs so special?  There are a large number of
tools that you must master to succeed.  The last thing any of us need is another tool with a
complicated learning curve.


**Return on investment**
What percentage of your time is spent editing text?   If you are a software developer, like me, or
an author, then you may expect to invest a lot of time typing words into a computer.  I average about
9 hours on the computer each day.  About 75% of this time is editing text, the rest is mostly
reading on the internet or a book on my tablet.

I expect to work for another 15 years, and expect to log about 60 hours a week doing some kind of
computer interaction.  This totals to about 3000 hours a year, with 75% of the time editing text.
Realistically, I expect to spend over 33,000 hours writing.

I believe that my productivity at editing has doubled in the last year from switching to Emacs.
This will certainly save me thousands of hours over the rest of my carreer.  This is the single
largest gain that you can make related to computer usage.


**Choose the big lever**
Emacs is very complicated to use.  It has a nearly vertical learning curve. It is frustrating at first
to learn enough to do basic tasks without thinking seriously.  But it is also extremely powerful.
There is both a big cost and big reward for switch to Emacs.

Emacs is readily available on any operating system that you will ever care about.  That is what
protects any investment that you make to learn it.   Learning to become a master at Emacs will
require you about 30 hours.  After making this level of investment you will be significantly more
productive that you currently are.

After you have made the initial investment you will have unexpected gains in many daily routines.
Entire tasks that used to take a significant amount of time will simply evaporate.  You will find
yourself with a lot of extra time to thing through bigger problems. All types of repeated work will
become largely automatic with the features provided by Emacs.


**Learning strategy**
When I learned Emacs, I just jumped into the deep end of the pool.  I read a book, "Pragmatic
Thinking and Learning", by Andy Hunt.  In the book he mentioned the importance of learning how to
get good at editing text and challenged me to learn Emacs.

I decided to go for it!  I installed it and within a few minutes was completely overwhelmed.  There
is just too much to learn, and I needed to still get my job done.  I took a weekend and figured out
the basics. Then continued to push forward.  Eventually I crested the hill and got where I needed to
be.

The resulting experience is this book.  By following the path that is laid out here, you can arrive
at the same place with a lot less effort.  This book will give you a map for where you are going
before you embark.


**Pace yourself**
Everyone has their own pace.  Find one that is right for you.  Consider investing an hour each day
over the next month to work through this book.  This will get you into the "Thriving Zone" within a
month. 

There are two transformations taking place simulataneously.  You are learning new concepts and ideas
about how to use a new tool to speed up your work.  This is fairly straight forward.  

The second part is not nearly as easy to master.  You are retraining your automatic responses.  This
feels a lot like when you first learned to drive a car.  Your mind knows what you want to do but
your fingers will not follow along.

Allow yourself time to let your fingers automatically find the right keys.   Analyse the way that
you do things and make small adjustment until the editor does exactly what you think it should do.

If you believe that typing "Control-L" should sort the lines in your buffer then that is the right
answer for you.  When this process is complete you will have a super-personal editor that no one
else in the world has.


**More than typing**
Editing text files is important.  You will see how to efficiently create and manipulate text
documents.  After all, Emacs is a text editor at its core.  But there are a lot of other interesting
topics that are worth exploring.

Most of the things written to help people learn about Emacs focus on the features and aspect of the
program.  We are going to take a different approach.  Instead of learning about all of the things
that you can do, we will start with the needs that you have. 

Each day will focus on some key aspect that might need.  It will introduce the "Big Idea" and give
you some pointer.  It will also point you in the direction of getting more help and other resources
you might consider.


**Two levels of learning**
Each topic will have a key concept to understand.  You will get an idea of why this topic is
important to you and some overall pointers.  For some people this may be the only learning that you
need.  You may consider going through every topic and picking off only the big ideas.

For others you will want to go deeper.  There should be enough meat for you to digest and mull
over.  There are also excerises that you can try and other resources to follow.

I recommend reading through the high level ideas of each topic, in order to decide if you want to
invest the energy to learn Emacs.  If you do then work through the more detailed sections in any
order that you want.


**Happy travels!**
You have already started on a excellent journey.  You now know more about emacs that 99% of the
people on the plannet.  Let's see if we can push that even further in the next month.


See also [[Emacs]]
fields.title: Why Bother  with Emacs?

fields.text:
* Business Principles *                 -*-muse-*-

1. The people are the business.

2. Ownership follows sweat equity.

3. Minimum viable product with follow up of success.

4. Action trumps planning.

5. Maximize leverage.

6. Utilize each person's strengths.

7. Plan to win over the long-term.

8. Give away as much as possible.

9. Fix problems quickly.

10. Just enough structure.

11. Do what works.

12. Pay as you go.


**Business Practices**

1. The people are the business.

    Commit to working out conflict
    Respect each person's uniqueness
    Empower people to act
    Build relationshihps and trust

2. Ownership follows sweat equity.

    Focus on enlarging the pie (rather than getting a bigger piece)
    Allow different investment levels
    1 sweat share/hour invested
    Some jobs are hired out
    Owners make decisions

3. Minimum viable product with follow up of success.

    Start with core product
    Free/open/easy to gather users
    Respond to popularity
    Build four levels of implementation 

4. Action trumps planning.

    Do what you can with what you have on hand
    Act to learn
    Everything is an experiment
    Let learning guide the next steps

5. Maximize leverage.

    View each product as an asset
    Recycle common patterns
    Reduce unique solutions
    Benefits of custom at the cost of standard

6. Utilize each person's strengths.

    Everyone is unique
    Allow self-selection
    Be flexible
    Respect both autonomy and mastery

7. Plan to win over the long-term.

    Be patient
    Invest in the short term for winning later
    Make sound platform to build on
    Plan for future expansion

8. Give away as much as possible.

    Generocity builds loyalty
    Give them reason to stay
    Allow them to contribute
    Encourage calibration

9. Fix problems quickly.

    Test everything
    Follow the pain
    Don't ignore problems
    Have standard ways to respond

10. Just enough structure.

    Don't over-build
    Wait till you need it
    Less than 2 days to deploy
    Listen to feedback

11. Do what works.

    Be pragmatic
    Choose tools that solve problems
    Automate
    Meetings & email guidelines

12. Pay as you go.

    Don't borrow money
    Customer lead development
    Team owns decisions (strive for unanomous)
    Grow as quickly as practical


See also [[Business]], BusinessPractices
fields.title: Business Principles

fields.text:
* Business Policies *                 -*-muse-*-

** Objective **

What do you want from your business?

I want to build a leading company in software engineering.  We operate based on principles and
practices that allow us to produce more value than any competitor.  We build life-long partnerships
with others.  We execute projects using the best practices available.

Shrinking World Solutions is built on several core ideas.  From these a set of operating practices
govern the daily activities of the company.


** Principles of Business **

What are the unchanging principles that make your business tick?

1. **Agile** - we only do what must be done
 
There are an infinite number of things that could be done to grow the company.  But many of these
good things, are not essential.  We are committed to delay actions until they are really
needed. This allows us to concentrate on the essential tasks that produce immediate value.

2. **Trust** - we aim for life-long partnerships

All relationships are built on trust.  We seek to conduct ourselves in such a way to build trust
with our partners (clients, employees, colleagues).  These relationships are more vital to the
long-term health of the business than short-term profits.

3. **Value** - we look for 10 times ROI

There are many problems that could be worked on.  We select the problems that produce the largest
benefit for the effort expended.  Most businesses have pressing problems that cost the business a
great deal of money.  We hope to achieve results that are ten times the cost of the solution.

4. **Solutions** - we solve pressing problems quickly and elegantly

We believe that simplicity is the key to great solutions.  Often a simple solution that is put in
place immediately is far superior to a more complete solution that takes a long time to implement.

5. **Best Practices** - we do what works

We have spent decades learning and sharing best practices in software development techniques.  When
you hire us you benefit from the learning and experimentation.   This allows us to quickly implement
lasting improvements to your technology and processes.

6. **Open** - we freely share everything we can

We believe that ideas are best when shared.  We invite you to join with us in mutual collaborations
that can be share with others.  We believe that businesses win by sharing because they can move
faster than their competitors.  The days of protectionism are over.  We freely share any 
general-purpose knowledge and techniques with our clients.


See also [[Business]], BusinessPractices
fields.title: Business Policies

* Project Docs *                 -*-muse-*-

Many projects have docs.
Data driven applications are mostly defined by documents.
It is important to manage both app docs and code together.
A git repo is used to track each project.
The core source code must be clearly identified.
Doc replication and linking should be done through update.tst.
