fields.text:
* Support Center Design *                 -*-muse-*-

Support Center is the central application for maintaining all of the Watermills in the field.  This
document shows how the system is built and how it can be extended.

Another document, called Support Center Operation, contains information on how to use Support
Center.  This document is written for the engineering staff at Watermill Express.

Application in the Cloud
 Web Faction
 Server Setup Scripts        
 Support Git    
 Accounting    

Setup Hosting
 Account setup
 Application setup
 Version control
 Automated scripting

Application Logic
 Mills, users, contacts
 Alert processing
 Accounting system
 Diagnostic tools

Data Import/Export
 Alerts
 Health monitoring
 Accounting data
 Executor (for remote command execution)
 File storage to reconstruct

Commander & automation
 File import filters
 Server scripts
 Commander execution

Testing
 Unit testing
 File import testing
 Executor testing
 Overall testing
 Checkup system

Mill diagnostics
 Diagnostics from server
 Mill monitor
 MCP

Support process and training
 Support Center
 Support Center Architecture
 Field Support 
 Tech Notes 

Development process
 Automated testing (file imports, executor, unit tests, sc-test)
 Develop and test locally (sc-test, sc-apache, sc-changes, sc-commit, sc-push)
 Deploy on staging server (sc-deploy, sc-staging-term, sc-test, sc-staging-web)
 Deploy on production server (sc-deploy-production, sc-web) 

** Chapter 1 - Application in the Cloud **

**Web Faction**

The Support Server is hosted at an Internet Service Provider (ISP) called Web Faction.  The company
specializes in providing low cost, reliable hosting for Django applications.  Mike Hegdal setup the
business arrangement with Web Faction.   Login information can be obtained by contacting Mike.

We currently have two separate shared hosting accounts. The same server contains many user accounts.
 * wmexpress2@wmexpress2.webfactional.com - staging server
 * wmexpress@wmexpress.webfactional.com   - production server

The web site, database, and domain mappings are set up using a Web Faction control panel at
https://my.webfaction.com .

The web site is visible at  http://wmexpress.webfactional.com.


**Support Git**

The full contents of the web server are contained in version control.  Git repositories contain all
versions of all files needed to fully reconstruct the entire history of the project.

Each day all files are committed into the repository. Email is sent to the engineering staff for all
files that are not committed. This makes us aware of everything that is happening automatically in
the system.


**Server Setup Scripts**

All setup operations are controlled by a set of scripts.  Each script tends to be simple around five
lines of bash script.  The script performs a single function.  The complex system can be quickly
decomposed into a set of simple building blocks for testing and trouble shooting.


**Accounting**

The accounting data in the system is one of the most important aspects of the Support Server.  Each
night every mill must send a daily report to Support Server.  Each report is entered into the
database in the web application, named 'Support Center'.

These files are also archived as text files in Support Server directories.  This allows us to
completely reconstruct the data that is currently in the database from the raw mill reports.  This
is occasionally done when a problem is discovered with the web application.

** Chapter 2 - Setup Hosting **

**Account setup**

The staging and production servers are set up in two separate accounts at Web Faction. Access to
these accounts is done through ssh (secure shell).  This lets every operation be fully scripted to
produce the same results every time.


**Watermill Inbox**

 We will need to set up a third account as an inbox that all of the mills can log into.   Each mill
 will contain a key that will allow them to authenicate themselve to the Watermill Inbox.  The inbox
 account will not allow any access to the Support Server.   Instead Support Server will reach in and
 grab files from this location.


**Application setup**

The web application is written in Python.  It uses a web application framework called Django. The
application runs in the Apache web server.  The application uses a MySQL database to hold all of the
data tables.


**Version control**

All of the application is stored in a Git repository.  A bare repository offers an endpoint for
push and pull operations. This repository is housed at ssh://65.121.123.211/usr/local/support-git .

The database is saved each night as a SQL file.  This file is committed into the repository.  This
would let us track the history if it were to be important.

All data files (both input and output) are also committed into this repository.


**Automated scripting**

All deployment is done with a single command from a development machine.  'sc-deploy' is used to
push the current code to the staging server.   'sc-promote' is used to move the code from the
staging server to the production server.

All testing is performed daily by the script, 'sc-test'.   This runs a directory of scripts and
sends email containing any unexpected results.

New problems discovered in the system should be fixed by extending the scripts to detect that
particular failure.  This means that over time every problem will be detected quickly and most
problems can be fixed automatically.


** Chapter 3 - Application Logic

**Mills, users, regions**

The Support Center web application is built to take care of watermills.  Each mill record defines
information that is important for that mill.   The watermills are broken down by business needs into
markets. 

Every user in Support Center is assigned into a market.  Some users are assigned to the market
"none" and others to "all".  Users in Support Center can only see field mills within their market.
All other mill data is hidden.


**Alert processing**

When a mill is malfunctioning it sends an Alert to Support Server.  This is a file containing the
recent history of bad things that happened.

Each mill is assigned to a market.  Each user within that market can sign up to listen to all of the
alerts for the mills in their market.

As each alert is processed within the Support Center application, an email may be sent out to the
technicians and managers that have requested it.   Email notifications can be set up to send a text
message to a telephone number, using an SMS gateway.


**Accounting system**

Each mill sends a daily report of sales, vends, and pricing.  These items are gathered into Support
Center and checked for validity.

Managers can display the summary reports from this data.  This is useful for proofing the data and
watching the updates come through the system.

Each day a report is sent that contains all of the sales, vends, and pricing data that was changed
since the last report.  This data is delivered to an FTP site for importing into wexnet.


**Diagnostic tools**

There are many diagnostic tools that can be run from the server.  These scripts make it very
convenient to maintain a large number of watermills without having to log into each one
independently.

There are several high-level tools that allow many other tools to work.

    sc-milldo - execute a single command on a mill and bring back the results
    sc-millput - push a single file to a watermill
    sc-millget - pull a single file from a watermill
    sc-each-mill - do a command for each watermill in the field

Using these basic tools it is very easy to build a sophisticated system to do advanced tasks in a
reliable way.  NOTE: Extreme caution should be used when performing operations across all field mills.


** Chapter 4 - Data Import/Export

**File import mechanism**

All of the data that comes from the watermill is a simple text file.  On the mill the file is
dropped in the /root/to-brighton directory.  It is then send using scp to the
sandbox@65.121.123.211:sandbox directory.  Then the file is moved to the /root/to-brighton-sent
directory on the mill.

Nightly the /root/to-brighton directory on every mill is checked to make sure that the data is
being moved.

A script called 'handle-sandbox.sh' brings the data into the account for Support Server.   A script
called 'handle-inbox' will import each data file into the Support Center application.


**Alerts**

The alerts arrive as files in the inbox.  Each file contains a recent alert history from that mill.
This allows alert files to be lost without losing any of the history.  This is really useful when a
mill is offline for an extended period.


**Health monitoring**

Every hour each mill records its cumulative vend counts, nine pressure readings, and tank level.
Each day these logs are all sent to Support Center.  

The data is put in tables and painted into web pages for Support Center users.  Each month this data
is archived into CSV files that can be used creating analysis tools.

When diagnosing a problem on a watermill it is often useful to update the web pages with information
from today.  There is a link on the mill page that pull fresh data from the watermill.


**Accounting data**

Each day every mill sends cumulative receipts, cumulative vend counts, and prices to Support Center.
All of this data is put into cumulative data tables.  From these values the daily values are
determined.  All of the records that are changed are saved in an export table.

The records from the export table are sent into a CSV file nightly and cleared from the export
table.  If the accounting has already been exported then this operation is not repeated, so that
data loss can be prevented.


**Executor (for remote command execution)**

The web server runs as a separate user under Apache.  When it want to excute shell commands a call
is made to the executor.  This script creates a command, runs it, and puts the results back into
Support Center.

Command execution is reliable and there is a full history of what happened.  This is especially
important when executing commands on remote watermills that may not complete correctly.


**File storage to reconstruct**

The following directory structure lets us reconstruct any story long after the situation happens.

data
 accounting
  3002
  3003
  ...
  3204
  3297
  3999
 archive
  2011-01
  2011-02
  ...
  2011-11
  2011-12
 collection
 commands
 imported
 inbox
  received
  rejected
 logs
  3090
 pending
 pricing
  today
 sql
 test
  accounting
 tmp

The way that this would normally happend would be to do a pull on the staging server.   This would
avoid any interruption of business on the production server.  The a 'git checkout' would let the
engineer roll back to an earlier moment in time.  Both the database and files will be configured to
the situation that needs investigation.


** Chapter 5 - Commander & automation

**Support Center Command**

Support Center is a web site that has convenient access to a database. There is also a command-line
interface to get access to the database.   'scc' is a super-command that allows scripts to use
Support Center functionality.

Support Center Commands (scc) take automation to a higher level.  An engineer can create a script
that will do a sequence of operations applied to all of the mills in the field.  This make it easy
to chain sequences of activies together.

scc combined with the Linux toolbox makes for a world-class automation platform.  Operations that
could take a person many days to complete can now be done in minutes of thoughtful programming and
testing.  


**File import filters**

All data comes into Support Center as files. The format of the filename describes the type of data
that is being imported.  Each data type is defined with a filename pattern and a handler that knows
how to read the records for that datatype.

The following data file formats are supported:

    executor
    account
    alert
    log
    pressure
    tank
    vend
    cmd
    result
    collection  

Every file that does not match any pattern is sent to the 'rejected' folder.  This folder is checked
hourly to see if any files have landed there. 


**Server scripts**

Everything in Support Server is controlled by scripts.  This means there are a lot of individual
commands to learn.  The place to start is with the 'sc-help' command.  This lists the available
scripts with a one-line description.

Searching  /home/seaman/wme/support-git/scripts
acc-to-csv      # Convert a CSV file to a millcmd accounting file
csv-to-acc      # Convert a CSV file to a millcmd accounting file
files.py        # Utilities for scripts
sc-admin        # Show remote Support Center admin view
sc-apache       # Restart the local development web server
sc-archive-month # Archive monthly data
sc-changes      # Show the Git status
sc-check-accounting # Check to make sure that all of the daily accounting is correct
sc-checkout     # Checkout the code on the production server 
sc-clean        # Clean out all the extra files
sc-clear-inbox  # Clear the inbox folders
sc-commands     # List Watermill commands
sc-commit       # Commit all the outstanding files
sc-control-panel # Go to the Support Center control panel
sc-crontab      # Setup the crontab with tasks for Support Center
sc-daily        # Run daily testing
sc-deploy       # Deploy the staging server code
sc-do           # Run a script on the staging server
sc-download     # Download the archive files from the production server
sc-each-mill    # Do the requested command on every mill
sc-exe          # Create a new Support Center control script
sc-forward-file # Forward a file to the Support Center inbox
sc-get          # Get a file from the staging server
sc-handle-inbox # Handle the inbox files
sc-help         # List Watermill commands
sc-hourly       # Run hourly testing
sc-import       # Import a single data file
sc-inbox        # List the contents of the inbox folders
sc-init-price   # Initialize all of the pricing for all mills 
sc-initialize   # Create a new Support Center control script
sc-ip           # Lookup the mill ip address
sc-loaddb       # Create a new database from the command line
sc-log          # Show the Support Center log
sc-milldo       # Execute a script on the mill using 211 as a gateway server
sc-millget      # Get a file from the mill using 211 as a gateway server
sc-millput      # Put a file on the mill using 211 as a gateway server
sc-money-convert # Convert the money tables
sc-monthly      # Run monthly testing
sc-newdb        # Create a new database from the command line
sc-newgit       # Create a new git repo on the production server 
sc-put          # Put a file on the staging server
sc-qt           # Support Center quick test
sc-same-file    # Make sure that these files are the same
sc-savedb       # Save the database from the command line
sc-send         # Send email using the STMP at seaman@comsystem.us
sc-show         # Show local Support Center
sc-showdb       # Show database info
sc-sql          # Create a new database from the command line
sc-start-inbox  # Run the import file handler
sc-stop-inbox   # Stop the handler for the inbox
sc-term         # Support Center terminal
sc-test         # Test all of the Support Center code
sc-test-accept  # Capture all test output as correct
sc-test-capture # Capture initial output from all tests
sc-test-check   # Compare the last output with the correct output
sc-test-filter  # Put the test output through a filter
sc-test-output  # Capture all test output as correct
sc-test-results # Compare the last output with the correct output
sc-test-running # Make sure that Support Center is running
sc-test-verify  # Run a command and check the output
sc-todo         # Add an idea to the todo list
sc-web          # Show local Support Center
sc-weekly       # Run weekly testing
scc             # Execute Support Center commands

Before running any script for the first time you must know what it will do.   Most of the scripts
are very short and easy to read.  The fastest way to learn about a new script is to use 'show'
(eg. 'show sc-test' or 'show sc-web'). 

If you cannot figure out what a script will do after reading it them don't run it.  You should know
the result before you execute the command.


** Chapter 6 - Testing

**Unit testing**

Support Center is equipped with a full set of unit tests.  These test are embedded in the Support
Center Python code.  To run all of the unit test go to the Support Server Console and type 'scc
test'.  

This will create a new database for testing.  It will create all of tables needed by reading
the Django source code.  It will then perform all of the tests defined in the 'tests.py' files in
Support Center.

It will then list all of the errors, exceptions, and failed tests.  If any tests fail then they must
be fixed immediately.  Failing tests indicate that something unexpected is happening in the system.

After all of the tests are complete the test database is removed.  All tests are performed outside
of the data for the running system.


**File import testing**

The most important feature of the Support Center web application is that it reads data that comes
from the watermills.  All of this data is imported by a collection of file import filters.   Each of
these scripts knows how to read one type of data and use it to perform system operations.  See the
section on "File import filters" to see the list of supported file types.

The file import testing is done by reading in a set of known data files and checking to make sure
that Support Center does the correct things with them.  Each test is unique to what is being read.
These tests all add, remove, query and update the data in the live database. 

The tests are written so that no disruptive operations are performed.  Modification are made only to
the records of test mill '3999' which is a virtual mill.  This protects the customer data from being
changed by the test.

In order for all of the file import testing to succeed everything has to work together perfectly.
Almost any change in the file import system will cause some test to fail.  When the tests pass there
is a high degree of confidence in the inbox mechanism as well as the specific file imports.


**Executor testing**

All Linux system commands are executed outside of the web server.  This protects the web server from
hanging if a Linux command were to hang.  Support Center is capable of initiating system commands
that talk to mills or that manipulate the server computer system.

Executor is the mechanism that runs commands for the web server.  A command is written to the inbox
and imported like any other file.  The command import filter starts the execution and attempts to
create a corresponding results file.

When a result file is imported the page that requested the command is rendered and returned to the
web user.   This mechanism prevents the web server from hanging to wait for long running commands.
The user running the browser will have to wait to get the results, but other users of the system
will not be blocked.


**Overall testing**

The entire system can be tested by initiating the 'sc-test' command.  This will find a directory
filled with test scripts and run all of them.  Currently it takes six minutes to perform all tests.

Each test has a file that contains the perfect output for that test.  This makes it extremely easy
to write new tests.   When the test returns the exact output that was expected it is said to pass.
If anything else is returned, then the test fails.

At the end of the tests a summary of all of the failures is sent by email to the engineering staff
for evaluation.  Any failing tests should be fixed right away.   This prevents the bit rot that
normally happens on system, due to the changing world around the system.

To fix failing test, use the 'sc-test-results'.   This lists both the tests that failed and the
specific expected output for each of the failures.

Start by understanding why the unexpected results appeared.  Is it a recent change?  Is it a test
that is to simple?   Is the test too critical?   Does it use today's data?

Common fixes include discarding certain output from the test, accepting the actual output as the new
correct answer, or rethinking how the test is performed.

The power of this approach is that it is very easy to constantly extend the testing to cover new
situations. Each time new functionality is added then a new test can be added to ensure that the
function is working in its basic form.

If this system is used properly it will guarantee that everything will continue to work well all the
time. To encourage this, the 'sc-test' command is run automatically each day with email sent to the
engineer staff.


**Checkup system**

Each morning at 3:00 the checkup script is run.  This will perform a full test of the Support
Server.  It will also do regularly scheduled maintenance tasks that are needed (eg. backup, log
rotation, disk space management).

Each of the field mills also has special support tasks that must be done.  The script
'sc-checkup-mill' is run to do testing and maintenance of a single mill.   'sc-each-mill' is used to
run the checkup on every watermill in the system.


** Chapter 7 - Mill diagnostics

**Diagnostics from server**

There are many diagnostic tools that can be run from the server.  These scripts make it very
convenient to maintain a large number of watermills without having to log into each one
independently.

There are several high-level tools that allow many other tools to work.

    sc-milldo - execute a single command on a mill and bring back the results
    sc-millput - push a single file to a watermill
    sc-millget - pull a single file from a watermill
    sc-each-mill - do a command for each watermill in the field

Using these basic tools it is very easy to build a sophisticated system to do advanced tasks in a
reliable way.  NOTE: Extreme caution should be used when performing operations across all field mills.


**Mill monitor**

There are currently three types of data that are logged on the watermills hourly.  This data is sent
from the mill and cleared daily.  Each of these are logged hourly to analyze time-of-day trends.

    vends - all nine product vend counts 
    pressure - during idle, ro, flush  -- readings of input, ro feed, ro pressure
    tank  - tank level in gallons


**MCP**

Another tool to debug watermills is MCP (mill control program). This program is run by logging into
a console window on the watermill.  This is a text based program that can be used to view values and
change a few of them.


**Diagnostics**

All of the diagnostics are located on the server and distributed nightly to all of the watermills.
There are different types of mills so the script 'push-diagnostics' is able to determine the
diagnostics that are needed on a given mill.

NOTE: This feature is currently disabled because of the pending roll of both old and new
watermills.  It will be enabled once the roll is complete.


** Chapter 8 - Support process and training

**Support Sever Operations**

This document describes how to use Support Center to accomplish various support tasks.  It is
written for helping the users of Support Center know what to do.


**Support Server Design**

This document describes the engineering view of Support Server and the embedded Support Center web
application, and scripts.  It is important to thoroughly understand this document in order to modify
any of the components within Support Server.


**Tech Notes**

Support Center contains an embedded system for displaying and editing technical notes.


** Chapter 9 - Development process

**Automated testing**

Manual testing is very expensive.  Typically it is used to "poke around" to see if anything is
broken.  For a system as complex as Support Server most problems will not be found with this type of
testing.  Our history has been that some problems have hidden in the system for months before
discovery. Unknown problems in a system can be very costly.

Automatic tests can be performed daily (or hourly if needed).  This is the only cost-effective way to 
keep a system like Support Server functioning properly.

The key to using automatic testing is to fix every failing test immediately.  It is tempting to
ignore a failing test, but the will result in a much worse problem occurring.

There are five unique types of automated tests done within Support Server: file imports, executor,
unit tests, sc-test, system checkup.   Each of these testing types will reveal certain problems.
Each of these test will require maintenance.


**Develop and test locally**

All development should be performed on an isolated computer system.   The 'support-git' repository
contains a full set of files to create a full self-contained server.  In only requires an Ubuntu
installation with Apache, MySql, and Django installed.

    sc-help - Show me useful commands
    sc-changes, sc-commit, sc-push - Used to manage changes locally
    sc-test - Run all automatic test (don't push without running this first)
    sc-apache - Run the local app within Apache


**Deploy on staging server**

When the code has been tested and committed on the development machine it can be fully deployed onto
the staging server with a single command.

    sc-deploy - Push and pull from the staging server, restart Apache
    sc-staging-term - From a dev machine show a terminal window
    sc-staging-web - From a dev machine show the Support Server web page
    sc-test - Run all of the automatic tests on the staging server (run on wmexpress2)


**Deploy on production server**

After the code is thoroughly tested and reviewed then it can be promoted from the staging server to
the production server.

    sc-promote - Deploy the current code on the production server (always run from staging)
    sc-web - From a dev machine show the Support Server web page


See also SupportCenterOperation
fields.title: Support Center Design

fields.text:
* Software Estimation *                 -*-muse-*-

I've been working for the past year to produce a reliable model for estimating the cost of new
system.  Here is the model that I am currently using.  I believe it to be pretty accurate.

A complex system can really be decomposed into a set of discrete task.  Each task solve a unique
technical problem.  Every task has two parts (learning, and doing).  Each task that requires about
an hour of engineering, on average, once the process is fully understood.

**Learning vs. Doing**

A competent engineer can learn a new trick in about a day.  Each time a trick is performed the
learning time for that trick is cut in half.  After about four times the task is automated or super
easy to repeat.

A complex system can be estimated by estimating the sum of the effort of the tasks.  Each task is
calculated to be 1 hour plus 8 hours for each new trick to learn.  I also use partial learning
credits of 2 hours and 4 hours for tasks that have been done rarely.

**System Scope**

There are four distinct parts to creating a web application.  Each of these aspects can present
unique engineering problems.  A task breakdown should be done for each aspect to create an estimate.

I try to use technologies that are already familiar to eliminate the required learning.  Here's how
I would estimate the following using familiar technologies

Setup Hosting 
     Account setup - 1 hour 
     Application setup - 1 hour 
     Version control - 1 hour 
     Automated scripting - 1 hour

Application Logic
     Scales by data type - 3 hours/type (add, modify, find)
    * Typical web application involves about 10 data types
     Each data type requires storage and views for CRUD ops
     Application framework - URLs, views, models, etc. - scales by type
     Gather user content - no time budgeted for this

Data Import/Export
     How does data enter and leave the system?
     File import/export operations
     Email interfaces
     Transactions on web service
     Estimate using the 1 hour + learning model

Testing
     Unit testing - all functionality should be automatically tested - 2 hours
     File import testing via scripted interface - 2 hours
     Overall testing - 2 hours
     Checkup system - embedded self test - 2 hours

**Summary**

Setup Hosting       - 4 hours - 36 hours the first time 
Application Logic   - 30 hours - 150 hours if learning new technology 
Data import/export  - 4 hours - 36 hours if learning 
Testing - 8 hours   - 64 hours to learn

Total investment - 42 hours with no learning - 300-400 hours with learning everything

This matches my actual experience with learning several new platforms.

**Eliminating the Learning Curve**

One thing that comes from this analysis is the need to eliminate the learning curve.  Any good
programmer can learn to do what is required to complete any job.  But the cost effectiveness is
based on how many times each trick has been performed.

The primary choice of technology is not based on the inherent effectiveness of the technology, but
on the actual effectiveness of the individual using it.  I believe that the differences between any
two technologies is a second-order effect.

A well trained engineer using .Net, Django, JSP, or PHP, will produce about the same level of
output.  There is no silver bullet.

The thing to avoid is climbing a new learning curve, unless you plan on getting a long-term benefit
for it.


See also WorldClassSoftware
fields.title: Software Estimation

fields.text:
* Review Cycles *                 -*-muse-*-

**Objective:** Create a regular pattern of reviews at different intervals

**Year**
review the past 4 quarters and envision the future
spend December 31 each year
benefit: review progress toward life goals

**Quarter**
review the past 3 months and envision the future
spend the last Saturday of the quarter
benefit: update annual goals, spiritual review

**Month**
review the past weeks and envision the future
spend two hours on the last Saturday of each month
benefit: monthly objectives

**Week**
review the past week and plan the coming one
spend two hours each Sunday afternoon
benefit: create short-term priorities

**Day**
think about yesterday and plan today
spend one hour each day
benefit: quiet reflection outside of the project activity

See also PersonalRetreat, SpiritualReview, SpiritualRetreat, MonthlyObjectives, LifeGoals
fields.title: Review Cycles

            * Use try without installing to make sure drivers can be found
            * Connect a LAN cable

            * System hung
            * Reboot and install off of thumbdrive
            * Use entire hard drive
            * Connect a LAN cable
            * Setup keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl-Space, Alt-W)
            * Setup ssh key to server
            * Activate the hardware drivers (for BroadCom and STA)
            * Configure the wireless network - SeamanFamilyLan
            * scp -r 192.168.1.101:bin .
            * mv .bashrc .bashrc.old
            * ln bin/bashrc .bashrc
            * . .bashrc
            * getdocs
            * cpmusic -c
            * Install codecs for MP3 in Rhythm Box
            * Setup cron jobs

* VNC *                 -*-muse-*-

Enable Virtual Network Computing
2-7-2009

 * Enable server software
   - Menu System, Advanced, Remote Desktop
   - Choose Allow other users to view
   - Choose Allow other users to control
   - Choose Ask you for confirmation

 * Install client software
   - Run vncviewer
   - Install tightvnc if needed

 * Configure security
   - No special steps are required

 * Run client
   - For hummer run "vncviewer 192.168.1.104"
   - For mini   run "vncviewer 192.168.1.103"
   - For rachel run "vncviewer 192.168.1.105"
   
 * Run on small display
   - On server run "vncserver -geometry 600x400 :1"
   - On client run "vncviewer 192.168.1.104:1"

See also [[Tools]]

fields.text:
* Kindle Publishing *                 -*-muse-*-

Taken from article at http://www.kindleboards.com/index.php/topic,42600.0.html
	
I posted this Kindle Primer on Authonomy, and many writers found it helpful.  I thought it might be
a useful here as a resource for epublishing Newbies, as well as other writers who have questions and
contributions.  For those whove been around awhile, you may want to skip to the second posting on
Promotion.

This is a fact: Epublishing is revolutionizing publishing, an event no less important to
intellectual discourse than the penny newspapers of the nineteenth century.

Epublishing is a viable option to seeking a traditional publisher.  Not only are established writers
publishing original material to Kindle (and other ebook platforms), but indie writers are being
offered traditional DTB (dead tree book) contracts based on their ebooks.  While the ebook market is
still only 9% of the total book market (as of 10/2010), it is a growing market.  Consumers are
expected to buy one billion dollars in ebooks by the end of the year.  So lets get aboard.

**HOW TO GET STARTED**

There is no charge to upload your manuscript to Amazon Kindle (or any of the other ebook platforms,
including Smashwords, PubIt, Kobo, iPad, Borders, Android, Sony, and Diesel). You do not have to own
a Kindle to publish on Kindle. You do not have to own a Kindle to read Kindle books (there is a free
download application for your computer on the Amazon website).

There are a handful of simple steps. Prepare your manuscript, then proof and format it to
perfection. Prepare your sales pitch, design a cover, decide on a price. Once you have these
elements together, it takes only about one hour per venue. You can finish writing a novel on Monday,
post it on Tuesday, and start making money on Friday (it takes a few days for Amazon to process it).

For Kindle, it is easier if you have a U.S. bank. Smashwords pays through PAYPAL, and is therefore
more international.  Kindle pays monthly, Smashwords pays quarterly.

**PREPARING YOUR MANUSCRIPT**

**1. COPY EDITING.** Have several people proof your work. Have at least three people (preferably fellow
writers) read your manuscript for typos.  And/or hire a professional (which will cost $300 
$1,000). If you need or want an editor, someone who chops and cuts and moves material around, and
questions you about word choice, narrative flow, storyline, etc., that will run from $2,000-$8,000,
and will take two weeks to a month.

Do an Edit/Find on redundant and passive words, such as that, starts and begins, of the,
turned, the phone and some of the, was and were.

If you cannot afford a copy editor, here's another technique several indies have employed.  Transfer
your book file to your Kindle and use the text to speech.  Read along with a hard copy of your
manuscript.  You'll be astonished by what you catch.  Very helpful and costs nothing.

NOTE: Kindle, Smashwords, and most ereaders allow readers to download a sample before buying your
book. Most readers will do this, SO MAKE THE BEGINNING OF YOUR BOOK FABULOUS. It must read so a
person is intrigued, has to know more, will not sleep until he reads more.


**2. Create a Word file** 

Put all of your files into one Microsoft Word document (including title page), single spaced,
justified. Times Roman or Arial font, or something simple. (Not courier.) Many prefer using the EPUB
file format. See Christian Cantrells Blog below.  Before you upload to Kindle, check your
formatting as Amazon converts it using HTML.

Make sure you have no tabs.  Do an Edit Replace for ^t, replacing it with nothing. Then highlight
your entire document, and use the Format, Paragraph, Indent first line feature.  (Or you can double
space between paragraphs.)

Kindle is much more flexible about format than Smashwords, but to save you from formatting your
manuscript twice, you might want to abide by Smashword rules (which you can read at Smashwords.com).
Titles and headings should not be larger than 18 pitch.


**3. Add copyright**  After your title page, you want to put something like:

Digital Edition Copyright  2010 by Author Name All rights reserved
 
The  symbol supposedly protects the text internationally. As I understand it, as soon as you've
created a text, it's copyrighted in the U.S., but that allows you only the ability to stop
republication by someone else. If you register the copyright with the Library of Congress, you are
able to collect money damages. For more information, see http://copyrightregistery-gov-form.com/

If a publisher reads what you have on Kindle, and wants to do a DTB (dead tree book), you have all
rights to sell it to them. I know of several indies who have found publishers this way.


**4. Save as HTML** 

When you are done formatting, SAVE AS a web page (HTML). This is the document you will want to
upload to Kindle.


**5. Create cover** 

A great cover does a lot to sell a book. You can design your own with free online photos and a photo
manipulation program. Photoshop is great but expensive. Gimp is free. An excellent list of websites
where you can download free photos is: http://www.photoshopsupport.com/resources/stock-photos.html

You want the title and author name to be really big, with a single intriguing image. A light cover,
letters at least 1/4 the size of the cover, lots of red. Yellow is good for title. (Look at a Kindle
book called THIN BLOOD, a brilliant cover.)

While you are working on your cover, reduce the image at times to 1-1/4 inch highthis is about how
big it will appear on the computer. If it doesnt pop out at you, or isnt easily read, change it.


**6. Create Blurb** You need to write a short synopsis, not more than 400 words. Shorter is better. Give
the synopsis to friends and ask if theyd be intrigued enough to read the book.

SHORT BLURB: You need to write a very short synopsis of 400 characters. This shorter version youll
need for Smashwords, and for self-promotion on blogs and websites.

Spend serious time on these synopses. This, apart from your cover, is your main sales tool.


**7. PRICING:**

A lot of writers first post their books for .99 cents because a number of Kindle readers routinely
buy only .99 books. It is a way to get a following. Think of it as an introductory price. The
minimum for which you can get at 70% royalty is $2.99, which is why many indie Kindle books are
$2.99. The DTB publishers often list their books at $9.99 or higher because they can. Many writers
think it's the DTB publishers way to suppress the ebook market, and to maintain a demand for
DTBs. But readers have made it clear on the forums that they think it is unfair to post an ebook for
more than a paperback.

In other words, $9.99 is probably too much for an indie ebook. Keep it under $5.00.

At some point you might want to change your price. If, for instance, you post at .99 cents and it
sells like crazy, getting you to the top 100 Kindle Best Sellers list, you might want to keep it at
.99 cents until you drop off. (The big deal about the top 100 is that it is a visible list that is
promoted by Amazon. A major goal is to get on this list.) But if you are not making a lot of sales
at .99 cents, you might as well go to $2.99 for awhile. I've had books that began to sell more when
I raised the price.

There is no stigma for .99 books on Amazon. DTB Publishers sometimes run very cheap specials (or
free) for their best sellers. Everyone, in other words, is trying to find a good price point.

Another technique--Amazon will "discount" your book if it is being sold cheaper elsewhere. You can
sell it lower at Smashwords, or keep it the same and sign up for distribution at Kobo, which
automatically discounts. Then Amazon will slash your price from say $2.99 to $2.39. People will
think they are getting a deal. You'll simply have to test out what works best for you.


**8. UPLOADING:**

You are ready to upload. There are a number of websites you can upload your ebook. Kindle,
Smashwords, PubIt, etc.  Kindle is the best, so well start with that.

Go to https://dtp.amazon.com/mn/signin

Register, then follow directions.

-Upload book and synopsis. Set price. Remember, you may want to start with a promotional price of
.99 for two weeks, then move to $2.99 where you'll get the 70 percent royalty

-Be sure to preview your book. It is laborious, but necessary.

-Add your bank account information with electronic routing number. If you are unsure about your wire
routing number, call your bank.

-Follow directions and add tags, categories, and other information.

-Kindle takes several days to upload your book, and will send you an email when it is
complete. While you wait, start working on your marketing strategy.


**9. CHANGES**:

At any point after you have published, you CAN make changes. You can change the
price. You can make editorial changes and upload again. You can change your cover and
synopsis. Amazon may take your book offline for up to 48 hours, so you dont want to do this
excessively, but it is hugely comforting to know that once its gone to print, its not carved in
stone.

**10. BACKLIST TITLES**

Many authors are uploading to Kindle previously published books when they get their rights back. You
need a letter from your publisher confirming Reversion of Rights. Upload your book. Within a few
days, Amazon will contact you and ask you to scan in your letter and send it to them. Within four or
five days, your book will be approved.

-Smashwords does not require such a letter.


**11. Barnes & Noble** 
has recently established an epublication website, PubIt. It works much the same as Kindle:
http://pubit.barnesandnoble.com/pubit_app/bn?t=pi_reg_home&code=4aa51434099049dc9bbb6f75872a952f


**12. AMAZON KINDLE for UK WRITERS:**
You have to join on the USA site with your UK password if you are already a customer, and when you
create your account it has US and UK buttons to turn on or off.

UK royalty is 30% regardless of where you are. They send a check in . If it is sold in US then they
send a check for 70% (if it is between $2.99 and $9.99).  They only send checks when it is over
$100, and will charge you $8 per check.  


**13. PROMOTION:**

The most difficult part about selling ebooks is getting the word out about them.

For my first Kindle book "Amsterdam 2012", I mentioned it on the Amazon Kindle forum and here on
Kindleboards.com. That was it. And it took off, selling over 1,000 copies the first weekend. Most
promotion is word of mouth--doing guest postings on other writers' blogs, finding interest groups
and pitching your book (e.g., if you have a book about dogs, pitching it to websites for dog
lovers), participating in various writers groups, reviewing other writers' works. The self-promotion
is time-intensive, and, yes, annoying. But even traditional publishers insist their writers do a lot
of self-promotion on their own (my last publisher asked me to hire a publicist!) There are some
websites that review ebooks only. Soon there will be established review venues. Right now everyone
is kind of flying by the seat of their britches.

AUTHOR COMMUNITIES to Join and to Promote Your Books:

- Kindleboards.com. Sign up and promote your book on the Bizarre forum. Participate in as many
discussions as you have time for. Post questions if you want. Everyone is very helpful. These boards
list a lot of other venues where you can advertise your book.

-Amazon Kindle, Discussions, Kindle Forum. There are several threads where you can plug your
book. Let friends know about where youve plugged your book, so they can comment on your remark and
keep it on the first page of comments. This helps enormously in sales. I do not recommend posting a
new thread about your book, although many do. Several trolls are very harsh to writers who hog
the forum for self-promotion. Use this venue with caution.

-Goodreads.com. Become a member and promote your book. If you spend time on their discussion boards
and make "friends", they can be really helpful.

-Nookboards.com. Become a member and promote your book.

-Soundings:Puget Sound Speaks. Promote on Board Index, Independent authors

-Mobileread.com. Become a member and promote your book on the authors promotion thread.

-Librarything.com. Become a member and promote your book.

-shelfari.com.

-Redroom.com.  Become a member and post blogs entries and stories.  They have weekly writing
challenges that are widely read.

-NOTE: Whenever you see that one of your author "friends" has a post on the Kindle Forums, chime in,
or ask them a question so they can respond, further bumping their thread. They will do the same for
you. You can follow these forums--Amazon will send you an alert, if you want, every time someone
posts.

AUTHOR BLOGS and REVIEW SITES: Here You Can Ask to Have Your Book Reviewed or be a Guest Blogger:

http://theindiespotlight.blogspot.com/ Fill out their author's interview questionnaire. They will post your book in about 3 weeks.
http://indiebooksblog.blogspot.com/
http://spaldings-racket.blogspot.com/
http://redadeptreviews.com/
http://simon-royle.com
http://dailycheapreads.com
http://candysraves.com
http://bookbuzzr.com
http://thefrugalereader.blogspot.com
http://hf-connection.com  (Historical Fiction Connection)
http://booksontheknob.blogspot.com
http://kindle-author.blogspot.com
http://coffeeandroses.blogspot.com
http://bellaonline.com
http://trishasbookshelf.blogshopt.com
http://paperbackdolls.blogspot.com
http://www.kindleobsessed.com/
http://thecajunbooklady.com
http://theunreadreader.com
http://kindlereader.blogspot.com
http://twoendsofthepen.blogspot.com
http://tinasbookreview.com
http://rexreadingrobot.com
http://cherylsbooknook.blogspot.com
http://myreadingroom-crystal.blogspot.com
http://lostforwords-corrine.blogspot.com
http://www.jennsbookshelves.com/
http://www.booksandchat.net/
http://www.thenovelblog.com/
http://kindlehomepage.blogspot.com Kindle Nation Daily, a promotional site. Promotional blitzes start at $59.
http://www.kindleboards.com also has a daily paid promotion available.
 
Simon Royle has another good list at:  
http://www.simon-royle.com/indie-reviewers

Scott Nicholson has a good list from his blog tour (emphasis on horror reviewers):
http://www.hauntedcomputer.com/booktour.htm

There are many, many more. Many are mentioned here on Kindleboards.com from time to time. It is a
question of networking and favors, but this shared promotion is invaluable.

Other Promotional Tools to Know About:

- Tagging. On your book page on Amazon, there is a place where you can list "tags" or key words that
help people find your book. Add tags, then go to Kindleboards and ask fellow writers to tag your
book. This will get your book up on the rankings for specific types of books. Very important.

- Author Page on Amazon. Amazon now gives you an author page where you can write about anything you
want to promote yourself. Put up a picture and stuff about yourself. You need to set up a separate
page for Amazon UK.

-Facebook and Twitter. Lots of writers use Facebook to promote their books. Become a fan of other
writers on FB, and they will do the same.

-If you have published DTBs, do a book giveaway on Goodreads.com.

-Blog tours.  Contact all of the sites you would like to appear on, and ask to be a guest blogger
during a specific promotion period.  Line them all up, get your blogs prepared, and promote your
tour.  Several authors have sponsored a Kindle raffle for viewers.

-Some authors have tried listing their book as an ebook on CD on Ebay.  The Ebay listing costs $.50
for a 30 day listing.  Add S&H costs.  The object here is not so much to sell CDs but to entice
Kindle owners to see the book and then check for the book on Amazon.

**14. READER REVIEWS:**
Reader Reviews are key to selling books.

-You can ask for reviews on Kindleboards.

-You can go to authonomy.com and post part or all of your book. When people comment on it, you can
ask them to post their review on Amazon.

-Many reviewers on Amazon make their emails available. You can send them an email and ask them to
review your book--sending them a free version or a Smashwords coupon.

-Amazon ranks Kindle books. Your goal is to get in the top 100, because there is a list of best
sellers which gives you wide visibility.

-Once you start getting reviews, keep a list of people who liked it, and then email them about your
next book.

-Facebook. Ask for reviews from your FB fans.

-Start a blog. If you can figure out something to say once a week (or every day) that people want to
hear, you draw a lot of folk. Quite a few writers have started blogs where other writers can promote
their works.

-Reviewing other peoples books is a good way to get your book reviewed.

-Youtube. Lots of people are doing book trailers on Youtube. So far, the time, money, and effort
invested in book trailers has not translated into huge sales for most writers.

-It's all about connections and relationships. Doing little favors for people, and they returning
little favors.


**15. PAYMENT:**

Kindle pays 70% royalties on books $2.99 to $9.99. For books .99-$2.99, and over 9.99
the royalty is 35%. Payment is 60 days after the close of the month. Smashwords pays 70% through
Paypal and quarterly (unless it is sold through another outlet through Smashwords). PubIt: Books
below $2.99: 40%; Books from $2.99 - $9.99: 65%; Books over $9.99: 40%

If you're in the US, that minimum in royalties is $10.00 for payment to a bank account, and $100.00
if you want them to cut you a check. If you do require a check, then they charge an $8.00 fee out of
that before they pay you.


**16. COUPON:** 

Smashwords allows you to create coupons for your books. You can give this virtual coupon (a number)
to anyone, and they can use it to buy your book on Smashwords. You can do a promotional "giveaway"
or "contest", posting it on forums and websites.


**17.  OTHER RESOURCES:**

An excellent resource for epublishing is J.A. Konraths, The Newbies Guide to Publishing, only
$2.99.

http://www.amazon.com/Newbies-Publishing-Everything-Writer-ebook/dp/B003I6496Y

Joes blog, http://www.jakonrath.blogspot.com, is also very informative, and very inspiring.

Also, adobe expert Christian Cantrells Blog is helpful:
http://www.livingdigitally.net/2010/09/everything-you-need-to-know-about-how-to-digitally-self-publish.html


**18. NOTE:** 

Don't try to do it all at once. Work an hour or two a day on your book upload. Format it one
day. Spend two days on the cover. One day for your synopsis. One day for uploading it. Once it is
up, spend a half hour a day promoting it. First on Kindleboards, Mobilereads, Nookboards. Isn't that
better than fretting about your &$&## agent, or the piles of rejection letters?

Remember, once it is up, you start making money immediately. You ARE a published writer who is
making money. Now isn't that what you always wanted?


See also [[Writing]]
fields.title: Kindle Publishing

fields.text:
* Virtual Build Machine *                 -*-muse-*-

*Virtual watermill build machine*

**Goals & Benefits**
Create a portable VM to create watermill builds.
Use on Sub to isolate native OS from build OS.
Allow risk-free upgrade of OS on Sub.

**Steps**

Download Virtual Box software from web site
 - select download 10.04 LTS - 64 bit
 - download sub install package -
   [[https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Linux_Downloads][Download 10.04 64]]
   [[http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/server-storage/virtualbox/downloads/virtualbox-4.1_4.1.8-75467~Ubuntu~oneiric_amd64.deb][Download 11.10 64]]
 - install on sub

Download VMs from Virtual Box web site
 - download guest ubuntu image for 11.10 - 32 -  [[http://sourceforge.net/projects/virtualboximage/files/Ubuntu%20Linux/11.10/ubuntu_11.10-x86.7z/download][Download]]
 - move into ~/Archive/Tools

Run VM
 - double-click appliance in Nautilus
 - startup Linux machine
 - login ubuntu,reverse
 - exit VB app, save machine state
 - install guest additions
 - failed to fix keyboard problem (hit a dead-end)

Download Turn Key Core
 - http://www.turnkeylinux.org/core
 - cd ~/Archive/Tools/VirtualBox 
 - unzip unzip turnkey-core-11.3-lucid-x86-ovf.zip
 - double click 'ovf' file

Setup Core on Sub
 - setup user ids at first boot  (MS1959li)
 - accept security updates
 - quit from Advanced setup menu
 - test Turn Key Core VM on Sub

                                    <-------- Done -----------<

Move to Hummer

Test basic usage
 - confirm start/stop Virtual Box
 - confirm startup and shutdown
 - measure performance (cat /proc/cpuinfo)

Create environment in VM
 - create  seaman user
 - clone files
 - install app stack
 - computer cloner
 - move into ~/Archive/Tools/'VirtualBox'

Move UbuntuInWindows VM onto Sub
Setup GIT repos
First build and test
Move VM to other system


See also VirtualBox
fields.title: Virtual Build Machine

fields.text:
* Follow Up *                 -*-muse-*-

Actions needed to develop business relationships
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Initial Ping Linked in** 

Dustin Morris   7-31
Rick Lesser     8-1
Jeff Beemer     7-31
Greg Begay      7-31
Rob Yockey      7-31
Ken Stockton    7-31
Ed Beeman       7-31
Kevin Bier      8-1
Frank Kurucz
Jordan Brewer
Stacey Campbell
John Dutton     8-21
Beth Delaney    8-21
Steve Hines     8-21
Jerry Donovan   8-21


I was just browsing Linked In and ran across your link. I hope things are well for you.  I enjoyed
our time working together.
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Linked In invite**

I am a software architect, engineer, and business owner.  It is always great to connect with local people in the software industry.

- Mark Seaman
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Explore Collaboration**

Great to meet you today!

I'd like to trade info about our backgrounds to explore possible ways that we might collaborate.

I'm a software architect, engineer, and business owner with extensive experience in complex projects.

I specialize in working with legacy code, training and leading development teams to use best practices.

I emphasize the importance of Agile Software practices, such as Scrum, Evolutionary Design, Test-Driven Development, and Continuous Integration.

Key Technologies include: Linux, Python, Django, C++, .Net, Java

I am open to discussing any collaboration opportunities that you may see.
_____________________________________________________________________________


**Rob Yockey, 7-31, Linked in** 

Mark: I was just browsing Linked In and ran across your link. How do you like working at Pelco?

Rob: Mark, Good to hear from you! I see that you have struck out on your own. How do you like that?
I hope that you are making a good go of it.  I have only been here for 8 weeks or so. I am still
coming up to speed, but so far I like it a lot. Nice to be back in a more R&D like environment. Also
still has a nice small feel to it. Plenty of challenges and opportunities to contribute.  cheers Rob

Mark: I left HP in the EER in 2007. I've been doing consulting since then. I really love the
autonomy that it offers. The work is great. Let me know if you would like to explore any ways that
we might collaborate.


**Ken Stockton, 7-31, Linked in** 

I was just looking at Linked In and ran across your link. How do you like working at OtterBox?
**

Ed Beeman, 7-31, Linked in** 

I've been thinking a lot about you lately. Would you like to get together sometime soon?

Ed: Sure. I could meet for breakfast or lunch Thursday or breakfast Fri.

Mark: How about breakfast on Friday? You pick a place.


**Frank Kurucz, 7-31, Linked in** 

I was just looking at Linked In and ran across your link. How do you like working at Oracle?

Mark: 
I have a consulting company that does software architecture, process, and hands-on
development. I have been working for one main client for four years now. I'm winding down that
contract and looking for new work.

Our three kids are all growed up. Christine, 30, lives with us and is working for a small
manufacturing company. Josiah, 27, is married and working on a doctorate in Bio-informatics, at
CU. Rachel, 24, is living in Japan where she works for the Prefecture of Kagoshima.

Stacie and I moved to our dream house on a lake in Windsor three years ago. We are all very happy.

Great to catch up with you.

Frank:
So far it's been good. I work in the old Sun Microsystems division, in the Solaris team, which has a
culture that reminds me of the old pre Carly HP. As you probably know, Mark Hurd is a big wig here,
but he's fundamentally the Chief Salesman, so he doesn't affect us worker bees the way he did at
HP. Larry Ellison does believe in actually growing the company and there has been some hiring. My
boss is very flexible and I work at home 2 days a week, which is nice as the commute from Loveland
is long.

I have heard that other parts of the company (the non Sun groups) are not as pleasant to work in.

Hope all is well with you and your family. Our youngest (Sam) starts college this fall. He'll be
attending UNC in Greeley (his older sister also goes to UNC) as he wants to be a high school
teacher. Where does the time go?


StaceyCampbell


See also Business, [[Networking]], [[People]]

* Health *                 -*-muse-*-

Work on establishing practices for sustainable health

**Weight**
    weigh each morning
    set weight limit to invoke austerity

**Doctors**
    primary physician yearly
    dermatoligist yearly
    dentist semi-annually

**Excersize**
    break for lunch and two 15 minute breaks at 10 & 3
    walk one mile four times weekly
    lift weights Tue, Thu

**Mental health**
    limit total work hours to 50
    allocate time to projects
    celebrate outcomes
    plan variety within the work day
    work on problem areas

fields.text:
* Lord's Prayer *                 -*-muse-*-

I come to you as your son, hold me close.

Your power, honor, and reputation are beyond my imagination.  You are infinite in every aspect.

You rule over everything that we see and can't see, since you created it all.

Let your will be expressed perfectly and your desires fulfilled in every situation.

Please supply everything I need, as you always have.  You are both faithful and generous to me.

Everything I truly need can be found in you. I don't need to look for any other source.

Forgive all of my sins.  I don't deserve it but I receive it.

Help me to forgive others that have harmed me. I release the desire for revenge.

Rescue me when I am tempted. Remind me to seek you in that moment.

Protect me when attacked. You will never abandon me.

You have rights to everything, everywhere, for all eternity.


See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Lord's Prayer

* Setup XBMC *                 -*-muse-*-

# Define the repository
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:team-xbmc

# Install the application
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install xbmc


Yes, you can use xbmc's maverick repository on natty.

sudo gedit /etc/apt/sources.list.d/team-xbmc-ppa-natty.list

Replace "natty" with "maverick".

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install xbmc

I haven't encountered any problems using this setup.

See also [[Brain]]

fields.text:
* Graphics On Sub *                 -*-muse-*-

Fix graphics problem on primary watermill computer.

** Alternatives **

Use Virtual Box on hummer (install guest 12.04-64)
 * Cost: 4 hours (learn Virtual Box)
 * Risk: Learning time + lack of disk space 
 * Benefit: Virtual Box for other jobs (Windows, other Linux)

Use Hummer and sub (with VNC or X)
 * Cost: 1 hour
 * Risk: Must keep two computers running
 * Benefit: No risk of breaking sub

Use Virtual Box on sub (12.04-64)
 * Cost: 4 hours (learn Virtual Box)
 * Risk: Learning time + Graphics issues
 * Benefit: Retires Hummer

Upgrade sub to 12.04 - 64
 * Cost: 4 hours in April
 * Risk: Work around for 3 more months

Use Hummer and b2
 * Cost: 4 hours (user account on fred server)
 * Risk: Tied to Kasey
 * Benefit: Frees up sub as experimental system

Buy another graphics card for sub
 * Cost: 2 hours + $50
 * Risk: Cannot get it to work 30%


See also WmTools, VirtualBox
fields.title: Graphics On Sub

fields.text:

fields.text:
* Presentation Aikido *                 -*-muse-*-


Our philosphy about presentations should change from an adversarial one.

You start by desiring to help your audience.

**Be competent**
Only speak on subjects that you are an expert on.
If you are not an expert become one

**Be passionate**
If you don't really care about it then do not present
If you are bored then the audience has no hope of being interested

**Be prepared**

**Be entertaining**

**Be stylish**

**B engaging**

Be yourself
Authenticity is a key part of your message
In the end you are selling yourself

 See also
fields.title: Presentation Aikido

fields.text:
* Trust Levels *                 -*-muse-*-

Goal        - Quality and quantity of end result
Strategy    - Best plan to get to goal
Assumptions - Untested beliefs
Experiments - Assumption testing
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Level 1 - Introduction**

Goal
    Create basic awareness with 50 people by September

Strategy
    Easy access to free info
    Engage in subjects of mutual interest
    10 minute pitch at Entrepreurs forum
    Make contacts at Open Source Conference
    Contact old HP collegues

Assumptions
    People are interested in testing strategies
 
Experiments
    'Join the fight against Bit Rot' FightBitRot.com
    'Why testing fails' paper and publicity
    Register http://LeanTest.com
    Create simple web site
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Level 2 - Readers**

Goal
    100 regular readers by December 

Strategy
    Create regular communication system and publish weekly

Assumptions
    People will sign up for a blog

Experiments
    Setup and use analytics to measure progress
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Level 3 - Clients**

Goal
    Work for five clients in 2012

Strategy
    Tell success stories to establish expertise

Assumptions
    People have work that requires my strengths 

Experiments
    Define and sell "Entry Jobs"
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Level 4 - Partners**

Goal
    Full time work for two clients

Strategy
    Exceed project expectations

Assumptions
    I can establish ongoing trust 

Experiments
    Investigate subcontracting
_____________________________________________________________________________

See also [[Networking]]
fields.title: Trust Levels

fields.text:
* Jack Hammer *                 -*-muse-*-

Framework for microprojects

Provides:
 * rapid context switch
 * automatic test framework
 * instance code sharing
 * extensible custom commands


**rapid context switch**

A single command sets root directory, command path, and variables
All commands relate to the current project
5 second context

 * project
 * run
 * dirs


**automatic test framework**

Command run all available tests
Creating, running, and viewing test results

 * tst, trun, tfail, tresults
 * tout, tdiff, tlike
 * tnew, tshow, tlist, te


**instant project setup**

Create new archive and directory structure
Clone command for new project

 * commit
 * changes
 * create
 * clone
 * proot, pbin, ptest, pdoc, papp


**extensible custom commands**

Create and modify project related commands
Instant access for all scripts

 * show
 * ew
 * todo
 * exe


**data type factory**

Support any data type by creating canonical operations

 * factory
 * list         l
 * detail       s
 * edit         e
 * new          n
 * delete       d


See also  HammerTutorial
fields.title: Jack Hammer

fields.text:
* Cluster Book *                 -*-muse-*-

*Command cluster for management of Turn Key My Book*

 * book-term    - Login to a terminal on the remote book site
 * book-admin   - Login the Django admin page
 * book-webmin  - Login the web admin page
 * book-control - Show the Turn Key control panel

 * book-deploy  - Update the My Book code on the server
 * book-publish - Update the content on the remote server
 * book-restart - Restart the remote web server

 * book-help    - List possible operations
 * book-content - List all of the files on the server
 * book-show    - Display the contents of the web site
 * book-page    - Get a page using wget

 * book-db-load - Load the database for My Book
 * book-db-save - Save the SQL to a file

See also CommandClusters, ClusterMyBook
fields.title: Cluster Book

fields.text:
* Write File *                 -*-muse-*-
Write a log of page hits to a file
_________________________________ **urls.py**  ______________________________

urlpatterns = patterns('',
    url(r'^(?P< path >[\w]+)$',      'buymore.views.record_view'),
)
_________________________________ **views.py** ______________________________

from django.http        import HttpResponseRedirect
from datetime           import datetime

def log(user,page):
    f=open(path,'a')
    f.write(str(datetime.now())+', '+user+', '+page)
    f.close()

def record_view (request, path):
    log (request.user, path)
    return HttpResponseRedirect('Home')

fields.text:
* Add Record *                 -*-muse-*-
Use a model add record

_________________________________ **models.py** ______________________________

class Note (models.Model):
    title = models.CharField (max_length=200)
    body  = models.TextField ()

def add_note(title,body):
    n = Note()
    n.title = title
    n.body = body
    n.save()
