fields.text:
* 50 Tricks in Django Web Development *                            -*-muse-*-
____________________________________________________________________________

The objective of this book is to discuss the Django web framework and
present enough information to enable you to go from no previous knowledge of Django
to building a web application using Django.  

In addition to getting an overview of Django, I'm going to dive into some detail on the
50 Tricks that are essential to building an application.  Building a web
application, or any other program for that matter, is really a matter of understanding
the specific tricks that you need to do to get your technical work done and then
assembling those tricks based on the needs of your application.  

PresentationGoals

By the end of this book you will know how to create a running web application using the 50 Tricks.  The 50 Tricks are a catalogue of best practices that will provide you with one interesting way to solve a particular problem - rather than present all the possible ways that you might solve that particular problem.  

WhatsDjango

So let's start by talking about Django.  Django is a framework that is very
similar to ASP.net or Rails or JSP and it's based on a language in the same way that
C-sharp is used to write ASP.net applications or Ruby is used to write Rail
applications.  So Python is to Django like Ruby is to Rails.  Building a web
application requires both a great computer language and a framework that solves
a lot of the recurring problems for you.  When you select a programming language, you also need to select a framework. 

WhyDjango

There are many different frameworks written in Python. I selected Django after evaluating a number of other frameworks such as Pyramid, for example.  Django offers a great set of features and it's also interesting that Django was created by factoring real world applications.  A number of different applications were created and then the commonality, the common
elements of those applications, were re-factored into a library that could be used on future applications.  

Some frameworks are created by analyzing a problem in the abstract and then developing a framework, Django was developed by capturing real world applications in specific elements that were reusable within that. This avoids the Ivory Tower design problem and ensures that everything in the library is there for a reason. When you re-factor real applications; you end
up with a minimalistic framework, rather than a conglomeration of everything that someone could think to include - everything is there because it has an immediate use in an actual
situation.  

Another thing that attracted me to Django is the docs are probably better than any other technical documentation I've read.  There are a number of different hosting options available.  I recommend the kind of hosting where you pay about 10 bucks a month and get a shared virtual server that can be set up in about an hour.  The result is, with the investment of about an hour's worth of time and 10 bucks a month, you can host your application. I set up new hosting for each new Django app I develop because the hosting is virtually free, compared to the development time.

The other thing that's really nice about Django is it's really great for automation.
You can expose all of the functionality of your running application, your running
GUI.  You can expose that either as a web service or as a set of scripts that you
can use with command line operations to do the same thing.  I find that this is
really, really useful for doing automated testing and there's a lot of automated testing capabilities built into the framework itself.  

LearnByDoing

I believe in learning by doing.  The fastest way to learn something is to pick a project and pick a technology - dive in and figure out what problems you need to solve along the way rather than trying to learn a lot about the technology before you start working on a project.  This is a similar approach to the refactoring of applications into a framework, creating a INSERTlearning a technology like creating an application is the fastest way to go.  The project we'll use as an example for this book is a wiki.


FiftyTricks

Let's talk about 50 Tricks.  There are two types of knowledge: there is a broad base
of engineering knowledge which involves things like how to define a software project,
how to design the actual writing of the code, the debugging and testing of that code.
That's a general body of knowledge that is very transportable from project to project
and from technology to technology.  

The other type of knowledge that engineers have that is valuable is a specific
technology that translates into a catalogue of how to solve specific
problems.  I'm calling these tricks because, once you know a specific trick, you can
apply that trick in about an hour.  But to learn a new trick, takes about a day's
worth of experimentation and messing around.  And I'm hoping that this presentation
will short-circuit that activity for you so that you can see one successful way to do
each trick and then, when you're working on your pile of project, you can basically
just draw from my catalogue of tricks and then maybe in a couple of hours, have a
working knowledge of how to apply that trick, rather than a whole day.  

This idea of tricks is what explains the difference between people that are very
effective at using a technology and people that are just learning that technology.  If
you switch technologies, you basically flush your bag of tricks and have to restock it
with that new technology.  So if you're a really good Ruby programmer and you are
going to Python for the first time, for example, you will have to restock your tricks,
relearn the -- even though you may know a lot of the Ruby tricks for doing all of
these things that we're going to present, you will have to go back and relearn each of
the tricks for the technology that you're trying to do. 

So if we compare two programmers, one that is very fluent in a technology and one that
is not fluent and the average application requires about 50 tricks, this whole project
can be completed in about 50 hours.  If a person is at the same time they're
developing the application, they are learning the tricks, then that same project will
take that person about 50 days.  And so this accounts for the order of magnitude
difference in program productivity.  It's not how smart the people are, but how
familiar they are with this specific technology and the tricks that are part of that
technology.

TrickGroups

So we're going to be looking at seven groups of tricks in our application development.
The first set of tricks that we're going to be looking at is how to set up a server.
The next set of tricks is about working with data inside your application.  And then
we're going to work with views and we're going to work with formatting, getting the
style that you want.  Then we're going to be working with documents in the file system
and in the database and then we are going to look at user authentication and
authorization.  And then we are going to kind of step back and take a look at some
project-related tricks, as well.  
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Server  (5 Tricks)**

ServerStart

Okay, we're ready to start our first set of tricks.  So what we want to do is we want
to set up a Django server that can serve our project needs.  So the first that we need
to be able to do is we need to be able to run the server application.  So Django ships
with a lightweight server that can be used instead of Apache.  When you go to
production, you're definitely going to want to deploy your application on an
industrial server, like Apache, but for development purposes, you can spin up with one
line of code, you can spin up a server and you can test out all your things and be
able to work with your application.  

So here what I've done is I've shown you how to get that server running.  There is a
managed script and you just use the script inside of that, called Runserver and now
all of a sudden, you have your application listening to whatever port you told it to
listen to and serving your pages.

When you go to production, you're likely to want to deploy that on Apache.  There are
a number of other options that you can use as well, but I deploy most of my Django
applications on Apache.  And so here's an example of restarting the server remotely
from a development machine.  So all you really need to do is you need to SSH into a
particular machine name and then you need to find the restart script in Apache and
just run it.  And so that one line of code will net you a remote server.  

Okay, the next thing that we want to do now that we're running our server is we want
to load a web page and check it out.  And so when we're running our development
server, it normally starts up on port 8000.  So if you just point Firefox to
localhost:8000 that will load your pages.  That's the first trick, starting the
server.  

CreateProject

The second trick that we want to do is we want to create a new project.  So we're
ready to start our thing, we're ready to start writing code.  There's a set of scripts
that are bundled under the Django admin script.  And so if you just type Django admin
start project Mystore then it will create a new project for you called Mystore.  And
what you see here in that directory is a number of different files that Django will
create for you, including the glue logic that runs in the web server that allows you
to answer HTTP requests.  So all that infrastructure is created for you and all you
need to do is modify a few basic settings to add your application logic. 

HelloWorld

And so the next that we do is we see the end of the directory and we run the server
and then we load the web page.  So now you should have a running web application.  

The next that we want to do, our application, it runs, but it doesn't do anything and,
at the very minimum, we want to answer and HTTP request.  And so this is just about
the simplest application that you can write.  So here what we do is there is a URLs
file that is automatically created for us.  And what we are going to do is we are
going to hook in to that URLs file and give it regular expression that matches the
HTTP request that is going to be made.  And then we're going to generate a HTTP
response for that.  So we could do all of this in about three lines of code. 

Interviewer:	So is each one of these slides one trick?  So the one earlier where you
had three different blue headers or is that just one trick between the three of them?

Respondent:	That's one trick, starting the server and then creating a project, one trick.
One trick saying hello world.  


Okay, so this code snippet here, if you were to just cut and paste this in or type it
into your editor then you test it out, fire it up and within five minutes after you've
started the project, you can at least answer HTTP [inaudible 16:12].  And all you've
written here now is really -- you've executed a couple of shell scripts, but you've
only written about four or five lines of Python maybe in total. 

CreateApp

In reality, you don't actually create applications by just hard coding the URLs with
the patterns to find.  What you really do is you really create a cluster of
functionality that Django calls an application.  I don't like this particular name
because it feels more like a module to me than an application, but nevertheless that's
the vocabulary that Django uses.

And so what you're really going to want to do is you're going to want to create what
Django calls an app and you're going to give it a name.  So in our example here, we're
going to create an app called Buymore.  And so what we do is we use that managed
script again, which really just sets the context for executing Python stuff.  So we do
start app Buymore and it creates a whole directory structure for us.  It creates model
code, it creates views and it creates kind of a skeleton that we can work with and we
can add our application logic.  

HomeView

The other thing that you need to do is, you need to hook that application in using
your settings file that it created for you.  You need to reference your Buymore
application as an installed application.  And that will mean that Django will go and
look for your model code and your view code and your URLs and all that stuff.  It
knows that that's an integral part of your application that you're building.  So one
line of code will basically hook up your application into the settings.  

So now what we've done is we've created a new app called Buymore inside of our Django
application.  Now the next trick that we're going to do is we're actually going to
write a view code that will respond to our HTTP request.  And here what we are doing
is we're going to handle the URL that is blank so you just hit -- if you just type in
the top level website domain then this is the URL that you're going to get and you're
going to get the homepage.  And so in this case, we've created an application that has
exactly one page that it can respond to.  And we've hard coded an HTTP response that
just replies Mystore contents for that request.  

Interviewer:	So URLs maps things to function [codes]?

Respondent:	Yes, it's a regular expression that it parses the regular expression if it --
it's a stack of regular expressions typically.  And, as soon as it finds the first one
that matches then it binds to your Python code that is located in the Buymore application
in the views file and then inside of views is a function defined as homepage.  And then we
just have a hard coded response.

Interviewer:	So if you wanted to have a custom 404 not found page, would you just put
[inaudible 19:59] pattern at the very bottom of your stack?

Respondent:	Yes.

Interviewer:	So everything else doesn't match you can send it to the...

Respondent:	And so you can do really fancy handling of 404s and all that kind of stuff.
And then in these responses, you can also redirect.  So when you're -- instead of just
hard coding a HTTP response, you might want to redirect to some other page if you
determine that a certain situation is needed. 

So now we've been able to create a server, create a project, create an application and
then create handlers within that application.  Now what we're going to do is we're
going to figure out how to work with data.  So we haven't worked with any data at all.
We had just hard coded everything.  
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Data (9 Tricks)**
DataBase
DataBasePostGres
NewDataModel
CreateDatabase
AddRecord
SaveRecord
QueryRecords
ShowResults
DeleteRecord

The first thing that you will want to do in your application is you're going to want
to hook to a database.  And in addition to Django shipping with a lightweight server,
they also allow you to hook up to a lightweight database.  And so when you're just
messing around when you're creating your application, you can create a database in a
single file and then when you're all done then you can basically deploy that and
reroute that to a more industrial database.  

So in this case, what we're going to do is we're going to just hook the sequel
[inaudible 21:34].  And the only that we need to do with [inaudible 21:38] because it
doesn't use any user authentication or anything like that, it's just a vocal file on
your file system.  The only thing that we need to do is just name the file.  And so
we're going to call this thing Hammer DB.

Now later on, you decide that you really need to use postscripts for example, or
Mysequel or any other kind of database that you fancy.  And so here what we do is we
have to name the database and then we have to have database access credentials.  And
so all we do is just change the name of the connection string that we're going to use
to mount that database.  

And typically on web host environments, the database is not located on the same server
or often times it's not located on the same server that your web application runs on.
And so, no problem; just put the access credentials for the other server.  So we
changed three lines of code and all of a sudden we were able to go from a single file
database to an industrial database.  

Okay, the next thing that we want to do is we want to define our own data types.  And
then we want to take these data types and put them in the database as table types.
And so here what we are going to do is we're going to define a class called Note and
it's going to have two fields.  It's going to have a title and a body and one is going
to be a fixed [length string] that can go up to a maximum size of 200 and the body is
just going to be some indeterminate length of text.  And that's all we have to do.
Three lines of code and now we have a model that we can use.  You put this model into
the model's file in your app so in like the Buymore app, if we put the note in there
then it's good to go.  

Interviewer:	Does it matter what app your data type is declared under since there's
multiple models that.

Respondent:	It creates tables that contain both the app name and the model name within
that and so if you have customers as an app and, if you have orders as a model within that
then the table that is created is called customers underscore order.  

Now we're ready to take that model code and generate a database for us.  So you don't
actually have to write sequel to create the database formats.  All you really have to
do is to find the Python code that accesses the data type and then it controls the
database for you.  So it will actually generate the database.  And the way you do that
is to do manage by [sync DB] and then that will create all of the missing data tables
for you.  

This is really awesome because, if you're creating data types all the time, they just
keep syncing the database and it creates a bunch of stuff for you.  Once you put data
in the table, it will not modify the database.  You'll have to do that manually.  And
there are some tools to help you with that, but the common case is that you're just
going to create a bunch of data.  I typically recreate the database many, many times
throughout projects and I will tend to throw it away.

Interviewer:	Our experience was that we had to create some migration scripts [in order
to diminish that pie] for when we change the data type of fields instead of the database.

Respondent:	Correct.  There's a couple of other great tools that will allow you to
side-step sequel.  You can dump all of the data in your database as JSON and then you can
load it back in and so this is a great thing to do if you just want to mess with the data
or you just want to write transforms that mess with the data and then put it all back in.  

It's also a great tool that you can use to actually do queries in a form that maybe
you want to send out to a front-end client app and you just want to have a job script
on the front-end that manipulates your data.  What you might want to do is just dump a
big [hairy] piece of data right out of your database and then just [hype it] to the
customer or to the front-end app that can manipulate.  

The next thing we want to do is we want to add a record of a particular type.  So this
is our old friend, the [Note].  It has a title and a body and to add a record, all you
need to do is create a blank object just by calling the initializer for a note, set
the fields that you want and then save it.  The save is really smart about how to get
the data in the right place and whether you have an exception to the data if you're
missing a field or something like that.  And then there are also some additional
validation things.  Save will throw an exception and you might want to handle that
exception if you're not sure if it's valid or not.  But really nice, one line of code
basically just smashes your data in the database.

Interviewer:	We were using Get or Create, but this is a lot simpler.

Respondent:	The next thing you want to do is you may want to modify an object.  So again,
here's our friend the Note.  We just get a note and we reset its body and save it.  So
that allows you to modify things that already exist in the database or selectively modify
fields allows you to -- so really to get here is doing a select and then the save is doing
an update underneath.  But you don't need to worry about that.  You don't need to worry
about whether you have one or don't have one or whatever.  This simple pattern here is
great for saving your data. 

Interviewer:	So will that give you a new blank object with title equals title?

Respondent:	No, it will throw an exception and so there is a version of the [getter] that
will

Okay, so the next thing that we want to do is we want to go out and list how many
objects match a particular thing.  So the first thing we want to do is just enumerate
all of the objects in the system of particular types.  So we ask for notes -- we ask
for note, objects all and this returns a list of all of the matching notes.  

The next thing we might want to do is we might want to match a particular title when
we're looking for something in the database and so, again, this generates a select
statement where the title matches the word lost worlds.  And the last case that we
might want to do is something more complicated where we're looking for a string in the
title that is greater than some value or it could be a numeric thing.  

And Django gives us a really nice list of modifiers that can be used for matching
certain kinds of criteria.  So there's greater than, less than, not equal and you can
do things like count how many there are and, if the count is bigger than a number, you
can do all kinds of things.  So anyway, the sky is the limit.  There's about 34
different types of modifiers that you can use.  And you can do date ranges and all
kinds of things.  There's no reason to write sequel.  If you're a sequel-hater like me
then Django gives you all the tools that will let you sidestep that.  

The next thing that you might want to do is you might want to [iterate] through --
you've got this query, you get back a bunch of things and now what you want to do is
you want to walk the list and print out all the title of the books or all the titles
of the notes or whatever it is that your database is holding.  

And so here's an example of printing out all the notes and it just prints a model, one
line each as a title and text and it just gives you a nice table of notes.  And so you
could imagine wrapping these kinds of things in text tools to do [inaudible 31:57] and
basically manage all of your stuff with automated [inaudible].  This kind of stuff is
just extremely handy for that.  

A more interesting example is you might want to query the database and give back a
table of notes and then apply formatting to that because you might want to have your
web page, for example, create a table for you.  And what you need is you need a
two-dimensional list of items that then you want to populate in a table.  What this
allows you to do is a set of generic views, like a table pager that knows nothing
about the data that it's holding, but it controls all of the formatting stuff.  

And then underneath you have a query function that can generate a table out of the
contents that you want to look up, but you don't have any idea how you want to format
this.  So this is what we call in the software industry, separation of concerns.  So
the formatting of the table is completely independent of the populating of the data in
the table.  So here's an example of getting a table out of a database.  One line a
code, really nice

The next thing you might want to do to close out our set of [inaudible 33:38]
operations is you might want to delete a record.  And so here I've given three
examples deleting everything in the database or deleting things that match a specific
criteria or a more complicated set of matches and these are essentially the matches
that we had before.  So once you've learned these set of operations of how to query
and how to select certain things then everything that you expect scales out and you
can apply any operations.  And here all we're doing is just calling the delete
[member] function on the 

Interviewer:	So will this delete underscore note just delete the first entry [inaudible
34:24].

Respondent:	[inaudible].  Yes, get only returns one.  Filter returns many.  And that's why
we have to iterate the filter list.  This one will actually blow up or throw an exception
if there is no matching -- the get operation will throw an exception if there is no
matching object.

Interviewer:	But if there's more than one note with lost worlds as the title it will it
only delete the first one? 

Respondent:	Get will have problems with that and so you would use a variant of filter if
you thought that there were multiple ones.
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Views (7 Tricks)**
HomeView
ListViewUrl
ListView
DetailsView
FormModel
AddRecordView
EditView
DeleteView

So now we have the ability to create an application.  We have the ability to
manipulate data within that application.  The next set of tricks that we're going to
explore is how to build views in our system because after all, we want to build a
web-based system and one of the key parts of that is building our views.  

Now these views can be HTML-generated or they could be maybe XML or JSON in the formal
web service thing.  I build a lot of web services where you basically can query URLs
and then have the rendering not be intended for human view, but is just a blob of JSON
data that you might want to put on your cell phone or do something like that.  So this
works both for front-end services as well as back-end services.  

So the next that we're going to do is we're going to revisit our friend the home view
and here what we're doing is we're matching the regular expression that is the
[inaudible 36:26] string, the beginning and end of line together.  The URL parser has
this regular expression language.  It's kind of some nasty syntax, but once you spend
maybe an hour trying to figure out how it works, it's not that hard, but when you're
reading it for the first time, it's kind of offensive, but you'll get used to it.  

So here we have our old friend the view that we just hard coded to return my store
contents.  The next thing that we're going to want to do is we're going to want to
have a list of items that we are going to want to display.  And so here we're parsing
out in addition to the home page, we're parsing out the list URL and mapping that to
the Python function list page.  

Here's the implementation of the list page thing.  And this is very typical of the
kind of thing that you will see is that the function it calls some Python function,
which generates a list of items and then it puts that in a variable called products
and then it loads a template and the template is a bunch of HTML code that's augmented
with some Pythony-stuff, so that I can manipulate the data inside my Python views.  

So our template here is going to iterate over each of the things in the products list.
It's going to call each one P and then it is going to print the label of P both as the
HREF of the anchor as well as the text that gets displayed to a user.  So what you end
up with after this runs is a bullet list of all of the products that are linked to the
individual pages for those products.  

Okay, the next thing that we want to do is we want to create a details view.  So we
have a list of hyperlinks that link to each of the pages for each of our products and
now what we want to do is we want to pick of each of the individual products.  And so
here we see a more complex syntax for parsing off the argument that's the product ID
that we want to display. 

And so that will be passed into the view, which is called item.  So we have a function
called item and it takes a request and an ID.  And that ID is the variable that got
parsed off in the URL pattern.  So presumably it's -- and, in fact, it says that it's
a series of digits.  So you're going to say URL with a domain name slash 33 and that's
going to map to an item call in the views [code].  

Then the template that is being used to display this details view is called details
dot HTML.  And so, in this case, we are passing the ID of the product, which is a --
I'm rewording this.  Just a minute. 

Here what we do is we look up the specific product object out of the database and then
we pass that object into the template and then, inside the template, we crack it open
and we print its primary key, its title, its description or when there were other
fields it has.  And so this is typical of Django views that there's typically a very
small amount of code that deals with the object types that are being used.  But you
can imbed some Python code in the template itself to handle special cases. 

Okay, the next thing that we want to do, and I have to say that this is probably the
most complicated thing that I'm going to show.  And this is form editing.  And so here
what we're going to do is we're going to pass back data to our view from user input
and there's several parts to this.  The first part is that we define a form that knows
what edit fields and things like that, that knows what UI to put on our template so
that we don't have to write the code that enumerates all of the contents of the class
that we want to edit. 

So instead what we do is we define a note form and that note form references the
actual object type and so it knows that it needs to create a text field for that first
-- or it needs to create an input field for that first path field in the object type.
And then for the body, it needs to create a text area to match the data type.  And so
what happens is a form comes up on the user interface just that is consistent with the
-- that is consistent with the object type and we didn't have to define any of the UI
elements for our specific data type.  All we had to do was create a form that
references the underlying data type. 

Okay, in the template part of this, we use this called Form S Table and that is the
thing that figures out what UI elements need to be present to edit that particular
kind of a thing.  And the other nasty piece is this cross-site reference and it is --
I'm going to ignore that for now, but you have to have this to prevent somebody from
invoking your form from another website.  This verifies that the creator of this form
is a legitimate service.

Okay, so we've created the surface area of our form.  Now what we're going to do is
we're going to populate this form with data and then we're going to accept that data
back after the user has typed in the title and body of their note.  And so here what
you see is a typical construct where we're using a post-back and there are three cases
that we need to handle in our forms.

The first case is that we have a blank form that we want to present to the user.  And
so we're adding an element, we're adding a data type to our database and so we put up
a blank form.  The second case is that we have a post-back and the data is good.  And
then the third case is that we have a post-back and the data is not good.  It will not
validate and so we can't put it into the database.  And if you analyze this piece of
code here, it handles all three of those cases.  In the case where we have valid data
then we redirect to the home page and so you could put any redirects in there.  

Okay, now this is the super complicated case because now we have data that we're going
to put in the form with, by looking up an object in the database.  So they're trying
to edit note number 33 and so we actually can look up note number 33, put the data
into the note then give it back to the user.

Interviewer:	As an editable form. 

Respondent:	As an editable form.  Then when they edit that, then we have the other two
cases for the post-back that we either have valid or invalid data.  And so this particular
form handles all of those paths.  

Okay, glad we're through that.  Now for more easy stuff.  We're going to delete based
on accessing a URL.  So here what we need to do is we need to figure out exactly what
item we're trying to delete from the database and then just map that to a delete view.
Inside the delete view, what we do is we look up the particular object in the database
and then we just call its delete function if we found it.  If we didn't find it, we
probably don't want to blow up the program. 

And then, in either case, we're going to redirect to the home view because we just
deleted something out of the table.  This could be -- this is typically a list of
items and you're going to delete them out of a table of a list and so that's usually
what the code looks like.  And then this, in our list view, I've given a snippet of an
anchor that will get you that URL.  And so this is an example of how you might put
that into your table. 
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Formatting (4 Tricks)**
PageLayout
PageTemplate
StandardNavigation
JsSupport

Okay, now we're through views.  So we've created our application, we've manipulated
data, we've built a set of views.  And so those are all operations that you need to be
able to work with data in a typical website.  Now what we're going to do is we're
going to style our website.  

One really nice thing that Django provides is the ability to declare a template that
can be used by other templates to set your page styling so you can control the styling
of your entire website from modifying your single base template.  So in this case,
I've created a template called layout, not HTML and there's a couple of things that
you would typically want to do.  One is I like to use Twitter Bootstrap in all my
projects and this gives the site an instant styling without putting any effort into
it.  And so here, what I've done is I've just imbedded the libraries, the library
references to Twitter Bootstrap right here on my base page and then all the other
pages get it for free.  

The other thing that you typically do is you have some area of content that you want
each page to override.  And so Django gives you the ability to define blocks and then
a default handling of those blocks.  So if in the inside of this block here, this
block content, I provided a bunch of HTML and then the page that extends this layout,
if it doesn't redefine that HTML, if it doesn't provide its own version of that block
then you get the default.  So that's kind of nice for having some default behavior
like no content goes here or something like that.  It's a handy way to do that.  

Okay and then this is a trick where we're going to extend that template and utilize
that in the context of our project.  And so here what we've done is we've defined a
block content, which has a title on each one and then it has an unordered list of
items for a number of different directories or a number of different files.  So this
is basically -- this construct appears in every program that I've ever written because
somewhere in there, you're going to deal with a list of stuff and so this is basically
how you walk the list and paint all the references. 

And you can see that each one of those individual references then is an anchor with an
HREF and text that match the content of the directory listing.  And so basically,
you're just passing on a list of items and then they get painted by a few lines of
code like that.  So that kind of construct you'll see in almost every application your
write. 

Okay, another nice thing that this allows us to do is to define our site level
navigation.  And so here what I've done is I've used the Twitter Bootstrap nav bar for
creating a set of links that I want to have specific kinds of information.  And so
this kind of a construct would appear in your layout HTML and then every page would
automatically get that without redefining that construct.  So this gives you one place
to define things.  It makes your code really clean. 

Another thing that you might want to do is you might want to provide some front-end
job script manipulation.  So in this case what I've done is just referenced a [J]
query library and then I don't really have to do anything else and now all of a sudden
I can manipulate front-end objects in all my pages if this were in the base page. 

Okay, now we've got styling in our application.  The next thing that we need to work
on is getting documents.  

Interviewer:	We're doing this as [inaudible 53:01] can be really nice if you show what
the applets look like so far. 
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Document (6 Tricks)**
BrowseDirectory
ReadFile
WriteFile
ExecuteScript
TextToHtml
SearchText

Respondent:	Okay now we're going to work on a set of tricks dealing with manipulating
documents.  The first thing that I always do when I learn a new programming language is I
always figure out how to be able to walk the file system because I often need to
manipulate either directories or files in the file system.  And so this is one of the
first things that I always need to do.  

And so here we see an example of a directory listing where we give the directory name
on the URL.  We map that to a function in the views code called list view and then,
inside list view, we take in that path name that came in through the URL and we go out
and enumerate the contents of that particular directory, stick it in a Python variable
called files, hand it off to our template, who knows how to paint a list of files.  So
in roughly less than 10 lines of code, we have now created a file listing interface to
our application.  

Okay, the next thing that we're going to want to do is we're going to want to open one
of those files and reading all the text.  And so here's an example of how you would
want to do that.  We take in the URL that names the file, we map that URL to a
function called read view in the views [class].  Then inside of read view, we open the
contents of that path and then we read all of the characters out of that and we stick
it in a variable called text.  And then we have a template that we just hand text to
and it paints all that.  So here we have roughly six lines of code and we have the
ability to display a file in HTML, assuming the file is HTML. 

Writing is just about the same and here what we've done is we have created a log
function so that every time I hit a page, I want to record the fact that I hit that
page.  And so I've created a function called log that I can imbed in all of my
different views that will keep a history of page hits in a text file on my machine.
And the way it does that is it appends to a file and it formats the date of the hit
and then which user was logged in and then the name of the page that they were
hitting.  So that's all imbedded in this log function.  

And then I could use that log function in any view that -- just to create a passive
logger so that I can get a history of all of the activity on my website.  So you don't
necessarily need to imbed a heavyweight logging tool, you can just build your own
logging in roughly four or five lines of code. 

Interviewer:	So how does this get then passed on to the page that you're requesting
because I though URLs only looked for the first match on the regular expression. 

Respondent:	This URL is going to map to the record view thing and then record view is just
going to return home.  In fact, its on -- this is basically going to double hop your
thing.  Its not actually going to do anything useful.  It's just going to redirect to some
other page.  But what I was really trying to illustrate is not the handler for that, but
how easy it is to imbed logging in other views.  Presumably you have some more interesting
logic that you want, but in just a few lines of code, you could write a custom logger. 

Interviewer:	Okay.  You're not demonstrating how to double intercept.  

Respondent:	Correct.  Okay, the next thing that we might want to do is we might want to
execute shell commands.  In this example, what I've done is I've allowed certain scripts
to be run and I look up those scripts and I execute them because they are shell scripts.  

And so here what I'm doing is I'm taking in URLs where the command is a part of the
URL name and then I'm executing the file using this [P] open and giving it -- I'm
supplying the command name and then I'm taking all of its output and passing it back
to the [caller].  And so here what I'm doing is I'm actually invoking some command and
then I'm going to create a page that shows both the command and the result of
executing that command.  Again, very few lines of code and its the magic of Python
that's really giving us this huge leverage factor.  

Another thing that I typically do in virtually all the programs that I write is I want
to do some formatting and I have some fairly sophisticated tools that deal with things
like wiki formatting and extracting hyperlinks and maybe I want to write some tools
that actually do some remote lookups and maybe do some command execution or whatever. 

So typically what I have is I have all my pages go through a command that can be
arbitrarily sophisticated and has nothing to do with the web infrastructure.  So I ran
my websites so that they deal with web pages and URLs in all of the infrastructure
about dealing with the web, I concentrate in one, but all my business logic, I have
isolated in worker functions that may have a different lifecycle than the rest of the
application.  

And so here's an example of that type of a thing.  The way that I paint a document on
the screen is I call this function format document that may do a bunch of arbitrary
things and one of the things that it may do is invoke an external program that does a
bunch of stuff that my web system knows nothing about.  What it does know is that, by
the time this wiki HTML format command is done, its going to produce a block of output
and then I'm going to pass that block of output onto the web page for display.  

But this allows you to build a system that is very, very decoupled and so that you can
change your business rules and it has zero impact on your web base infrastructure,
very important for the long life of the system. 

Another thing that's really handy to do is you might want to search all the objects in
your database for a particular piece of text.  And so here's just a simple example of
getting all the filters -- getting all of the objects by filtering them, based on
whether the name contains the word, Bill.  And so this one thing will give you all the
Bills in the system and then that's being passed on to the template as a variable
called people.  

**Users (7 Tricks)**
AdminImage
AdminInterface
UserLogin
EnforcingSecurity
DetailsImage
EditUser
ListUsers

Okay, now we have built an application, we've been able to work with data, we've been
able to work with views, construct views, we've been able to style those views and now
we've been able to manipulate the underlying file system and work with documents. 

Now we're ready to work with user authentication.  There's really two parts that we
want to do.  The first is that we want to authorize a particular user.  We want to --
there's two parts to working with users.  The first part is to authenticate that a
particular -- that we know who a particular user is.  The second part is to allow them
a certain level of privilege and that's called authorization.

Django provides both of these facilities with great ease.  In about two lines of code,
you can enable a whole user auth system that has amazingly good capabilities; very
nice, secure, robust, easy to implement and turn on.  And I highly recommend not
building your own user authentication system, but just enabling the one that is
provided to you.  

At its base level, it gives you a number of objects that you have a nice user
interface too so you can manage the users in your system.  And this is how you turn on
the user auth system.  The first thing that you need to do is include the access to
the import libraries and then the next thing that you need to do is tell Django that
you're using the built-in authentication system and then the last thing that you need
to do is you need to map all the URLs that start with admin to be handled by the
built-in library.  That's all you need to do.  So all you're really telling it is
every time somebody types in a URL that starts with admin, it must be for you and then
you get all this user interface for free.  

Here's an example of adding login and logout to your application.  So here what we're
doing is we're picking off the login and logout URLs and then we just map them to the
default handling of those same functions.  So we don't actually have to provide any
user interface or anything and all of the business rules about what happened with a
failed login and resetting my password and I forgot my password and email me so that I
can get a reset link, all of that stuff is done for you.  You don't have to do any
work to do that. 

Okay, this is an example of the authorization piece.  Here what we're doing is we're
going to require that, if you hit the home page that you have to be logged in in order
to see the home page.  And what that decorator does, the login required decorator is
that, if you are not authenticated when you hit the home page, you'll be mapped
automatically.  You'll be redirected to the login screen.  Again, one line of code and
now all of a sudden, we have checking. 

And so you can have certain views that can be universally accessed, but you add the
login required decorator anyplace in your system where you decide that you want to
control permissions.  And there are a number of other decorators' variations on this
that allow you to -- only allow super users to have access to this or only require a
specific user or user group privileges to be able to do certain things. 

One of the things that I love about Django is that easy things are easy and hard
things are possible and that's the right combination.  Easy things should be trivial.  

Okay now what we're going to do here is we are going to be able to look at not only
all of the built-in types that Django has that they have offered for us that they
automatically put in our database, but we are wanting to get nice customized views of
our specific data types.  So for example, the note thing that we created, once we've
created that data type, now we can edit that data type, automatically writing zero
additional code. 

Some of the data types for the built-in things are really sophisticated.  For example,
you can see in this edit box for the user that they have [salting] of the passwords
and they have the forgot my password thing and there's a whole bunch of business
logic.  There's probably thousands of lines of code implementing business logic that
you have no business re-implementing yourself when a team of experts did that for you.  

And then another nice thing is that any tables can be shown as a list and so that you
can drill down in and you can look at all of the fields across all of your different
data types, which is built-in user interface stuff, again, writing no code at all.
All you did was hook up the admin interface. 

Okay, so now we've got user authentication in our system and we've written about five
lines of code total to get all of these rough indication stuff looked up.  It also
saved us many, many hours, maybe a month's worth of hard work. 
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Project (5 Tricks)**
TricksInventory
EstimateCost
TestDrivenDevelopment
HostYourApp
DeployApp

Okay now the last set of tricks that we're going to look at is some global project
management tricks.  And this kind of takes advantage of the capabilities of Django,
but is not necessarily specific to Django.  

The first trick that I recommend is that you analyze your next project and you
actually do an inventory of all of the tricks that you're going to need.  Then you're
going to -- and many times when people first start analyzing a project, they end up
with big tasks that need to be done.  I would say break those tasks down until you can
get down to the level of identifying specific tricks.  And so you want to keep
decomposing until you feel like I can do this in an hour if I knew the trick.  

Then do an inventory of how many times you've used that trick already.  If you've
applied a specific trick five or six times, it will probably only take you an hour.
But if you've never done that trick before then you have to factor in both the
learning, as well as the doing.

Interviewer:	Its probably a day.


Respondent:	It will probably take you a day the first time and every time you do a trick,
you can cut that time in half, down to about an hour.  So then you can estimate the
cost just by rolling those things out.  You can take how many tricks that you've got,
figure out how many tricks you already know.  You can apply a trick in an hour, learn
the trick in a day.  So that gives you a really accurate estimate.  

So this is a typical project that I work on is that it has 50 tricks.  I know 40 of
them.  So it's going to take me about 40 hours to apply the tricks I already know.
But there's 10 tricks that I don't know yet.  Those 10 tricks are going to take me
twice the amount of time as the 40 tricks that I already know and that's typical of a
project.  So what this says is that two-thirds of my time spent on this project is
going to be learning what I don't know already.  

The next thing that I highly recommend is use test-driven development.  Accelerate
your project by creating a process of rapid iteration.  And when I mean rapid, I think
you should be able to add a new feature every five minutes.  And so what you want to
find is how to create on line of code to add a new feature and to create one line of
code to add a new test and then what you want to do is you want to write your test
before you write your code.  

This is not hard because you're only writing one line of test code and then you're writing
one line of product code and you should be able to turn that wheel in about five minutes.
Test hourly,daily and weekly at different levels of depth and then deploy all of your code
only when the testpassed.  There's no point in deploying bad code.  And, if you haven't
tested it, it is bad code.

So the next thing is host your web application.  The first time that you have to host
an application, it will probably take about a day.  And after that, you can probably
deploy your app in an hour.  While I like a web host called WebFaction, they have very
cheap sites and you can set them up and get going very quickly.  They have control
panel, operations that allow you to set up the URLs and map them and they create a
static server for you to serve up your images and JavaScript libraries and thingslike
that.  And so it's a largely point-and-click and then they allow you to bind yourweb
application to specific domains.  One of the tricks that I like is I have many
different domains serve off the same web application.  So I have one app thatserves
probably 20 different domains.

The next thing that you want to do is you want to deploy your application.  So I
really like a tool called Get that allows me to create a new repository by calling
[Getanet] to check-in everything that's been modified, added or deleted, with one
command, where you get commit.  And then I can push my application to share with the
repository or any other people that are using that repository with a single command
code get push and then I can do that remotely.  I can redeploy my application by just
doing SSA [inaudible 01:15:36] get pull. 
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Follow Up**
SourceCode
HelpMe
DjangoDocs
RelatedTopics

All of the source code that I've showed is on my GitHub repository and the slide
presentation is located on my website.  And I'd be happy to talk with you about this
subject matter at mark.seaman@shrinking-world.com.  I invite you to help me build
something great because what we want to do is -- all of the code that I've showed you
here is all open source.  And so I want you to help me make this open source project
really great.  

In specific terms, what I'd really like is for people to help me with new languages
and frameworks.  I'd like to have this application available in a JavaScript version,
in a Django version, maybe in a Pyramid version and I would like to take the same set
of tricks and technologies and show them in multiple technologies.  I'd also like to
add new features to this framework and build some user guides and some great developer
documentation tools as well.  

The other references that I would give you is the Django project documentation and
Django book are really good and then there's also a great book written by Harry
Percival that covers test-driven development with Python and then there's some
additional follow-up topics.

Thank you.  Have a nice day.

* Save Record *                 -*-muse-*-
Lookup a record and modify its contents


class Note (models.Model):
    title = models.CharField (max_length=200)
    body  = models.TextField ()


def modify_note(title,body):
    n = Note.objects.get(title=title)
    n.body = body
    n.save()

fields.text:
* Stay In Love *                 -*-muse-*-

*Notes from Fall In Love, Stay In Love*

Marriages are saved by learning how to stay in love

A love bank tracks deposits and withdrawals

Deposits are when you associate someone with good feelings

A feeling of love exists when the account is above the romantic-love threshold

You will feel love for anyone who has a balance above that threshold

You can choose to make deposits and stop withdrawals to restore the account

Instincts and habits are behavioral patterns we are born with or learn

Both are effortless

We can learn habits that make regular automatic deposits

Bad habits and instincts can make automatic withdraws (these must be stopped)

The most important emotional needs are essential to staying in love

Emotional needs are unique to each person; learn yours and your spouses

Lost love can be restore by changing habits to meet the other's needs

Meeting needs must be enjoyable to both people

You must meet needs that may seem unimportant to you

You cannot meet the needs unless you spend time together each week
  
A minimum time of 15 hours is required each week

Undivided attention is required for everything important in marriage

Lack of private time prevents honest sharing of feelings

Every other demand competes for private time; make it your top priority

Become your spouse's greatest source of happiness by meeting emotional needs

Pay attention to protect the account from withdrawals

Love busters: demanding, disrespectful, angry, annoying, independent, dishonest

Do whatever it takes to prevent love busters

Honesty is crucial to making each other happy

Reveal to your spose as much information as you know about yourself: 
thoughts, feelings, habits, likes, dislikes, personal history, daily activities, and plans for the furture

Honesty prevents secret destructive habits

Each person has two sides: Giver and Taker

Giver - Make you happy and prevent your unhappiness at all costs

Taker - Make me happy and prevent my unhappiness at all costs

Most relationships balance these, but marriage seems to alternate between them


See also MarriageImprovements
fields.title: Stay In Love

fields.text:
* Psalm23 *                 -*-muse-*-

I care for you like a shepherd cares for his sheep.  I will give you everything that you ever need.
I give you rest when you need it.  You can find refuge in my presence.  I will take you to pleasant
places of comfort and peace to allow your strength to be renewed.

Where you go is a reflection of my reputation and work within you.  Choose wisely.  How you live
influences others.  Seek the high road.  This brings me honor and is an act of worship.

When life takes a bad turn I will be there to bring comfort and strength.  I will walk you through
every frightening experience.  You will never have to be alone.

My authority and protection will cover you in every situation.  You will overcome every enemy that
you face.  You will bask in victory for my power will be upon you.

You will live a rich life, filled with all of my blessings.  My goodness and love will envelop you
throughout your life. My presence will be a constant companion.

See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Psalm23

* Software Development Learning *                 -*-muse-*-

**Web Development Platforms and Tools**
Django
ASP.Net
PHP
JSP
Rails

Selection Criteria:
    Popularity - Mainstream development tool in top 3
    Developer productivity
    Scalability - to 1000 concurrent users
    Reliability - proven track record
    Familiarity - close to what I already know
    Open source - no licensing fees
    Mature - in at least the third generation
    Support - lots of books and materials available
    Futuristic - growing in popularity

**Programming Languages**
Go, Io, Closure


**BOB MARTIN**
Why are we still talking about Xtreme programming after 10 years?
Scrum has caught on because it is palatable to business people
Scrum allows you to go faster, this can create a mess without the technical discipline
Technical debt is increased faster
Agile shows the gap with flawed tech practices
There is a renewed interest in Craftsmanship
Craftsmanship requires constant practice
Boy Scout Rule - make things better, do no harm
Programming practices are adopted by people who want to be Craftsmen

**AZURE WEB SERVICES**
Cloud computing - making services available by leveraging services from a leased data center
Requests per second per machine 300-500 requests is typical (could be as low as 100)
Main players (Amazon, Google App Engine, Microsoft Azure)
Azure - OS in the cloud, provisioned on-demand, load-balanced

**RESTful services**
REST is simple and initially harder (but best in the long-term)
SOAP is easy and complex (but can be harder in the long-term)
You get advantages from using each of the constraints of REST

Choose simple (but hard) over complex (but easy)    

Example:
/doctors - Collection of doctors - GET, POST (create a new doc)
/doctors/{id} - One doctor - GET, PUT, DELETE
/doctors/{id}/reviews - Doctor's reveiws - GET, POST
/reviews
/reviews?search={searchTerm}
/reviews/{id} 
/reviewers
/reviewers/{id}

**EMERGENT DESIGN**
Design is a way to reduce risk
Design is an intellectual and a practical pursuit
When do we design?  When do we test the design?
What is the natural flow of development?
Design allows us to change software to take advantage of what we now know.
Agile methods create change, so we must address the risk and waste of change.
Open-Closed principle (open for extension, closed for modification)
http://netobectives.com/PatternRepository
http://netobjectives.com/resources

**SECURE LOGIN FOR AJAX**
http://www.holub.com/publications/notes_and_slides

fields.text:
* Is Jesus First? *                                           -*-muse-*-

My sense of well-being, happiness, security, and peace are more related to my relationship with
God than any circumstance.

Jesus is the rightful center of my attention.  How is he involved in the following key areas?

 * **Spiritual** - Personal growth & health
 * **Learn**  - Building knowledge and expertise
 * **Plan**   - What I do with my time, dealing with expectations
 * **Build** - Problem solving and creating solutions
 * **Teach**  - Influencing others

These are the areas where my core values touch God plans for my life.  Pray through each of these
areas regularly.


**Spiritual**
You transform my life (from start to finish)
Spiritual formation takes an investment (of time and focus)
You are the only source of true emotional and physical health

**Learn**
You gave me the capacity to think; you want me to learn
You gave me interests to guide my path to knowledge

**Plan**
You have a plan for my life and its purpose
Things go better when I invite you into the objectives process

**Build**
Guide me selecting the projects that matter most
I trust you for the outcome, and am content with the result

**Teach**
You bring people into my life
I am responsible for being obedient; you take care of the rest

See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Is Jesus First?

fields.text:
* Integrity *                 -*-muse-*-

Integrity is a measure of personal wholeness.  It is impossible to be healthy when the different
parts of our inner person are not integrated.  Consistency within the different parts of our life
is a requirement for happiness.  This is impossible without the presence of God.  Whatever else we
do must be based on this.

A boat with 99% of its hull intact will still sink.

Measure your integrity (rank on a 10-point scale):
 * Peace with others, family, self, and God
 * Personal development within the last year
 * Social connections
 * Service to others
 * Understanding of life purpose
 * Self-sacrifice
 * Difference between emotional extremes

Emotional evidence:
 * Love & Passion
 * Peace & Joy
 * Kindness & Gentleness
 * Humility & Patience
 * Self-control

How are you doing?  Hopefully, well, but with room to grow.  If your score below 5 in any of these
areas you should think about how you can grow.  Surround yourself with people that can help you.
Read books. Seek counseling.  Whatever it takes to get healthy. Everything else depends on it.

See also ActionModel, PersonalManagement
fields.title: Integrity

fields.title: Running From God

fields.text:
* Belief Leads Behavior *                 -*-muse-*-

My behavior is determined by what I believe. If I see things the way that You do then my actions
will be aligned with Your purposes. On the other hand, if I am deceived about the truth, that
deception will lead me to do things that follow the false reasoning.

Lord, show me areas where I have believe lies. Reveal the power that those lies have to control my
life. Let me see through the lies to grasp Your truth. Give me the supernatural power to embrace
Your truth. Transform me from the inside.

Good intentions to obey without seeing the truth and the lies are powerless to control me. Without a
change in perception I am doomed to continue on in the same pattern. Help me, Jesus. I need You.

 * Perceive the truth
 * Believe the truth
 * Receive the truth
fields.title: Belief Leads Behavior

fields.text:
* Cover Letter *                 -*-muse-*-

I have a wealth of experience in software engineering encompassing many types of technologies and
software projects.  My primary passion is the process for creating high-quality, cost-effective
software systems.
 
I've identified several keys to great software development and created methods for training and
mentoring teams:

  * Managing complexity is essential to great software. Developers can be trained to address
    problems early while they are still easy to fix. 

  * Tools and automation can greatly simplify or eliminate repetitive tasks. I show teams how to
    identify areas that must be automated and how to build automation around a running system.

  * Most projects can benefit from an outside perspective. An adviser can provide momentum for what
    others already know must be done.

I also love doing hands-on project work, including system architecture, project planning,
test-driven development, and implementation.

 See also Business
fields.title: Cover Letter

fields.text:
* Burst Mode *                 -*-muse-*-

A burst is a 30 minute activity that is aimed at producing a single user story.  To accomplish this
we follow the User Story Process.

Creating a new feature in software is organized around a building a user story.  Each story is a
scenario for solving a specific user problem.

The overall process will follow a familiar pattern.

**Learn**   5 minutes

    understand the user problem
    describe the end goal
    identify the key elements that the solution must have

**Plan**    5 minutes

    propose a solution
    detail the solution by creating a series of next steps
    reduce the solution to its core

**Test**    5 minutes

    figure out a test strategy
    create a testing context
    incrementally test to drive development

**Fix**     5 minutes

    solve problems that emerge during the testing
    keep a list of all unsolved issues
    review progress on all defects

**Extend**  5 minutes

    add new product features
    strive to deploy the same day
    test every five minutes

**Improve** 5 minutes

    refactor constantly
    eliminate duplication between programs
    identify common patterns


See also UserStoryProcess, BurstWorksheet
fields.title: Burst Mode

fields.text:
* Version Control Tricks *                 -*-muse-*-
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Version Control**

**Use modern version control**
Project time is too precious to be confused
Simple things must be easy; hard things must be possible
Setup a great tool and brige if you need to

Code:
    git init
    echo Slide Slinger Features > Read-Me.txt
    git commit -am'Slide slinger features'
    git status
 
**Sync yer files**
Use git to share your files
Sharing to a server covers the backup need

Code:
    git clone some-url  # Copy some repository
    git pull            # Get code from others
    git push            # Share your code

**Use simple version control**
Show what changed
Commit changes
Get in sync
Share with others

Code:
    git status
    git diff
    git commit -am'Current changes I made'
    git pull
    git push

**Create custom commands**
Wrap the standard commands to hide to complexity
Create commands that support your workflow

Code:
    s-x s-changes 's-d && git status';    s-changes
    s-x s-commit  'git commit -am"$2"';   s-commit
_____________________________________________________________________________


See also FiftyTestTricks
fields.title: Version Control Tricks

fields.text:
* Mod WSGI *                 -*-muse-*-


Using mod_wsgi with Django on Ubuntu

sudo apt-get install libapache2-mod-wsgi

Virtual host configuration:

    <VirtualHost *:80>

        ServerAdmin you@example.com
        ServerName example.com
        DocumentRoot /home/you/public_html/example_com/public

        # Django settings
        WSGIScriptAlias / /home/you/public_html/example_com/wsgi_handler.py
        WSGIDaemonProcess example_com user=you group=you processes=1 threads=10
        WSGIProcessGroup example_com

        # Non-Django directories
        Alias /static /home/you/public_html/example_com/public/static/
        <Location "/static">
            SetHandler None
        </Location>

    </VirtualHost>

Put a file called wsgi_handler.py in your project folder:

    import os, sys

    sys.path.append(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)) + '/..')
    os.environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE'] = 'example_com.settings'

    import django.core.handlers.wsgi

    application = django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIHandler()

Excerpt from:
    http://solutions.treypiepmeier.com/2008/09/20/using-mod_wsgi-with-django-on-ubuntu/


See also ComputerSetup

fields.text:
* Consulting Gild *                 -*-muse-*-

I have a dream of someday working at a consulting firm that is organized like a doctors'
practice. This company would work for a variety of clients to provide IT services.

Each partner would be responsible to bring in its own clients and service them. We would share
marketing, business and administrative services. Each partner would pay a fixed percentage to the
firm in return for these services. Fees would be set by the engineers to be competitive.

Expertise could be shared between the partners. Specialized marketing could be done to bring more
clients. Consultants could cover for each other.

The firm would lease office space to have a physical place to meet with clients. This would increase
the perceived legitimacy of the firm.

fields.text:
* Git - Oscon Training Session *                 -*-muse-*-

Office Hours at GitHub.com/training
http:/amzn.com
not a new subversion: not a file tracker, but a content tracker
you only nee 15% of the 150 commands to be a great git user
learn about programming by studying the layering in git commands
http://whatthecommit.dot
where are the tenacles?
user info is not authorization (just identity)
mutable with a permanence marker
google the ship of theseus
protocols: file, git, ssh, http

**Command Guide**

git add 
    -p file
    -u .
    -A

git commit
     -a -m'Comment'

git diff 
    --color-words
    --word-diff
    --staged
    HEAD
    origin/master

git log
    --stat
    -p
    --patch
    --color-words
    -3
    --pretty=raw -1
    -M
    master..origin/master  (older..newer)

git cat-file -p bfbc

git status -u

git clone https://url-name  dir-name

git remote -v

git fetch

git merge origin/master

git branch 
    -a
    new-branch-name

trust is asymetrical

fork the repo
git clone repo

fork is the beginning of collaboration at GitHub

git push -u origin branch-name

pull request for modified branch

git remote add matthew https://github.com/project-user/hellogit.git

git fetch project

git merge matthew/master

git push

git stash
    list
    pop
    apply  stash@{2}

git commit --amend -m'Fix the comment on the old commit'

git commit --amend

git reset --hard 'HEAD^^^'
git reset --hard 'HEAD~3'


See also [[OSCON]]

fields.text:
* Power of Fear *                                       -*-muse-*-

Sometimes fear comes at night.

Stalking me like a relentless enemy.

Fear creates its own reality, calling all things into question.

How will I respond?

Run and hide or stand and fight?

This time I choose to yield!

But not to fear.

I choose trust in the God who loves me.

His presence has been with me through the darkest times of despair.

In fact, the fear I now face is nothing compared to those times.

Your presence is the cause for hope.

As I turn toward you I feel peace returning.

You are the antidote for anxiety.

You are the source of true peace.
fields.title: Power of Fear

fields.text:
* Watermill Support Scripts *                 -*-muse-*-

Automation is essential to both productivity and quality because it
reproduces repeatable results.  

Knowledge should be stored in scripts.  It should be executed and tested.

Use 'sc-help' to list the available developer scripts for Support
Center.

**Support Center Web page**
sc-show         # Show local Support Center
sc-web          # Show local Support Center
sc-admin        # Show remote Support Center admin view

**Support Center Scripts**
sc-help         # List Watermill commands
sc-exe          # Create a new Support Center control script
sc-commands     # List Watermill commands
scc             # Execute Support Center commands

**Testing**
sc-qt           # Support Center quick test
sc-test         # Create a new Support Center control script

**Deployment**
sc-apache       # Restart the local development web server
sc-deploy       # Deploy the staging server code

**Git - Version Control**
sc-changes      # Show the Git status
sc-download     # Download the archive files from the production server
sc-checkout     # Checkout the code on the production server 
sc-commit       # Commit all the outstanding files
sc-newgit       # Create a new git repo on the production server 

**Web Faction**
sc-term         # Support Center terminal
sc-control-panel # Go to the Support Center control panel

**Database**
sc-newdb        # Create a new database from the command line
sc-loaddb       # Create a new database from the command line
sc-savedb       # Save the database from the command line


See also WmServer
fields.title: Watermill Support Scripts

fields.text:
* Tricks For Rapid Development *                 -*-muse-*-

**Small steps**
make it simpler
never lose control or stability  (move slow to move fast)
fix it now; do not ignore problems
make it better with every step
delay work until it is needed

**test first**
rerun automatic tests for free
each test should be one line 
every line of code should have a test
schedule tests to run each week,day,hour
system tests are scripts that use your system
unit test are for isolated functions

**automation**
create your own language for working your system
scripts are named for the desired result
build your own future
find a bigger lever

**predictable results**
run from source every time
everything should be kept in version control
automate all deployment tasks
define the full context required to run your system


 See also  RapidDevelopment, DevelopmentRules
fields.title: Tricks For Rapid Development

fields.text:
* Variable Mapping Conversion *                 -*-muse-*-

**Goal:**
Convert from XML variable definitions to a lookup table

**Development Strategy**
Work from a stable base of master
Test all manual edits
Avoid converting hardware I/O
Unit test all code
Create *tested* branch
Remove wmeSystemData includes
Remove module dependencies
Test on watermill
Debug at first problem
Capture lessons for the next project

**Tools:**
dependents          # Find all of the users of wmeSystemData
fix-modules         # Convert the SConscript files
include-vars        # Add includes for all files
find-increments     # Find  ++, +=, -=
expand_increments   # Map ++, +=, -=
find-set-lines      # Find all of the references to set
replace-set-lines   # Convert all sets
find-get-lines      # Find all of the references to get
replace-get-lines   # Convert all gets
convert-var-lines   # Convert all the source code
translate           # Find and convert all the source code
remove-system-data  # Remove the includes for "WmeSystemData.h"

VarCodeChanges, VarTypes, [[Work]], [[Done]]
fields.title: Variable Mapping Conversion

fields.text:
* My Book Hosting *                 -*-muse-*-

https://my.webfaction.com/

**Steps to configure WebFaction host to create MyBook.**
Use the control panel to create

**Applications**
    application (Django 1.2 mod_python using WSGI)

    application for static content

        static_media
        Static media (no .htaccess)

    application for admin media

        admin_media
        Symlink for static media
        /home/seaman/webapps/mybook/admin-media

**Database**
    new MySQL database set the password to  web site mapping

        django application (app name, /)
        admin media (/admin_media)
        static media (/media)

**Import the data**
Login to web hosting account

manage.py syncdb
manage.py loaddata data/book.topic.json

**Configure Apache application**
Edit /home/seaman/webapps/project/apache2/conf/httpd.conf
Change myproject to mybook
Change myproject.settings to settings
Copy the admin media files

c /home/seaman/webapps/mybook/lib/python2.5/django/contrib/admin/media  /home/seaman/webapps/mybook/admin-media

**Test**
test the application

    * http://mybookonline.org
    * http://mybookonline.org/admin

See also MyBook
fields.title: My Book Hosting

fields.text:
* Technical Debt *                 -*-muse-*-

*Everything that you need to do but cannot do now*

"Pay me now or pay later with interest"
Debt levels can always be measured in hours to pay it off.
________________________________________________________________________________________

**Tools Debt**          - computer tools that do not work

**Communication Debt**  - unspoken info or expectation mismatch

**Learning Debt**       - things you still need to know 

**Planning Debt**       - unmet goals or paralysis from lack of planning

**Writing Debt**        - things unwritten

**Merge Debt**          - code that has diverged

**Task Debt**           - unfinished projects and incomplete actions

**Defect Debt**         - known problems in software

**Structural Debt**     - structural problems in software

**Process Debt**        - process problems 

**Career debt**         - lack of reflection or direction

**Marketing Debt**      - potential loss of work due to weak relationships


See also [[Work]]
fields.title: Technical Debt

fields.text:
* Project Planning *                 -*-muse-*-

Just enough planning

**Capture**
record ideas as they come
allow all sizes of scope (from big to small)
identify the core idea that is being purused
create a 4x4 description (10 minute plan)

**Dream**
imagine where this project could go
what new capabilities are enabled
how does this overlap with other projects

**Organize**
key benefit desired
project cost
short-term/long-term gain
project data sheet

**Prioritize**
leverage opportunities
fit into big picture
invest limited resources of time and $

**Philosophy**
capture all changes
incremental planning
priority drives focus
use one consolidated system
Four levels of scope: Role, Project, Task, Action
Plan, Do, Review

**Present**
cascading list
instant priority
record of actions (1/2 hr increments)
top actions & hot projects
update changes constantly

**Past**
weekly review
monthly summary
project log (weekly summary)
time allocation
accounting & reports

**Future**
Capture new ideas & actions & projects
Create simple plans (of all scopes)
Allocate time to projects weekly
Update project priorities weekly

**Simplify the Planning Approach**

Past - Celebrate success
 * Spend 30% on capturing accomplishments
 * Record, Review, Create a story, Leverage to new options

Present - Optimize time
 * Prioritize and focus
 * Leverage between projects
 * ROI - max effect for min effort
 * One week horizon

Future - Limit commitments
 * Project pyramid
 * Roles lead goals
 * Periodic planning - Monthly, Quarterly, Yearly

See also [[Projects]]  ProjectDataSheet  ProjectPlanner
fields.title: Project Planning
