fields.text:
* Personal Review Questions *                 -*-muse-*-


**Daily life**
In the last twenty-four hours, what gave you joy? Sorrow?
Who in your life (past or present) has given you a taste of God's love?
What activities in your life seem to draw you to God? What activities in your life seem to pull you away from God?
When and where are you most likely to be aware of God's presence? When or where are you least aware of God's presence?
In the last day or two, when or where are you most aware of the presence of God in your life?

**Spiritual journey**
How would you describe your relationship with God today?
What is prayer like for you? What kind of prayer is most appealing to you?
When do you remember first thinking about God?
How do you experience temptation in your life?
What do you do really well? What do you think you are gifted to do?
What is your soul longing for today?
How is it for you when you read scripture?
When are you bored with your spiritual journey?

**To go deeper**
How is your view of God changing because of this experience?
What person in your own life acts (or acted) the way you perceive God to be acting in your life right now?
How would you like God to help you in this?
What do you think the spirit of Jesus might be whispering to your spirit in this situation?
How are you being changed by this relationship or set of circumstances?
How would you most like God to touch your soul, your inner being, at this time in your life?

**Closing**
How would you like to experience God in the next few weeks?
Do you sense any invitation from God in this?
What would you like God's invitation to be?
How do you hope your relationship with God will change as a result of this time together?
What do you see as the first step on this next phase for your spiritual journey?

**Feelings**
Can you say more about the (anger, fear, perplexity, etc.)?
How does your body respond to that feeling?
When are you most likely to have that feeling in this relationship or situation?
As you think about the issue you're processing, what feelings rise up within you?
When in your life before have you had the feeling you're describing now?
Or would you say you're feeling glad, mad, sad, confused or angry about this situation or relationship?
What adjective describes how you feel about the person or event you're talking about?
Would you like us just to sit with you for a few minutes in silence to let you feel that feeling?
I hear anger or frustration or hurt in your voice. Is that what you're feeling?
What would be helpful to you right now?

See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Personal Review Questions

fields.text:
* Anxiety Dream *                 -*-muse-*-

I had the srangest dream last night.  It took place at church while I
was operating the presentation media for a large conference.  There
were about 500 people there so I was trying my best to not distract
others from paying attention.

Stacie was helping me too, by telling me to click on things.
Everything that I clicked on brought up some random image or launched
into a random video.  Everyone in the room started to murmur and Stacie
and I started to argue loudly.  Suddenly an episode of Amazing Race
broke out.

I was so frustrated that I yanked the mouse out of the computer and
threw it across the room.  This immeditately seemed like it was a
mistake so I went searching through the crowd to see if anyone had
seen my mouse that had gone missing recently.  It was nowhere to be
found.

Meanwhile the meeting had completely stopped and I felt a little
responsible. Fortunatey the next thing that happened was me waking
up. What a great way to escape such a public embarrassment.  Best of
all there were no social reprocussions from my little meltdown.

See also [[Brain]]
fields.title: Anxiety Dream

fields.text:
* Git Repo Setup *                 -*-muse-*-

How to make a git repository, make it shareable and upload it to a central server.

Choose name for new repo of the form project-git

Create the local git repo

cd project-git
git init
git add .


Copy the repo without the working directory

cd /tmp
git clone --bare ~/project-git .


Copy the new repo to the server

ssh 65.121.123.211
cd  /usr/local
scp -r old-computer:/tmp/project-git .


Change the file permissions

cd /usr/local
chgrp -R scm project-git
chmod -R 770 project-git
chmod g+s -R project-git


Set up the correct options

cd /usr/local/project-git
git repo-config core.sharedRepository true
allow unannotated tags
cd /usr/local/project-git/hooks
chmod -x update
vi description
fields.title: Git Repo Setup

fields.text:
* Turning Point *                 -*-muse-*-

*Turn to the Lord, and you and your family will be saved!*

A relationship with God is marked by moments of clarity.  This often happens when we are going along
and minding our own business, which is really another way of saying ignoring God. Then we suddenly
become aware of how the Lord has been working in our lives.

This can be a dramatic experience, like Paul going to Damascus, or a more subtle one, such as John
Wesley feeling "strangely warmed".  Either way this is a powerful emotional experience for us.  This
become a reference point, as we think about our relationship with God.

We are not always aware of his presence in our lives. The problem is on our side not his.  Life is
filled with turmoil, business, relationships, losses and triumphs.  We are often led by fear and
pride. Both make us feel alienated from God.

Then, often in the midst of confusion, God shows up.  We suddenly see everything differently.  He
show us how one core assumption is invalid and we spend months trying to understand the full
implications of that.

In the bible, people would often build memorials to commemorate these events.  This is a good idea
for us too.  Place something in your daily life that symbolizes the emotional significance of an
encounter with God.

The specific experience that you have at a turning point will not last.  But there is an residual
effect that leaves us changed. Later in the business of life, we still recall the moment when we
caught a glimpse of the glory of God.

Grab a hold of these moments and savor them.  Create reminders that will take you back to that time
when you felt the Lord's presence the most.  He is longing for us to feel closer to him.  Use that
memory to create more time seeking his closeness.

In the presence of God, every daily struggle seems less critical.  This lesson is the most important
thing that we learn in the turning point.

See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Turning Point

* Our Lake *                 -*-muse-*-
Journal of activity around the lake in our back yard.

**2-17**

Lake thaws
Large numbers of Gulls are fishing on the lake
A family of four eagles apear in the skies around our house
They build a nest in the tree across the lake
The blue herron appears for the first time this year
A few mallard ducks appear
First red wind black bird of the year

**2-24**
Lake freezes up again, thaws, and then freezes
Family of four eagles is spotted by our house
At least one eagle is visible most of the day
Canadian geese begin arriving
Albino goose
400 geese on the lake at one time

**3-3**
Eagles build a nest in a tree 200 yards from our house
Daily observation of eagles
Blue herron is around occasionally
Extreme cold causes the lake to freeze up again

**3-10**
Lake thaws
Daily observation of eagles
Blue herron is around occasionally
Water Valley fixed the beach at our house
Alternating between warm and cold days

**3-17**
Daily observation of eagles
Blue herron is around occasionally
Work crew repaired the beach

**3-24**
Geese starting to reapear
Blue herron is around regularly
Fairly cold temperatures mixed with warmer days

**3-31**
warming trend - hit 60 degrees

**4-7**
3-6 inches of snow

**4-14**
Cormorants arrive
eagle drying its wings
blue herron 
first pelican arrives

**4-20**
set up telescope to watch eagle in tree
pelicans on lake daily
last sighting of eagle

**4-27**
15 pelicans hunting with 30 cormarants
bald eagle has not been seen in a week

* Business For Two *                 -*-muse-*-
Description of a successful business model for a comapny with two people.
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Technical work**
Each person works as a consultant
Actively develop areas of collaboration.
Each parnter does individual and shared work.
Shift to shared work over time.
Shift from contract engineering to products.

**Marketing**
Each person brings in consulting work and can work with customers.
When booked solid then raise the hourly fees charged.
Sources for clients: 
 * free seminars
 * past customers
 * business network
 * training

**Growth**
When work becomes too great then it is time to bring in a business/marketing person.
Make sure that two person company is debugged
Requires at least one full business cycle (sales,work,delivery)
Automate everything

**Management**
Two equal partners: ownership, decisions, finance
10% of revenue is contributed to the company.
Split up administration
Each partner has own insurance

See also Business

**Install RVM** -- Ruby Version Manager
bash < <(curl -s https://rvm.beginrescueend.com/install/rvm)
echo '[[ -s "$HOME/.rvm/scripts/rvm" ]] && . "$HOME/.rvm/scripts/rvm" # Load RVM function' >> ~/bin/bashrc
rc
rvm install 1.9.2 && rvm use 1.9.2
rvm rubygems latest

**Install Octopress**
git clone git://github.com/imathis/octopress.git octopress
cd octopress    # To trust the .rvmrc file (say yes).
ruby --version  # Should report Ruby 1.9.2
sudo apt-get install ruby-bundler
bundle install
rake install

**Post directory**
[[~/octopress/source/_posts/][Directory]]

fields.text:
* My Perfect Life *                 -*-muse-*-

Here is a powerful exercise.  Sit down and describe your ideal life
situation of three years from now.  This is not a plan but a target.
What would you life your life to be like in three years?

Why three years?  It is close enough that it demands immediate
action. But there is also enough time to accomplish something
meaningful. A five year goal may not be very realistic because there
is a feeling that anything in possible.  A one year goal, on the other
hand, is so immediate that it is not possible to dream.

Three years is enough time to create meaningful change.  The question
is, "What direction do you want the change to be in?".  This should be
an expression of your values.  What things drive you at your core?

At this point in my life I value autonomy, mastery, and purpose.
These three core values were first articulated for me in the book
"Drive", by Daniel Pink.  But they have resonated with me for a long time.

A target for my life three years from now, would need to embrace all
three of these dimensions. Before describing the ideal situation,
let's explore each of these three dimensions.

**Autonomy**

For much of my life I had to work to meet the expectations of others.
This was a natural consequence of having responsibility for the
welfare of my family.  Now that they are grown I am able to take on
more professional risks.

I have also spent thirty years building technical experience and
financial strength to weather the inevitable turmoil to come.  Life is
what happens when you are busy making other plans.

Having consistently invested for three decades has put me in a strong
bargaining position from a career, financial, and relational
viewpoint.  Now it is time to experience the benefit of that.

I want a life situation that lets me choose what I work on, when I
work, and who I work with.  I love thinking about projects and intend
to work hard on them.  But this must be internally motivated rather
than forced by the expectations of others.

I have worked hard to achieve this position, and now I am already in a
position to control the terms of by career.  The biggest challenge
for me is to not sell this freedom for some other benefit.

**Mastery**

I see myself as an inventor, software developer, and author.  From
childhood I have been fascinated by inventing things.  I love learning
and teaching others.  My whole adult life has been a quest for
achieving mastery of the process of developing software.

Over the last few years, I have been making more time to write.
Reading is a very important part of my life.  I have the largest
personal library of anyone I know.  As I learn more I feel compelled
to pass that knowledge on to others.

Over the last few years I have begun to develop daily practices of
writing. I have been learning more about the process of writing and
how to tell a good story.  Someday I hope to be a strong writer with a
following of people who anticipate the next update.

I love computers (except when they break).  Software development is an
intensely human activity.  It is a chance to create an entire world
inside of a computer.  I have been very fascinated by the mechanics of
the process of software creation.  I want to thoroughly understand and
teach what makes great software.

**Purpose**

I think that purpose is about serving others.  It is about meeting the
needs of someone else.  Sure we have to meet our own needs but that is
not enough.  We each must have a feeling that we are producing more
than we are consuming.

At the end of my life I must be able to point to my career and see
that I contributed much more than I was ever paid.  I must be able to
look at the lives of the people that loved me most and realize that
their lives were much fuller for knowing me.

Finally purpose for me is about knowing that I have changed the
world. I need to know that things that I have said have been heard,
and that things that I have done have made a difference.

This comes to the issue of influence.  Have I led others to a deeper
understanding of truth?  Are others inspired by my example to a
greater level of sacrifice?  These are the questions that cause me to
lay awake at night.
fields.title: My Perfect Life

fields.text:
* Filter, Map, Reduce *                 -*-muse-*-

**Filter**

filter(function, sequence) returns a sequence (of the same type, if
possible) consisting of those items from the sequence for which
function(item) is true. For example, to compute some primes:

        >>> filter(lambda x: x%2 != 0 and x%3 != 0, range(2, 25))
        [5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23]
        >>>

**Map**

map(function, sequence) calls function(item) for each of the
sequence's items and returns a list of the return values. For example,
to compute some cubes:

        >>> map(lambda x: x*x*x, range(1, 11))
        [1, 8, 27, 64, 125, 216, 343, 512, 729, 1000]
        >>>

More than one sequence may be passed; the function must then have as
many arguments as there are sequences and is called with the
corresponding item from each sequence (or None if some sequence is
shorter than another). If None is passed for the function, a function
returning its argument(s) is substituted.

Combining these two special cases, we see that map(None, list1, list2)
is a convenient way of turning a pair of lists into a list of
pairs. For example:

        >>> seq = range(8)
        >>> map(None, seq, map(lambda x: x*x, seq))
        [(0, 0), (1, 1), (2, 4), (3, 9), (4, 16), (5, 25), (6, 36), (7, 49)]
        >>>


**Reduce**

reduce(function, sequence) returns a single value constructed by
calling the (binary) function on the first two items of the sequence,
then on the result and the next item, and so on. For example, to
compute the sum of the numbers 1 through 10:

        >>> reduce(lambda x, y: x+y, range(1, 11))
        55
        >>>

If there's only one item in the sequence, its value is returned; if
the sequence is empty, an exception is raised.

A third argument can be passed to indicate the starting value. In this
case the starting value is returned for an empty sequence, and the
function is first applied to the starting value and the first sequence
item, then to the result and the next item, and so on. For example,

        >>> def sum(seq):
        ...     return reduce(lambda x, y: x+y, seq, 0)
        ... 
        >>> sum(range(1, 11))
        55
        >>> sum([])
        0
        >>>

See also PythonTricks
fields.title: Filter, Map, Reduce

fields.text:
* Send Html * -*-muse-*- This text is the body of an email message received at gmail. Thinking - * Shrinking World Solutions *

* Shrinking World Solutions *

Tips to help you thrive in the modern world

Sign up for email updates

Thinking

How you think dictates to a large extent the quality of your life. Some people are naturally good at think through problems and coming up with great solutions. Here are a few patterns that can help you in thinking better.

List limit of 9 items

Psychological studies have shown that people can only retain up to nine items in short-term memory. This means that any list where you expect a selection ony works up to nine items. Longer lists should be broken into multiple selection lists. A reasonable list should have five or more items to be useful. Nesting can be used to handle more complicated scenarios.

Minimize mindshare

Some things we can control and other things we cannot. Try to make your circle of influence match your circle of concern. Decrease the amount of mental energy that you invest in areas where you have little influence. Save your energy for the things that you can change.

Eliminate multitasking

Your worst enemy is multiple tasks interrupting each other. Focus on one activity as much as possible until it is completed. Then go on to the next with equal focus. It is very easy for us to spend as much as 50% of our overall time just switching between multiple tasks. This has become especially bad in our modern world. Most people underestimate the cost of multitasking.

Scheduled thinking

Consider having a block of time scheduled to think through problems. Imagine knowing that you could just file that issue away for 3:00 Thursday. I recommend that you perform this think time in a location where you cannot be interrupted. Start with one hour per week. You are likely to find that you need more time, and that it is easily justified by the return that you get.

Think before you leap

When confronted with a big decision consider taking both paths. Imagine trying to live with each of the alternatives. Which one seems to carry the least risk? Which is better in the short term or in the long term? What problem might surface? What does your intuition tell you?

Brainstorm/organize

A great way to work out problems is to brainstorm. This typically involves making a list of various ideas or impression. During a brainstorm try to postpone judgment. Once you have captured a bunch of ideas you can work on grouping things together. This is the time to apply some judgment and pruning.

Four by four analysis

In order to think through, a topic try this technique. Break your main topic into four roughly equal topics. Then decompose each of them into four more topics. I found that this technique is remarkably useful to help me see the interesting aspects of almost any subject. It gives you twenty one statements that have both breadth and depth that can be explored later.

Work on only one thing

Select a single task that will be the most satisfying to have done. Postpone distractions until this task is complete. By selecting this task you are saying that this is the most important thing that you could do right now. If you feel that a legitimate interruption is likely then limit the scope of your task to complete it sooner. Then you can focus on another task when needed.

Use tools that preserve context

Don't have multiple windows up on your computer (each vying for your attention). When you run an application, make the window take the full screen. Finish one thought before going on the next. Turn off email notification, and check it between tasks. If you don't control your tools they will control you. Know what you must do in your job to succeed and create the environment that lets you focus. If your job calls for 10 second response time on IM, then play along. If it is a constant distraction, turn it off.

Try new things

Break your routine occassionally. Keep a list of random things to do for fun. At least once a week, pick a fun thing and do it. Life is too serious for most of us. Look up an old friend. Do a random act of kindness. Play a practical joke. Tell someone that you love them.

Random item from the past

Imagine having a list of things to think about someday. Now image doing a random selection from that list. This would give you a miscellaneous topic to ponder for a few minutes. I use this technique for a number of different lists. I frequently get emails of ticklers to remind me of things that I originally thought about earlier. The key idea here is to have a list of topics and a random selection. You could do the same thing by shuffling 3 x 5 cards with ideas.

Say in fewer words

I like to make complex subjects simple. One way to do this is to describe something and then try to capture the same ideas with half of the words. Is it possible to get the same idea in 5 words? Try to think in sound bites.

List of current problems

Consider keeping a list of problems that need think-time. Pick a problem and analyze it. Try all your best techniques: pros-and-cons, return on investment, brainstorming, SWOT (strength, weakness, opportunity, threat). Bang away at the problem for an hour and see if any new solutions pop out.

See also Table of Contents , Previous Page , Next Page


Sponsored by Shrinking World Solutions
See also [[Brain]], SendHtmlMessage
fields.title: Send Html

fields.text:
* Brain Lobes *                 -*-muse-*-

An external brain is a kind of wiki.  Each topic is related to other topics.  There is a tendency
towards identifiable clusters of related topics.  Let's call each of these clusters a lobe, to use
the brain analogy.

Each lobe has a index that lists the collection of topics.  In turn, each topic also references the
index by including it in a "See also" line at the end of the topic.

Occasionally, it is important to verify that this double linkage is updated.  This is done by
searching for a keyword throughout the brain and reviewing the resulting text. All topics that
belong to the lobe should appear in the index.  They should also be searchable by using the
brain-tag command.

See also [[BrainProject]], CommandClusters
fields.title: Brain Lobes

* Spiritual Retreat *                 -*-muse-*-

Set aside one day quartery to be alone with God.  Go somewhere unusual don't do any normally
expected activities.

Review time and money allocation
Refresh dreams and fears
Relational inventory
Listen to God
Work on marriage improvements
Review developments for the past year
Pray for people
Write down ideas
Decide on followup actions

**Retreat Notes - 7-6-2013**

What do I want my relationship with God to be like?
 * friend of God
 * feel his acceptance
 * experience absolute trust
 * total surrender
 * in the center of God's will
 * integration & explanation of life
 * know God's will
 * feel God's love
 * wisdom 
 * map - where I've been and where I'm going

Heard in the silence
 * receive my gift
 * live in the present
 * experience me
 * peace
 * frantic pace
 * tune in
 * day dream
 * green space for the soul
 * poverty of spirit leads to desparation

Growth in relationship requires paying attention both to the other and our own reactions.

Awareness allows spiritual growth.

Stop, look, listen.

Understanding resolves frustration.

Spiritual formation is shaping the inner person to be more like Jesus.

Behavior follows transformation.


**Prayer of Surrender**
Lord, I yield myself to you.
Let your will be my delight today.
My your love be the pattern for my life.
I surrender my hopes, dreams, and ambitions.
Do with them what you will, whenever you want.
I place in your loving hands my family, friends, and future.
You care for them far more than I ever could.
I release my need to control, my craving for success, and my fear of failure.
Purge selfish motivations and other forms of evil.
Transform my heart and give me a longing for more of you.
Lead me to serve others effectively.
Use me to bring you glory and draw others to follow you.

fields.text:
* Monthly Objectives *                 -*-muse-*-
 
Over the next month there will be about 40 hours of free-style work.  Here is a plan for
how to invest that time in important activities.

Objectives are really about telling your business story, for the past, present, and
future. The roles you play are characters in the story.

Pause monthly to reflect to tell the story in a better way.  Recap the past and rewrite
the future.  The past deals with things that are already accomplished and lessons learned.
These need to be processed in order to get the full value from them.

There should always be experiments that are happening now and others in the queue.  Active
experiements are already underway or will start in the next couple of weeks.  There should
not be more than one new thing in play at any time. Set up a queue of desired experiements
and prioritize the expected results.

The are many great projects that I would like to do as soon as possible.  The challenge of
writing the future part of the story is determining the relative priorities for these
projects.  This can be very difficult but decreases the conflict of attempting everything.

**create monthly objectives process**

 * develop my business story (architect, engineer, businessman)
 * past    - What have I done? What have I learned?  Who do I know?
 * present - What am I doing? What am I learning?
 * future  - What is my legacy?  Who will go with me?  
 * define next experiment
 * plan for business networking

fields.text:
* Debugging Process *                 -*-muse-*-

Reproduce the error
    Understand the problem that was observed
    Try to get the problem to happen again
    Get closer to the original context until problem happens
    Make problem happen several times

Make it go away
    Try a new context and observe that the problem has disappeared
    Don't do anything else until you can eliminate the problem
    Reproduce the problem
    Run the context that removes the problem

Turn problem on and off
    Preserve two contexts (with and without the problem)
    Alternate test runs must pass or fail
    Determine what is different (between pass and fail)
    If you cannot turn the problem on and off you have lost it

Bisect the space until problem is found
    Try to get to the smallest difference between pass and fail
    Isolate to root cause
    Do not attempt to fix problem before cause is found
    Try to limit fix to one line of code
fields.title: Debugging Process

fields.text:
* Ssh Tunneling *                 -*-muse-*-

To expose a machine that is inside the firewall to be called from outside do the following to establish a tunnel.

 $ ssh -L8888:inside-ip:80 outside-ip

which reads as "establish a tunnel that maps port 8888 on the local host to the inside-ip on port 80. The outside-ip is a gateway through the firewall.

Once the port forwarding has been established then access the web page at http://localhost:8888

Example:

 $ ssh -L8888:10.97.24.40:80 204.133.31.34
 $ web 'http://localhost:8888/web'
fields.title: Ssh Tunneling

fields.text:
* Watermill Subcontracting *                 -*-muse-*-

**Meet with Bryan**

    My dilhemna
        Cannot scale
        Cannot deliver enough time to clients
        Need to change business models
        Change means risk
        Hiring and pay-as-you-go

    Opportunity
        Watermill approval
        Shared risk for Don/Eric/Mark/Bryan
        Building using stepping-stones
        Experience = Income

    Pay
        Billable rate (based on value-added)
        Business overhead (based of value-added)
        Rates follow job function
        Total annual income - area under the curve
        Total earning potential - lifetime
    
    Expectations
        20 hours
        Motivated to learn
        Pay the bills
        Work closely (shared goals)
        Long-term potential

**Write proposal**

    Limited time to invest
        Expanding my business to work for new clients
        Available time is limited to 8 hours/week
        Committed to providing support and engineering services

    Expand services by hiring staff
        Multiply the expertise to reduce risk
        Get more hours of engineering applied
        Provide staff with "appropriate" level of expertise for each job
        Create the most cost effective solution possible

    Produce more value
        High quality through strong oversight and mentoring
        Greater effort
        Lower hourly cost


Don,

Over the last few months I have been working on restructuring my business to better serve my
clients.  I have been seeking to turn Shrinking World Solutions into a team of consultants that can
deliver high-quality software systems at reasonable cost.

In the past all of the work billed by the company was for my personal work.  While I intend to work
in the business full-time and be involved in the daily engineering work, this has real limitations
on the number of engineering hours I can deliver to each client.  The cost is also much higher than
it should be for the results achieved.

My goal is to hire, train, deploy, and manage the work of a team of specialists. This will allow us
to deliver both deeper and broader solutions to our clients.  I plan to be specifying, designing,
and reviewing the work, while having some others do some of the detailed programming.  

My son, Josiah, is currently working on a doctorate in bioinformatics at CU.  He wrote an
application to view the genome.  I have been collaborating with Josiah and his friend, Bryan Hurst, on
this project for about a year.  I am considering hiring Bryan as an associate progammer in my
company.  I met with him today to discuss this and he is open to the idea.

Watermill has need of more programming effort that I can currently afford to provide to finish out
the server projects.  There are currently twelve projects underway that are making very slow
progress.  This could be a solution help expedite these projects without letting the cost baloon.

Currently I can provide about 4 hours of engineering and 4 hours of support each week.  This is
barely about to keep up with the burden of things that break and unable to expand the current
system. If I were to use 20 hours/week of Bryan's time, I could produce, about 4 hours of support
each week, and 24 hours of engineering.

I would be responsible for the quality and productivity of all work done for Watermill by Shrinking
World Solutions.  Both training and management would be administered personally by me in
collaboration with Bryan.  Initially, he would work out of my office in Windsor, until the need for
communication dimished.

Because the hourly rate for Bryan would be less than half of what I make, the cost per hour to
Watermill would be significantly reduced.  I hope that this will be a long term collaboration and
intend on helping Bryan to develop a career as a leader in software development.  I also hope to use
this as a model that would allow other people to be added as needed to my company.

In order to move forward on this, I need your approval to enlist his help on Watermill projects.  I
believe that I will need to bill out his time at $35/hour in order to create enough incentive to get
him involved for the long-term.

If we are able to move quickly then Bryan can be fully engaged and cover any issues that appear
while I am gone to Jordan.  He has agreed to make this a priority and to commit up to 20 hours
weekly to this project.

Please let me know what you think about this proposal.

fields.text:
* Generations *                 -*-muse-*-

**Web sites**
    http://www.lifecourse.com/insight/timelines/generations.html
    http://www.lifecourse.com/insight/timelines/turnings.html

**Recognize patterns in history**
    Societies operate on a cycle that is predictable
    History is a fractal, recurring patterns at different levels of detail
    The cause for this can be understood

**Cyclical attitudes and events**
    War cycle
    Spiritual awakenings
    Ideas about children
    Public vs. private interests (security/freedom)

**Generations**
    Experiences create a similar outlook
    Each generation spans twenty years (matching the life phases)
    There are four generational archtypes (or patterns)
    These patterns occur in a predictable order

**Generational Cycles**
    Each generation plays a specific role in the cycle
    Each genation ages together causing  a change of lineup
    Each lineup produces a unique outlook
    This create pattern of four distinct seasons every eighty years

**History**
    History and culture can be viewed as cyclical
    Social dynamics are tied to the seasons
    Season changes are abrupt and inevitable
    Every human experiences every season
    Winter is more similar to other winters than to spring

**Gerational Patterns** (archtype)
    Hero - King
    Artist - Lover
    Prophet - Priest
    Nomad - Warror

Seasons (20 year periods)
    Spring - High:       Time of optimism, expansion and growth
    Summer - Awakening:  Spiritual growth and conflict over values
    Fall   - Unraveling: Deep devisions and growing problems with success
    Winter - Crisis: Old systems die and new ones are created


**Cycles in American History**

**Tudor**
(14871517) 	Tudor Renaissance
(15171542) 	Protestant Reformation
(15421569) 	Intolerance & Martyrdom
(15691594)     Armada Crisis

**New  World**
(15941621) 	Merrie England
(16211649) 	Puritan Awakening
(16491675) 	Reaction & Restoration
(16751704) 	Glorious Revolution

**Revolutionary**
(17041727) 	Augustan Age of Empire
(17271746) 	Great Awakening
(17461773)     French & Indian Wars
(17731794)     American Revolution

**Civil War**
(17941822) 	Era of Good Feelings
(18221844) 	Transcendental Awakening
(18441860) 	Mexican War & Sectionalism
(18601865) 	Civil War

**Great Power**
(18651886) 	Reconstruction & Gilded Age
(18861908) 	Third Great Awakening
(19081929) 	World War I & Prohibition
(19291946)     Great Depression & World War II

**American Millennial**
(19461964) 	American High
(19641984) 	Consciousness Revolution
(19842004) 	Culture Wars
(20052026)     Homeland Crisis


**My Family**

**Homeland** 2003-2026 (Artist)

* Simple Site Presentation *                 -*-muse-*-

Great engineering without marketing is mostly wasted.

Business success = products that deliver value + marketing plan

Great products are innovative
    solve a business problem
    high value
    use appropriate technology
    fast to market        

Great products are engineered
    just enough
    stable platform
    optimal flexibility
    quality is built in

Great products are grown
    sustainability
    pay as you go
    minimum viable product

Startup business rules

    flexibility is king - do what works

* Personal Retreat 2012-12-31 *                 -*-muse-*-

KingdomOfGod
reflections on the areas of my life and how God's kingdom is interacts with my will

The kingdom is about God's authority in my life.
    Within the kingdom there are different realms that represent local areas of control
    Each realm is in a different state of unrest or rebellion
    Periodically it is critical to get a briefing on the war
    Each land has a unique set of conditions and circumstances to confront

Questions for review
    What does piece look like? 
    What does unrest look like?
    Briefing on the past, present, and future of this realm?
    Gratitude --> Contentment, Simplicity, Generosity

Realms of the Kingdom
    Realm of Knowledge
        spiritual growth
        technical knowledge
        books & ideas
        travel & recreation
    Realm of Relationship
        influence
          professional reputation
          business relationships
          family
      Realm of Goals
          time
          expectations
          incremental planning
          prioritization
      Realm of Creativity
          thought life
          invention
          writing
          tools and practices
      Realm of Security
          finances
          health
          safety & risk
          family well-being

PersonalRetreat - create a template for personal retreat practices

ReviewCycles - review content based on period

CelebrateAccomplishments
    **recall** - make a list of everything that was done, or was was learned along the way
    **organize** - group things together into themes and extract the key learning
    **dream** - about where you would like to take this accomplishment in the future
    **share** - your ideas with others that can appreciate what you did
    **prioritize** - assess how important this accomplishment is relative to other possible investments

fields.text:
* Why I Write *                                                                             -*-muse-*-
________________________________________________________________________________________

**Why I write**
 * **organize**    - It helps me organize my thoughts in order to learn.
 * **express**     - It is an enjoyable form of self expression.
 * **contribute**  - It is a way to help someone else by passing on what I know.
 * **affirmation** - It brings recognition from others that I have good ideas.

**Who I write for**
 * Smart & busy people
 * People interested in best practices
 * People like me 
 * Professional people (age 25-50)

**What I write about**
 * Thriving by using technology and best practices
 * Becoming more human

**Where I write**
 * Seaman's Log
 * Build an Outer Brain
 * Super Power Handbook
 * Automate Your World
 * World Class Software

**How I write**
 * Write a great headline 
 * Build an outline
 * Write a draft
 * Rewrite for clarity and impact
 * Edit
 * Publish

**How to succeed**
 * Deliver great content predictably
 * Consciously build subscribers
 * Optimize for search
 * Create an integrated experience: email, web site, ebook
 * Separate publishing tools, marketing, and writing

**Measure of success**
 * number of messages sent > 2000
 * words written > 50,000
 * books available > 2 books

**Why Write?**
Influence           Seamans Log
Validation          facebook, g+, twitter
Process ideas       brain
Produce             kindle books
Marketing           SW dev
Software            SW dev
Publishing tool     mybook         
Enjoyment           brain

**Writing Motivation**

Autonomy
    Control life's details
    Satisfaction by real expectations
Mastery
    Knowledge growth: learning and solving problems
    Recognition & validation by others
Purpose
    Influence help someone else
    Produce value
    Connect & build relationships


See also [[Writing]], WritingTasks
fields.title: Why I Write

* Absolute Honesty *                 -*-muse-*-

It is hard for me to divulge my innermost thoughts, even to myself. I am afraid of being exposed, so
I hide within my lies and self-deception. I fear that if I admit what is really going on then You
will force me to change, so I protect my sin my hiding in the dark.


The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness can never extinguish it.

In this journal the truth about me will be exposed. I cast myself on Your mercy to work in my heart
to change me from the inside.

fields.text:
* Should You Budget *                 -*-muse-*-

Should you budget?

Budgeting means different things
    Accounting of each penny spend
    Different buckets for each expense
    Scheduled argument about money

Invested time must have value
    Administration has no inherent value
    Flexibility and adaptability
    Models must be customized to your needs
    Need discipline to fit spending into income

Switch to spending model
    Match your spending to your income
    Match your spending to your values
    Avoid administration
    Forcing choices is valuable

Define your ideal money model
    Based on actual history
    Reconcile with unique situation
    Helping others categories (Taxes, Giving, Saving)
    Caring for us (Housing, Living, Vacation)
    Manage spending to the overall percentage

See also LifeBudget
fields.title: Should You Budget

* Bible Meditation *                 -*-muse-*-

**ready**
Invite God's presence and take time to become aware of him.
Get still and prepare to receive from him.
Select a passage from scripture.

**read**
Savor a single verse.
Emphasize difference words.
Reword the passage or expand on it.

**reflect**
How can I apply this verse?
Is this related to other similar passages?

**respond**
React to the revelation from the Spirit.
Express surrender, grattitude, or any other appropriate response.

**rest**
Receive love, affirmation, peace, and wisdom from God
Listen for instruction relating to further action needed

**return**
Visit this moment throughout the day
Refect on themes prompted by God to identify opportunities.

See also PrayerPractices

fields.text:
* Development Contexts *                 -*-muse-*-

When you are developing software consider doing the work for a
specific context.  In fact there are three unique contexts that are
important at each stage of development.   Understanding what is shared
and what is unique will speed your development.

The three contexts that you should consider are:
 1. **Customer benefit** - when and how will you make business use of the
    new feature.
 2. **Product** - how does this feature integrate with the rest of the
    product features
 3. **Function** - how does this feature work in total isolation

Every feature that you write should be developed through all three
contexts.  You will plan the three together but you will build and
test from the bottom up.

**Functional Context**
When you create a new feature in the software, start by creating the
smallest possible context for your development.  This should probably
result in creating a two line test that calls a function and tests for
an expected result.  Actually this is a single line that should look
something like, 'assert(test_is_ok())'.  

This requires you to completely isolate or encapsulate the
dependencies of your system.  This act alone will give you a much
sharper view of your system.  The key part of the functional context
is to make testing your new code independent of as much of the rest of
the system as possible.

**Product Context**
The product context is your opportunity to integrate the new feature
with all of the other parts of the system.  The functional context
tests the inside view of the feature, while the product context tests
the outside view.

Good testing at this level involves having real world data that you
put through the entire system to verify the results.  Consider testing
as a pipeline, 'read input > process > gather output > analyze for errors'.

**Customer Context**
The customer context also brings in the issues of how this
functionality gets deployed.  No feature works in isolation. Examine
the full customer experience and make sure that the feature integrates
consistently with all other aspects of the application.

Testing at this context involves using the product like a real
customer would and may actually involve real customers. Problems
identified at this context should be solved and verified at a lower
context level.
fields.title: Development Contexts

fields.text:
* Adopting Technology *                 -*-muse-*-

There is a process for adopting new technology or even learning new technical tricks.  These things
do not happen immediately and not everything that is tried works.

**Phases of Adoption**

Awareness
 * Identify a problem and gather potential solutions.
 * Decide on the most promising solution available.

Evaluation
 * Try to get the tool to do what it is supposed to do.
 * Find the limitations by trying to get it to do everything.

Replacement
 * Use the tool for everything that it works well for.
 * Figure out how to fully adopt it into everyday life.

Acceptance
 * Identify additional needs.
 * Customize the use of the tool to make it work better.

**Familiarity**
Success in any technology is related to how often it has been used.  With usage the skill level
increases because new situations have been encountered and resolved.
Novice      0-1
Beginner    1-3
Competent   3-20
Proficient  10-100
Expert      50+

**Efficiency of solving a new problem**
Novice      Serveral days
Beginner    Serveral hours
Competent   Two hours
Proficient  1 hour
Expert      <1 hour


See also [[Brain]]
fields.title: Adopting Technology

fields.text:
* Hearing The Bible *                 -*-muse-*-

Familiar words can lose their impact.

After years of reading and hearing the bible, it stops having the impact it once did.
- Read without benefit
- No surprises left
- God is full of surprises
- The dynamice voice of the Spirit

I have started a practice that brings fresh hearing to my bible reading.
- Select a small passage
- Say it in my own words, preserving the meaning
- Change the voice, as if Jesus was speaking to me
- Consistent with sound bible interpretation

Personal receptivity
- Different level of participation (mind/emotions)
- Personal nature of the message
- Ongoing and repeated benefit in my quiet times
- Systematic prayer guide

Lessons learned
- Start small but build
- Regular pattern (twice a week)
- Dynamic conversation with God
- Invite him into our pain

See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Hearing The Bible

fields.text:
* Frazzled *                 -*-muse-*-

There is a feeling of stress that is rooted in performance anxiety

**1. Everything is on the line**
single elimination tournament
no margin for error
success is the only acceptable outcome
assume hostile response from others

**2. Self inflicting stress**
role of self-talk
rooting in pride
must do the impossible
expections of mine and others

**3. Consequences not so dire**
compare to ideal results
people are more supportive than I believe
demanding constant praise
be a regular person

**4. Failure means learning**
not perfect yet
risk means failure (both are inevitable)
incorporate lessons in new path
normal part of process

 See also NineThings

fields.text:
* Business Experiments *                 -*-muse-*-

Experiments to validate core assumptions and develop new opportunities.

**Objectives**
Limit work to 50 hours weekly for 48 weeks yearly. Earn $120K.  ($50/hr average billing)
Operate by BusinessPolicies: Agile, Value, Trust, Solutions, Best Practices, Open
Grow company one step each year.  (2012-1, 2013-2, 2014-3, 2015-5, 2016-8, 2017-13)

**Key Assumptions**
Work in area of good job fit.
Develop long-tem equity in every action.
Limit unpaid work to 10 hours weekly.
Decide on projects strategically

**Business Experiment**
A short-term project that can be completed in 10 hours of invested time.
Each project should consume no more than $1000 or 10 hours of time.
Every project should lead to new opportunities or learning worth the price.
A failed experiment does not produce opportunity or sufficient learning.
Learning keeps an experiment from being a mistake.
The value of learning should be estimated in $.
Each experiment starts with an objective, expected outcome, cost, series of steps, and evaluation criteria.
A written outline is created for a series of experiments.
A new experiment can be completed every week or two.
Monthly objectives are a way to organize the experiements over time.

**Measure cost and benefit**
Estimate cost in hours or $ equivalent ($100/hour)
Estimate expected benefit in revenue contribution over the next year
Reject anything with a negative revenue over next year
Multiply by risk factor 

**Risk Factors**
100% - sure bet
80% - find out this month
25% - dependent on other experiments

**Learning Value**
major new skill to sell $50k
new client: (revenue - opportunity cost)/2
market lesson: opportunity/2

**Process**
Experiment backlog
    Criteria for order
    Always under consideration
Pre-action review (2 hours)
    Who am I? What do I know? Who do I know?
    Available resources and acceptable loss
    Expected benefit
    Possible outcomes and paths forward
Post-action review (2 hours)
    Compare actual to expected outcome
    Capture lessons learned
    Apply the time machine
    Create follow on experiment
Create a business history
    Experiments done
    Changes incorporated
    New directions and opportunities

**Potential Experiments**

**Team building**
Create plan for developing business relationships
    virtual meeting
    plan next step: Kevin Burke, Bryan Hurst, David White, Eric Stanley, Marshall Smith
    create advisory team

**Learn**
record YouTube videos
create Kindle book
multiple formats for delivery
learn about other teaching venues (eg. Kahn accademy)

**Teach**
Contact training company
Plan structure of Software book (plan, design, test, code)
Fifty tricks: Testing
Fifty tricks: Project planning
Fifty tricks: Shell Scripting
Fifty tricks: Python
Fifty tricks: Django

**Build**
Bid one project on contract engineering marketplace
Create draft of kindle book formatter

**Plan**
Design business planning process: based on experiments and serial focus
Draft company web site and resume with new business ideas
Draft business principles
Draft business practices


See also Business

fields.text:
* Why I Work *                 -*-muse-*-

One important reason to work is the ecconomic reality that we need money to pay for the things we
really want to do.

Tax             600 hours   30%     15 hrs/week
Saving          200 hours   10%      5 hrs/week
Giving          200 hours   10%      5 hrs/week

Housing         400 hours   20%     10 hrs/week
Living          400 hours   20%     10 hrs/week
Vacation        200 hours   10%      5 hrs/week

    Total      2000 hours
___________________________________________________________________________________________________

[[Motivation][Basic motivational needs]] according to Daniel Pink in Drive

Autonomy - My ability to choose the project details.
Mastery  - Ability to grow in technical skills.
Purpose  - Contribution to goals greater than me.
Relationship - Build a high level of trust (both ways).
___________________________________________________________________________________________________

**Basic work constraints**

Limit work to 2000 hours/year (including overhead, commute, writing)
Profit of $100,000/year
Low overhead wage ($90k/45 hrs/wk = $41/hr)
Maximum wage  ($120k/35 hr/wk = $71/hr)
Flexible work arrangement
Good fit
High trust
___________________________________________________________________________________________________

**My Perfect Job**

Based on current skills with new learning built in
Pay $75 for 40 hours/week
Long-term viability
Key Technologies: Linux, Python, Django, MySQL, ssh
Remote client with previous experience at software

See also LifeBudget

fields.text:
* Prayer As A Place *                 -*-muse-*-

What I learned from reading "Prayer As A Place" by Charles Bello


** 1. Invitation **

"If you don't let me love you, you won't finish the race."

We need to learn to simply rest in God.  We need to know his passion for us.  Receiving his love
brings refreshment and renewal.

We need to do the things that Jesus did in order to stay connected.  We can learn to live the way
that Jesus lived.

Spiritual disciplines can create a space where we encounter God.

We never know how in trouble we are until we slow down long enough for God to reveal it to us.

Spiritual disciplines are not the sign of maturity, but rather how we achieve it.

Without embracing spiritual formation we are doomed to cycles of hitting dead-ends, resulting in
cynicism.

Contemplative prayer is how we create space in our busy lives to be changed by Jesus.

Intimacy (not ministry) must be at the center of our lives.


** 2. Spiritual Disciplines **

Coming to Jesus is the only answer to weariness.  Matt 11:28

There are different movements in prayer:  Upward, Outward, Inward

The upward movement connects us with God's love for himself.  This includes worship, thanksgiving,
praise, and adoration.

The outward movement connects us with God's purpose for others.  This includes petitions,
intercession, and ministry prayer for the sick, oppressed and broken-hearted.

The inward movement connects us with God in our inner-self (motives, attitudes, and self-concept).

Evangelicals are good with the first two but not the latter.

In order to really know God, I must begin to know my true self.  This is always painful.

Beneath the roles and masks lies a self that only God fully knows.  It is difficult for us to follow
God on the journey of self-discovery.

Knowing God more causes me to admit how broken I really am.  Follow Christ as he takes you into the
darkness of your own soul.

Inward disciplines create a space where the Spirit can transform us into the nature of Christ.

** 3. Where we encounter ourselves **

Public self   - What I allow others to see in me.
Private self  - What I hide from others.
Revealed self - The blind spots that others see.
Unknown self  - The things that only God knows about.

The public and private selves must be aligned with the purpose of God in our life.  But true
transformation occurs as God touches areas that we have not seen before.

Stages of growth: Awakening, Purgation, Illumination, Union

Awakening    - deep awareness of God's presence in our lives
Purgation    - removing habits, actions, and attitudes that are contrary to God's purpose
Illumination - experiencing more of God in our joys and sorrows
Union        - experiencing God's emotions as we love like he loves

** 4. Our Inward Journey **

Cultivate an internal life that sustains outwardly-focus living

Spiritual disciplines provide a context for God to speak and transform our lives.

Growth is a long-term process that God leads us through

Seasons of life
 * First Love
 * Learning and belonging
 * Serving
 * Surrender to God's love
 * Convergence
 * Integration

** 5. Contemplative Prayer **

As place of intimacy - When we are together do we always have to discuss work?

God drives the conversation, He may take us to the abyss of sorrow, dispair, and anger. He may touch
on our place of deepest pain and dysfunction.

Process your life with God: experiences, frustrations, expectations, fears, confrontations,
opportunities

Place of transformation from the inside out.  God's word is living and active and it illuminates our
motives.

Learn to rest in God's presence with no specific expectations.

Embrace discovery


See also PrayerPractices
fields.title: Prayer As A Place

fields.text:
* Google Circle *                 -*-muse-*-

Have you ever wanted to create a small group for a discussion topic
and disband the group once the topic has played out?  Do you need to
begin a conversation with one group and then have to replay it because
you add someone else to it later?

A Google Circle is a great answer to both of these issues.  Here's how
it works.  You create your circle, begin building content, and then
add people to the circle.  Each person that you add can see all of the
content that has been previously posted.

Each person can interact with the others in the circle.  Comments and
posts can be seen by everone in that circle.  That is the good part.
The interaction of the people in your circle is contained by that
circle.  Your high school friends are not going to interact with your
boss.  And this is a good thing.

You can set up a circle with published content that is constructed
around the topic you want.  Then you can create an opt-in list to
provide this information only to people who are interested in it.
This lets you control the membership and direction of the conversation
that takes place.

It sounds like something you need then give it a try.  It's easy,
free, and fun.
fields.title: Google Circle

fields.text:
* Send Html Message * -*-muse-*- Here is the content of a desired HTML messsage to be sent through the email. Create the HTML output formatter: - Create a test-html script - Create a hello world message - Create message container - Create message body - Hook message to sender - Convert blog-send to send html messages

Thinking

How you think dictates to a large extent the quality of your life. Some people are naturally good at think through problems and coming up with great solutions. Here are a few patterns that can help you in thinking better.

List limit of 9 items

Psychological studies have shown that people can only retain up to nine items in short-term memory. This means that any list where you expect a selection ony works up to nine items. Longer lists should be broken into multiple selection lists. A reasonable list should have five or more items to be useful. Nesting can be used to handle more complicated scenarios.

Minimize mindshare

Some things we can control and other things we cannot. Try to make your circle of influence match your circle of concern. Decrease the amount of mental energy that you invest in areas where you have little influence. Save your energy for the things that you can change.

Eliminate multitasking

Your worst enemy is multiple tasks interrupting each other. Focus on one activity as much as possible until it is completed. Then go on to the next with equal focus. It is very easy for us to spend as much as 50% of our overall time just switching between multiple tasks. This has become especially bad in our modern world. Most people underestimate the cost of multitasking.

Scheduled thinking

Consider having a block of time scheduled to think through problems. Imagine knowing that you could just file that issue away for 3:00 Thursday. I recommend that you perform this think time in a location where you cannot be interrupted. Start with one hour per week. You are likely to find that you need more time, and that it is easily justified by the return that you get.

Think before you leap

When confronted with a big decision consider taking both paths. Imagine trying to live with each of the alternatives. Which one seems to carry the least risk? Which is better in the short term or in the long term? What problem might surface? What does your intuition tell you?

Brainstorm/organize

A great way to work out problems is to brainstorm. This typically involves making a list of various ideas or impression. During a brainstorm try to postpone judgment. Once you have captured a bunch of ideas you can work on grouping things together. This is the time to apply some judgment and pruning.

Four by four analysis

In order to think through, a topic try this technique. Break your main topic into four roughly equal topics. Then decompose each of them into four more topics. I found that this technique is remarkably useful to help me see the interesting aspects of almost any subject. It gives you twenty one statements that have both breadth and depth that can be explored later.

Work on only one thing

Select a single task that will be the most satisfying to have done. Postpone distractions until this task is complete. By selecting this task you are saying that this is the most important thing that you could do right now. If you feel that a legitimate interruption is likely then limit the scope of your task to complete it sooner. Then you can focus on another task when needed.

Use tools that preserve context

Don't have multiple windows up on your computer (each vying for your attention). When you run an application, make the window take the full screen. Finish one thought before going on the next. Turn off email notification, and check it between tasks. If you don't control your tools they will control you. Know what you must do in your job to succeed and create the environment that lets you focus. If your job calls for 10 second response time on IM, then play along. If it is a constant distraction, turn it off.

Try new things

Break your routine occassionally. Keep a list of random things to do for fun. At least once a week, pick a fun thing and do it. Life is too serious for most of us. Look up an old friend. Do a random act of kindness. Play a practical joke. Tell someone that you love them.

Random item from the past

Imagine having a list of things to think about someday. Now image doing a random selection from that list. This would give you a miscellaneous topic to ponder for a few minutes. I use this technique for a number of different lists. I frequently get emails of ticklers to remind me of things that I originally thought about earlier. The key idea here is to have a list of topics and a random selection. You could do the same thing by shuffling 3 x 5 cards with ideas.

Say in fewer words

I like to make complex subjects simple. One way to do this is to describe something and then try to capture the same ideas with half of the words. Is it possible to get the same idea in 5 words? Try to think in sound bites.

List of current problems

Consider keeping a list of problems that need think-time. Pick a problem and analyze it. Try all your best techniques: pros-and-cons, return on investment, brainstorming, SWOT (strength, weakness, opportunity, threat). Bang away at the problem for an hour and see if any new solutions pop out.



Sponsored by Shrinking World Solutions
Seaman's Log

You are receiving this message as a subscriber of the Seaman's Log mailing list. Your privacy is important. To learn more or unsubscribe visit http://Shrinking-world.org/unsubscribe.

See also SendHtml

fields.text:
* Josiah Project *                 -*-muse-*-

*Thriving during crunch time*

**Planning**
Process Principles
 1. Test everything 
 2. Eliminate rework (DRY)
 3. Small steps - move slow to move fast
 4. Focus on one thing - finish before you start
 5. Plan for the long-term, execute for short-term
Create a project map
 - Identify unknowns - Dreyfus model (0 100%, 1 50%, 2 25%, 10 5%) 1/2**t - 8 hours/trick 
 - Evaluate your biggest risk - new things
 - Select alternatives
Budget time -- track progress

**Design**
Frameworks/Operating Systems - Speed and clarity
Virtual Box - separate dev and production
Language
Extra libraries & tools
Automation - build tools for reproducible results

**Coding**
Version Control: changes, commit, history, get version
Master refactoring
Programming Tricks
 - Use standard data structures (text, lists, dictionaries)
 - Learn the language
Fast lookup of any question  (Google, references)

**Testing**
Three levels: features, units, product
Edit/Test Loop - minimize delay in the think loop
Two window layout (edit, test) - minimize context switch
Automatically test all code every five minutes - let success drive scope


See also WorldClassSoftware, DoVersusLearn

* Watermill Start Development *                 -*-muse-*-

*Set up the development tools every day the same*

Requires ten minutes

**Record past activity**
[[Done]]    - record time and results [[Mileage]]
[[Work]] - select the starting task for the stack

**Open windows**
Main terminal
Build window
Fred test system
Watermill test system
Editor
Support Center
Email

**Get current code**
cd $c
gk
select development env and code branch

**Build and test**
build the starting code
test on watermill (verify that mill is operational)
run all unit tests (pull, test-start)
fix anything that fails

**Integration**
when local changes are good, then integrate
pull, build, test, push

**Enter the development loop**
start with the biggest test
on each failure decrease the testing scope
on each success increase the testing scope
set 25 minute timer for each iteration
each iteration ends with a commit
each commit must be tested

See also [[Brain]], DevelopmentRules, RapidDevelopment
fields.title: Watermill Start Development

fields.text:
* Media Shout *                 -*-muse-*-

The following info will be useful to train people how to setup Media Shout

Sunday Morning Process

These steps must be done to properly setup Media Shout for use in the
Windsor Campus of the Vineyard.   Each of these main steps is really
just of bunch of detailed steps to follow.

 * Turn on projectors and computers
 * Copy content
 * Add songs
 * Add announcements
 * Add teaching slides
 * Add rolling ads
 * Hook up teaching video
 * Setup count down

Note: While working with Media Shout, save early and save often.


1. Turn on projectors and computers

Use the remotes to turn on the two side projectors and the main
projector.  Turn on the computers after the projectors are on.


2. Delete the old content

Run Media Shout and select "Sunday" folder.  Remove the old contents
from the script.
 * Teaching slides
 * Songs
 * Announcements
 * Rolling Ads


3. Copy content

Open the Drop Box and Today folders.  Delete the contents of the
previous folders and copy the contents of the following folders from
the Dropbox to the "Today" sub-folders.
 * Teaching slides
 * Announcements
 * Rolling ads


4. Add songs

Locate the songs from the Worship Next web site.  Find the appointment
for the song list.  Search for each song and add it to the script.
Proof the song screens.
Make sure that the template is applied to each song.
Set the order of the songs


5. Add announcements

Insert graphics for the Announcements from the Today folder.
Adjust the order for the ads to match the flow of the service.


6. Add teaching slides

Insert graphics for the Teaching slides from the Today folder.


7. Add rolling ads

Insert graphics for the  Rolling ads from the Today folder.
Add 8 second timer for each add.
Edit the Script to loop to the first ad.  Test it.


8. Hook up teaching video

On the main screen computer Insert Video File for the main teaching.


9. Setup count down

Locate a suitable countdown video. Insert it as a Video File.
fields.title: Media Shout

Simple workflow should be used until more sophistication is required.

many applications will only require this
