fields.text:
* Fifty Tricks to Fight Bit Rot *                 -*-muse-*-
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Agile Software Architecture**
 Mark Seaman
 Shrinking World Solution
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Bio**
32 years as a professional developer
27 years at HP (software and firmware for consumers)
5 years as a consultant (real-time control & web dev)
50 product cycles & million lines of code

Everything is on the web site at http://shrinking-world.org
_____________________________________________________________________________

**Test-Driven Architecture**
using patterns to drive solutions
apply lessons from TDD to improve system architecture

**Architecture:**
Use patterns to deliver solutions

Programming is a mental activity done by humans

Software lasts forever

**Change is Constant**
System age because they are rigid
The world changes constantly
Systems are flexible only if they are flexed

**Knowledge:**
 Engineering, Technology, Domain

Engineering principles work everywhere

**Personal Journey**
Goal: Double productivity in 2011
Keys: Domain, Tools, Process

**Fundamental Insights:**
Four-stroked development engine
Personal automation

Lazy, Greedy, Easily Bored, Forgetful

Diligent, Work for Food, Repetition, Steel Trap

**Principles**
Limit the context to move faster
All knowledge is in scripts
Everything is text
Tests run continuously
Each test case produced output which is verified
Good answers are accepted and used later
Little problems can cause large pain
Pay down technical debt early
 
**Four-stroke Development:**
Extend  - add new features
Fix     - correct defects
Test    - find remaining defects
Improve - match the structure to the problem

**How much does the boss care**?
 ****   Extend
 **     Fix
 *      Test
        Improve

Balance the activity by incremental investment

Testing drives the entire development stack

**Time to revolutionize testing**
 * Errors go undetected
 * Debug take a long time
 * Development proceeds slowly
 * Maintenance is eating our lunch

Produce dramatic savings

**Skepticism is healthy**

 * Denial - that's nothing new

 * Anger/Barganing - that will never work

 * Acceptance - never do it any other way

**What's the Trick ?**
Tactical knowledge for a small context (idioms, hacks, patterns)
Tricks must be adapted to your context
Low half-life, but transferrable

**Example tricks:**
    BitBlt to a device context
    Hydrate objects from a database
    Postback of form data

1 hour or 1 day

10x productivity difference

**System Testing**
 1. Execute a command
 2. Verify the output
 3. Report unexpected results
 4. Build a test inventory

**Each Trick**
 * Principle
 * How to apply it
 * Code to illustrate usage

**Overview of tricks**
Tools selection
Testing framework
Product structure
Incremental features
Design pivot

**Architecture is temporal**
Everything is an experiment
Architecture is the current design that meets the need
As things change the architecture must evolve
You can not predict the future, adapt instead

Flexibile systems are flexed

**Testing a system**
Unit tests
System tests

**Unit tests**
 - test the Innards

**Example:**
    MyApp --> MyFunc --> OtherStuff
    MyTest --> MyFunc, OtherStuff

**Hard problem:**
Manage dependencies

**System test**
 - test the Outards

**Hard problem:**
Feature surface

Unit testing is well covered
System testing needs more attention

**Stock your catalog with new tricks**
learn new tricks
customize them for your context
evaluate effectiveness
standardize on the best practice

Examples --> Tricks --> Principles

Revealing my secrets
Some of these will work for you
Prune and adapt
_____________________________________________________________________________

Trickery & Skull-duggery
_____________________________________________________________________________

**1. Tool selection**

**Be a polyglot**
Learn different languages for different situations
Create your own domain mapping
Always choose the language that gives you the highest leverage

Have a preferred tool for each situation

 * Deal with files or computer control  -- bash
 * Work with individual file contents   -- python
 * Work with data interchange           -- xml
 * Web pages and data                   -- Django
 * Web page content                     -- HTML, CSS
 * Data storage and manipulation        -- MySQL
 * Real-time control system             -- C++
 * Fancy client apps                    -- Qt
 * Integrating with a Java system       -- Java
 * Integrating .Net components          -- .Net
 * Integrating PHP                      -- PHP

**Match tools to the problem**
Hard problems require heavy tools
Easy problems require light tools
Say it in one line

Code:
    cat *.txt   # Join files the easy way

**Build your own domain framework**
Build simplest app you can (do not anticipate)
Refactor common pieces into reusable parts
Eliminate all duplication
Buy two; third one's free

**Three pieces of code**
Development, Tests, Deployment, Product

**Build bridges**
Secret of reuse
Convert from one data type to another
Common problem

**Slide Slinger Project**
Convert from text format to HTML presentation
Range of features that go beyond the trivial
Illustrates concepts and tricks
  
**Slide Slinger Requirements**
 * Use Reveal.js
 * Read standard text file
 * Output context for existing Java Script presentation engine
 * Use Four-stroke Development

**Start a new project**
Create fresh things with a fresh project.
Then integrate them into existing work.

Code:
    export p=~/swarch
    mkdir -p $p
    cd $p
_____________________________________________________________________________

**2. Automation**

Genies and wishes

**Create a context for commands**
Make a place to create commands

Code:
    mkdir -p $p/bin $p/test
    tree
    PATH=$p/bin:$p/test:$PATH

**Create a command to rule them all**
Move from memory to scripts

Code:
    pwd && ls -l
    
    exe l 'clear && pwd && ls -l'

    echo $2 > $1 && chmod +x "$1"

**Save knowledge in scripts**
Encapsulation is key
Choose names you will remember
Create throw away commands
Tools augment your knowledge and capabilities

Code:
    vi /home/seaman/Documents/Brain/FightBitRot

    vi $br/FightBitRot

    be FightBitRot

    exe x 'be FightBitRot'

**Count keystrokes**
How many keystrokes does it take to do things you do every hour or every minute?
 * Go to your favorite directory
 * Check for changes
 * Execute your favorite command

Code:
    exe d      'cd $p'

    exe l      'ls -l $p/bin $p/test'

    exe show 'cat `which $1`'       

    show d 
    show l
    show show

**Analyze your context switches**
Switching context is very expensive
Look for ways to stay mentally engaged
Optimize for your brain

Code:
    d      # Go to directory
    l      # List my files
    e      # Edit something
    a      # Show all changes
    c      # Commit all changes
    h      # History of commands
    s      # Search my code

**Fold several concepts into a result**
Name the result you want
Create a script that gets you there

Code:
    scp /home/seaman/Documents/Brain/FightBitRot 192.168.1.100:/home/seaman/Documents/Brain/FightBitRot
    push-file FightBitRot

    send-tps-report

**Build your own catalog of practices**
Identify the essential operations
Implement each operation with a single line of code
Run it and fix it

Code:
    run     # Execute this project
    tst     # Run all the tests
    deploy  # Share the results with others
    send    # Send an email

**Build a tool to automate each practice**
Encapsulation is key to effectiveness
Pick a name that matches the result
Wrap the standard commands to hide to complexity
Create commands that support your workflow

Code:
    # Create command to capture ideas
    exe idea 'echo "$*" >> $p/ideas.txt && cat $p/ideas.txt'
    show idea

    # Have some ideas
    idea 'Milestones:'
    idea ' * Basic text mapping application'
    idea ' * Slide content creator'
    idea ' * Clean up format'
    idea ' * Handle code blocks'
    idea ' * Vertical slides'
    clear && idea

    # Command to edit ideas
    exe ideas 'e  $p/ideas.txt' 

**Use version control for everything**
Project time is too precious to be confused
Move from backup to sharing (computers come and go, but data lives forever)
250 hours of savings in a year

Code:
    git init
    exe changes 'd && git status' && changes
    exe commit  'git add -A . && git commit -m"$1"'  && commit "Automatic checkin"
    alias c=commit
    alias a=changes
_____________________________________________________________________________

**3. Test Framework**
<<<<<<< HEAD

Building a castle
=======
>>>>>>> 5a0d0b505fc1615ef4700ba2bd76d83683b9f580

**Unit Tests build on assert**
Test frameworks manage execution and reporting of results
Build your own for light weight testing

Code:
    assert (2+2==4)
    assert (call_my_function("Yo Dude") = 'OK')

**Scriptable applications are testable**
Text --> Program --> Text

Code:
    cd test

    # Create an input and a correct file
    echo "This is some input text" > txt.in
    cp   txt.in  txt.correct

    # Create a program
    exe sling 'echo Slinging slides...'
    sling

    # Run the program and check the output
    sling < txt.in > txt.out
    diff txt.out txt.in

    # Fix the failure by making sling pass the input
    exe sling 'cat'

    # Create a correct file to check
    sling < txt.in > txt.out
    diff txt.out txt.correct
    
**Create a test before modifying the code**
Define what you want to work
Write the simplest test that fails (illustrating the defect)
Isolate to a single function

Code:
    # Create a new test
    show tnew
    tnew txt 'sling < txt.in'

    # Run the test
    show trun

    # Show the source code for the test
    tshow txt

    # Pass
    trun txt                      

**Create a second simple test**
Use new data to test something different
Create a hard coded test case

Code:
    make-sample-files
    tree

    # Create a new test
    tnew copy-all 'cat data/*.txt | sling'
    tshow copy-all
    
    # Run the test
    trun copy-all

**Accept the results as new answer**
Decide what the correct answer should be
Use the running system to evaluate the answers

Code:
    # View the output
    show tout
    tout copy-all

    # Accept the answer as correct
    show tlike
    tlike copy-all
    
**Run all my tests**
Loop through the test directory on each 'tst' file

Code:
    # Run all tests
    show tst
    tst

**Add more tests**
Watch directories for all changes

Code:
    tnew data-watch 'ls data'
    tst
    tlike data-watch
    touch data/x
    tst
_____________________________________________________________________________

**4. System testing**

Yank the chain
**
Test the story**
Graduated complexity: Simple, Medium, Hard
Encapsulate your logic in a named test

Code:
    # Run test (no input)
    tnew no-input 'sling < /dev/null'

    # Generate input
    tnew dir-listing 'ls *|sling'
    
**Cause failures**
Create failures occasionally to ensure that tests catch them

Code:
    # Make an old test fail   
    rm test/data/x
    tst

**Review and fix failures**
List the failed tests
Show all failure details
Rerun tests
Accept answers

Code:
    # Review all failed tests
    tfail
    tresult
    trun  data-watch     
    tout  data-watch     
    tlike data-watch      

**Fix each failing test**
What happened?
Why?
Fix test or product?
Better coverage?

**Both Kinds of Problems**
Known - Fix before they breed
Unknown - Each mystery is a clue
_____________________________________________________________________________

**5. Create a new app**

**New context is cheaper than the old one**
Create an stand alone feature and with tests
Integrate the working result
Build a simple story

Code:
    # Create a python script
    exe sling-body '#!/usr/bin/python'
    ew  sling-body

**Make your job easier**
Change things to match your perfect idea
Create new commands
Create new tests
Simplify

Code: 
    ew l
    get Step1 bin/l

**Test each case**
Create data to produce each unique context
Create a one line test that uses the data
Compare to expected results

Code:
    # Modify sling body
    from sys import stdin
    print stdin.read()

    # Fix the test
    tshow  sling-body
    tnew no-slide-body   'echo | sling-body'
    tnew one-slide-body  'echo slide1 | sling-body'

**Extend features**
Add harder test cases 
Fix the product to match the test

Code:
    print '<slide>'
    text = print stdin.read().slit('\n')
    for line in text:
        if len(line)>0:
            print line
    print '</slide>'

**Multiple slides**
Blank line should be a slide break
But only if there is text for the slide

Code:
    slide1
       text
       more text
    
    slide2
       text
        more text

    # Get stored tests
    get Step2

**Refactor after each step**
Group related functionality
Remove any duplication
Test everything; coverage matters

Code:
    # Refactor main
    get Step3
    # Refactor process one line
    get Step4
    # Refactor process with parm
    get Step5
    
**Use real data**
This approach allows you to verify with contrived cases
Then move quickly to real-world examples

Code:
    # Get a large data file
    cp $br/FightBitRot test/data
    get Step6

    # Create a test to read it
    tnew bit-rot 'sling-body < data/FightBitRot'
    tst
    
    # Look at the results
    tout bit-rot
    tlike bit-rot

**Other unexpected changes**
You cannot plan every change
The system will report unexpected changes automatically

Code:
    tlike data-watch

**Extend the tests**
Cause intended corruption to verify the test coverage

Code:
    # Corrupt the correct answer files
    get Step7

**Extend the feature set**
Add features, refactor, add tests

Code:
    # First line of each slide must be a heading
    get Step8

    # Later lines must be paragraphs
    get Step9

**Connect to other systems**
Merge in contents of other frameworks and libraries
Test the library
Package your entire development chain

Code:
    cptree ~/slide-slinger/reveal reveal
    ls 
    ls reveal
    ls -l -R reveal
    tree reveal
    tree -s reveal
    tnew reveal-tree 'tree -s $p/reveal'

**Work with other tools**
Remove extra files and see how testing catches it

Code:
    rm sling.html xxx.html  
    mv sling/*.html .
    rm -rf sling/
    tst

**Implement requirements with tools**
Require all tests to pass in order to commit changes
Bind tests to commit

Code:
    # Create a failure
    touch reveal/x  
    tfail

    # Test before commit
    tst; [[ -z "`tfail`" ] ] &&

**Script your sharing**
Implement one acceptable sharing path
Script a custom work flow

Code:
    pull && tst && push

**Test features before they exist**
Create a sling-slides application
Expect a certain output in order to be correct

Code:
    # Create a new application
    cp bin/sling-body bin/sling-html

    # Run program with no output
    sling-html < /dev/null

    # Create a test with no input
    tnew blank-html 'sling-html < /dev/null'

    # Create expected output
    cp reveal/index.html test/blank-html.correct
    
    # Create other tests
    tnew requirements-html 'cat data/Requirements.txt | sling-html'

**Use external verification**
Create an output file using a test
Verify that the output is good before accepting the results of the test

Code:
    # Run the browser on the output
    cp test/requirements-html.out reveal/requirements.html
    w reveal/requirements.html

    # More difficult example
    sling-html < test/data/FightBitRot > reveal/FightBitRot.html
    w reveal/FightBitRot.html

**Test multiple sources of code**
Libraries, HTML templates, Scripts, Programs, Data files, Distributed systems
Combined performance is what is tested

Code:
     tst  # Full system test

**Refactor to simplify**
Find the duplication
Pull it out and call it where needed

Code:

Setup windows

Check in at each point of stability

Work on a development branch
Integrate daily

**Release planning**
Create a stabilization branch when close to release
Let master be rapidly progressing

fields.text:
* Simple Sites *                 -*-muse-*-

SimpleApps

Business Strategy
    Management
        Limited partenership
            Skills: Business/Marketing, Software dev
            R & D (web, mobile)
            Operations (hosting, sales)
        Short project cycles
            Prioritized features
            Series of MVPs (minumum viable products)
            Build on stable base
        Growth
            Pilot project - First customer
            Operations break-even
            Development cost break-even
            Generate $50k/year profit
        Finance
            Partners provide leadership and ownership  (three initially)
            Parnerts provide time and expertise to bootstrap the business
            All work is pay for services
            Cash reserves of 20% (of this year's revenue)
    Marketing
        Value propositions
            Create custom data driven web sites
            Reusable code for low cost
            Simple and elegant vertical apps
            Allows high-margin for web resellers
        Pricing
            End-user pricing  (1 site,   $2000/data type)
            Wholesale pricing (5 sites,  $100/data type)
            Partnership       (10 sites, $500/data type)
            Typical site      ($2.5K wholesale - $10k consumer)
        Competition
            CMS (Joomla, Plone) - better user experience for vertical apps
            Community (Drupal, Word Press) - better data handling for business rules
            Web frameworks - too much effort to create end-user solutions
            Full custom webdev - 4x cheaper
        Creating awareness
            Value chain (End users, Vertical app host, App Reseller, Production)
            Shrinking World Solution (Production house)
            Partnerships for each stage of value chain
    Engineering
        Technology
            Stack: Django, Python, MySQL, Linux, Seamix, Web Faction
            Mobile app: Android, iOS
            Build reusable infrastructure
            Engineer long-term efficiency
            Peerless engineering practices
        MVP (4 projects in 4 months)
            Project 1 - solve all key engineering issues
            Project 2 - produce a well-factored framework
            Project 3 - hit peak effectiveness
            Project 4 - create profit margin
        Expansion
            First client for project 1
            Initial partner (3 sites)
            Web hosting partnership
        Development cost
            Early dev cost (8 hours/data type)
            After four projects (1 hour/data type)
            Mobile app (1 day/app)
            

See also [[Business]]

fields.text:
* Jordan Partnership *                 -*-muse-*-

**Charter**

Work together to strengthen the church in Jordan and the middle-east.


**Key themes**

Crossing barriers: Nazarene/Assembly of God, Arab church/Oasis, Americans/Jordanians
Overcoming differences is a living demonstration of reconcilation
Motivated by a desire to serve
Active prayer communities (with exchange trips)


**Our commitment**

Pray for the church in the middle-east
Communicate regularly with other partners
Look for opportunity the engage with others


**Our Prayer**

Peace

    Violence stops the advancement of God's kingdom.
    We are called to be peace makers.
    God's people must model forgiveness
    There are many competing factions that would seek to break the peace
    Satan is the father of lies and murder

Prosperity

    We seek prosperity and justice for all
    God has a special place in his heart for the poor
    We must give a voice to those who have none

Church

    Our goal is to support the Arab church
    We play a supporting role
    We actively look for opportunities to serve

Leadership

    The Arabs are most aware of what is needed
    Leaders are more important than programs or buildings
    Youth are the key to the church in Jordan
    We seek to create reproducible models of ministry 


**Strategy**

Collaboration 
    Create a charter for partnership
    Create channels for regular communication
    Recruit partners
    Organize exchange program

Train leaders
    Help organize conferences to assist local church leaders
    Create regular schedule for training events

Reach the youth
    Support youth programs in Jordan
    Help create resources for the next generation
    Invest in young leaders

Support the local church
    Listen to local church leaders
    Work together to demonstrate unity

Outreach to the poor
    Invest in current opportunities (eg. Sri Lanka, Philipines, Syrians)
    Work with young leaders in the Arab church
    Integrate Jordanian church and Oasis



See also JordanTrip
fields.title: Jordan Partnership

fields.text:
* Life Budget *                 -*-muse-*-
___________________________________________________________________________________________

Our life only has so many hours left.  How we spend those hours is important.  We can choose to
spend those hours making money, or spent money to purchase time.  Either way there is a direct
exchange between money and time.

A life budget combines the concept of budgeting both money & time spending. If you have a full time
job then you probably spend at least 2000 a year working. You do this so that you can earn money to
spend time on the other things that you enjoy.

Spending habits reflect the reasons why you work.  You can replace each dollar amount with the
equivalent amount of time spent working to pay for it.  For example, if you spend $1000/month on a
house payment and make $50/hour, then your house costs you 20 hours/month.

Here's how it works. 
 1. Create a budget using last years actual spending, limiting yourself to six categories.
 2. Convert the budget to time, where total dollars equals 2000 hours.
 3. Create a weekly time budget, showing the six categories.  
 4. Create an annual time budget for how you spend the 5000 hours each year  
 5. Combine these to show work hours as percentages that match the money spent
 6. Group these into large categories (us/them, work/play)

___________________________________________________________________________________________

See also [[Time]]
fields.title: Life Budget

fields.text:
* Directory Navigation *                 -*-muse-*-

The most frequent thing that you do when using a computer is move around the file system.  We are
going to make this extremely efficient by implementing the operations that you do 1000 times a day
as one letter commands.

    l - Show my files
    u - Go up one directory
    d - Choose a new directory (and push the current one)
    b - Go back to the last direction (on the stack)

To create these command we will be creating both shell scripts and functions.  A shell script runs
by starting up a new program.  When it exits any changes to the environment (like cd) are lost.  A
command like 'l' does not need to change the current environment.  It is implemented as a shell
script.

    $ echo 'clear;ls $*' > bin/l    # Create the script
    $ chmod +x bin/l                # Make exe
    $ l bin                         # Test it

The 'u' command will be an alias so that the changed directory applies to the currently executing
shell.

    $ echo "alias u='cd ..;l'" >> .bashrc   # Append alias to profile
    $ . .bashrc                             # Make it active
    $ cd bin; u                             # Test it

The 'd' command must take an argument so it must be a shell function.

    $ echo 'function d { pushd $1;l }' >> .bashrc  # Append function to profile
    $ . .bashrc                             # Make it active
    $ d bin                                 # Test it

Finally the 'b' command can be an alias.

    $ echo "alias b='popd;l'" >> .bashrc    # Append alias to profile
    $ . .bashrc                             # Make it active
    $ d bin; b                              # Test it

Mess with this until you feel totally comfortable with the ideas here.


See also DaysOfLinux
fields.title: Directory Navigation

* Micro Burst *                 -*-muse-*-

microburst work style
    work in short bursts with no distractions
        use activity timer to work for 20 minutes
        select a single goal
        do not allow any distractions
        record the activity done
    take a short break to id the next burst
        stand up for the break time
        select a rest activity
        do that for 10 minutes
        watch the clock
    take care of non-burst business
        create a mental break
        take care of physical needs
        interact with people
        balance goals and immediate needs
    keep lists for burst and rest items
        break down key project tasks into bursts
        create a list for non-project goals
        work on top priorities first
        balance multiple clients by allocating bursts

fields.text:
* Weekly Highlights *                 -*-muse-*-

Each week has a few events that stand out from all the rest.  These are typically also moments that
are captured in the daily highlights.

**Week of Feb 4**

Lucy has been visiting us for the last two weeks. Last week she collapsed and was taken by ambulance
to the hospital where she received a pace maker. After four days in the hospital she returned home
where she continues to mend. This has increased our overall stress level, but God is working
everything out.

Josiah is doing really good now.  He has been visiting a chairopracter since November which has had
a remarkable impact on him.  Cassandriel is now five months old and so precious.  Josiah and Sam are
both great parents.  So loving and patient.

Rachel is doing great.  She plans to return from Japan in August.

Christine recently started working at Xerox in the call center.  She is in her fourth week of
training.

I had some ups and downs with the business but feel good moving forward with it.  I recently have
taken on learning about Node.js and related technology to use for the pipe scan project.  I'm
exploring setting up a new business to do vertical applications for end users.


**Week of July 26**

Josiah has been essentially disabled since May 4.  The first week of July he was granted a leave of
absence from his doctoral program for up to a year.  Last week he had a battery of tests including
MRI and EEG.  He said that the EEG captured 20-30 events that can be analyzed.  With a baby girl on
the way in October, Josiah and Sam are very stressed over the future.

In April I decided to end my work with Watermill.  Over the four years I have been working with them
I have been able to build what they needed.  Now they don't need the full-time work from someone
like me.  I am planning on working for Watermill one day each week during August.

I have been working on plans for the next phase of my career.  The most promising path forward is to
develop a short course on software engineering that I can use to help get longer term consulting
work. I will present a training session to the software arichtects group in three weeks on Fighting
Bit Rot.  I hope that this will lead to other work opportunities.

**Week of Jan 16**

This week I saw how volatile life can really be.  I was almost in a head-on accident, which would
have been my fault.  I ran a red light, while rushing to get through an intersection on snowy roads.

A day later a teen was killed when a driver crossed the line on 257. 

A routine furnace inspedtion revealed that our furnace was inproperly constructed.  We replaced it
with a new one and an air conditioner.  This cost us $11K that we were not expecting.

I finally got a budget for our family.  It has a nice simple outline: Tax 30%, Giving Housing Living
all 20%, Vaction 10%.

My writing projects are really taking off now.  I am so pleased.  It is very fun to work on these projects.


**Week of Nov 27**

This week was an intense week of work after a lot of time off.  We are trying to release the
software for the new watermills by the end of the year.  We had two big snow storms which affected
the travel to Frederick.  I worked at home on Thursday, and Eric called in paniced on Friday,
wanting me to come to Frederick to fix bugs that he had just found in testing.  I had told him
earlier that I would work on Friday, but had not yet started by noon.

I learned enough Emacs lisp to be able to start automating basic commands. This is terribly exciting
to me.  I have also mapped out a strategy for publishing multiple blogs and books.

I had my second meeting with Tim Musslewhite this week. It was a bit tentative.  But I think we are
still working on finding the right way to interact.

I realized that I really don't like the month of December.  I hate having to put up decorations and
the conflict that inevitably follows it.  I really dislike the issues with over spending, over
committing, and extra demands that put way too much stress on everyone.  For me the main meaning of
Christmas is conflict.  It reveals the greatest level of tension between Stacie and I.

We had our second meeting with the Hoods in Jordan.  God is putting together something very
special.  We feel that we are really connecting with them.

The Windsor church leaders had a Christmas party at the Nardins' house.  There was a time during the
party where each person was able to share about what they really appreciated about someone else.  It
was very moving and encouraging.


**Week of Nov 20**

This week was filled with great times to connect with both Eric Stanley and Josiah.  We shared ideas
and stories about people that they were interacting with, and life experiences.

This week I launched the Dr Prof Tips newsletter and got my first 20 subscribers.  I got two books on
blogging which were very helpful.  I also found out about the Octopress platform which is similar to
MyBook.

Rick Olmstead announced this week that we will be focusing on reaching the next generation.  I am
very excited about that and am praying about what my role will be.


See also PrayerPractices,  [[Highlights]]
fields.title: Weekly Highlights

fields.text:
* Computer Cloning *                 -*-muse-*-

It is possible to quickly setup a new computer by cloning the setup of a previously configured
computer system.  This topic will show you how to accomplish this step-by-step.

Reduce the pain of setting up a new computer.  By following this process you can configure a new
computer system in about 2 hours.  This may be just the incentive that you need to try out a Linux
operating system.  Quick cloning of computer environments is very easy in Linux compared to other
available operating systems.

We all know the pain of setting up a new computer system.  Even though people that work with
computers all of the time have set up many computer systems in the past.

I regularly used about 7 different operating environments.  These differ by location, mobility,
ownership, and purpose.  I now have a recipe that allows a new computer environment to start doing
useful work in less than an hour.  Linux lends itself to this type of quick start.

I still find that setting up Windows systems is extremely time intensive.  First, Ubuntu is
installed off of the Live CD.  This operation takes about 20 minutes with about 5 minutes of setup
time and a break to watch a half-hour TV show.  When you return you are ready to customize the
environment.

I have special commands that I am constantly updating.  Currently I have about 150 commands that
automate everything that I do with the computer.

These commands are all stored in a directory called bin in my home directory.  They can be moved by
network or thumb drive to any new system.  Next I link my script to customize the shell from my home
directory using:

  	ln ~/bin/bashrc ~/.bashrc

Now you can make this active.

	. ~/.bashrc

This process lets you get up and running in well less than an hour with a computer environment that
has all of your favorite automation tools already configured.  Additional configuration can be done
by including a setup-computer script in your bin directory.

See also ComputerSetup
fields.title: Computer Cloning
